article name: Martin O'Malley to Drop Out of Democratic Presidential Race; Campaign overshadowed by Clinton, Sanders
article text:
DES MOINES, IOWA--The first casualty of Iowa's caucuses is former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who announced Monday night that he was dropping out of the Democratic presidential race after a disappointing showing .
Mr. O'Malley told supporters at a Des Moines bar that he was suspending a campaign that never gained traction against rivals Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. He did not endorse either of the two.
With about 90% of the Iowa caucus results reported, Mr. O'Malley stood at less than 1%.
Flashing smiles, Mr. O'Malley said: "When I got into this, eight months ago, I had no doubt that it would be a tough fight. And it has been a tough fight."
Election 2016
* Iowa Caucuses: Live Coverage
* Voters Seek Change at Iowa Caucuses
* Photos: Iowa Caucuses Kick Off U.S. Presidential Election
* How the Iowa Caucuses Work
Mr. Sanders, in a speech late Monday might, thanked Mr. O'Malley. "He should know that he contributed a whole lot to the dialogue," the Vermont senator said.
Mr. O'Malley had sought to position himself as a liberal alternative to Mr. Sanders--a seasoned executive who had the skills to put his ideals into practice. At age 53, he also cast himself as part of a younger generation who was not part of Washington's political culture. The arguments fell flat, though, and he never came within striking distance of Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Clinton. In national polls he never cracked an average of 5%, according to Real Clear Politics.
After Mr. O'Malley dropped out, his campaign manager, David Hamrick, sent out an email saying, "Entering the race as an unknown, he always faced long odds--especially against a candidate as universally known as Secretary Clinton."
Mr. O'Malley jumped in the race in May and struggled to gain name recognition or raise the money needed to be competitive. At some of his events in Iowa, people who came to see him had no idea where he was from or what offices he had held. He collected about $5 million in campaign contributions, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. By contrast, Mr. Sanders raised $20 million in the month of January alone.
When it came to policy, Mr. O'Malley had little to offer that distinguished him from his rivals. All have said they favor gun control, aggressive steps to combat global climate change and an immigration overhaul that provides undocumented immigrants a path to citizenship.
Mr. O'Malley put great stock in the Democratic debates. A fluid speaker with good looks, he hoped to turn in strong debate performances that would cause Clinton and Sanders backers to give him a fresh look. But the schedule approved by Democratic National Committee chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz did him no favors. The party set a total of only six debates and threatened to punish candidates who took part in debates that it had not sanctioned. Mr. O'Malley accused the party leadership of favoring Mrs. Clinton.
In a speech at a Democratic National Committee gathering in Minneapolis in August, he took aim at the party's decision to hold only six debates, saying, "Whose decree is this actually? Where did it come from? To what end and what purpose? What national or party interest does this decree serve?"
(Under pressure from Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton, the party now seems likely to accept more debates .)
Yet when the debates began last October, Mr. O'Malley found himself a bit player on stage. He could not match Mrs. Clinton's command of policy detail or Mr. Sanders's populist fervor.
Before the caucuses, O'Malley aides signaled that the Iowa results would determine whether he would plow forward. When Iowans gathered for the caucuses Monday night, they showed little appetite for his candidacy.
At a West Des Moines church, nearly 300 people crammed into a room that was set up to hold about half as many caucusgoers. Only five supported Mr. O'Malley; three were undecided. As the numbers were read aloud, an O'Malley supporter yelled out, "We beat undecided!"

article name: Clinton, Sanders Locked in Tight Race for Delegates; Clinton campaign says it's well positioned; Sanders vows to press on
article text:
Battling for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders were locked in a tight race for Iowa's delegates and the momentum that comes with a win in the nation's first contest.
Mrs. Clinton maintained a narrow lead through much of the night, but with 93% of precincts reporting, her advantage was just 49.8% of the delegates versus 49.6% for Mr. Sanders, according to tabulations from the Iowa Democratic Party.
Election 2016
* Voters' Desire for Change Hints at Lingering Unease
* Iowans Entertain Radical Messages Amid Seeming Prosperity
* Why Democratic Lawmakers Hope Cruz or Trump Win GOP Race
*
Interview With Jane Sanders: Bernie's Words Are Backed by 'Real Plans'
"It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for," Mrs. Clinton told supporters in Des Moines late Monday night, ahead of the announcement of final results. She didn't declare victory but thanked the people of Iowa and said she was "breathing a big sigh of relief."
Corrections & Amplifications: The Democratic race in Iowa remains too close to call. An earlier version of this article prematurely named Hillary Clinton a winner. (Feb. 2, 2016)

article name: Federal Lawmakers Ramp Up Response to Flint Water Crisis; House committee issues subpoenas, Democratic senators seek money, and Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders plan debate in city
article text:
Scott Calvert, Siobhan Hughes and Kristina Peterson contributed to this article.
WASHINGTON--Federal lawmakers Wednesday ratcheted up their response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., as a House committee subpoenaed government officials and Democratic senators urged that money be set aside to address the problem.
The Democratic Party also said its two presidential hopefuls, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders (D., Vt.), would hold a debate in Flint on March 6 as a way to draw attention to the contaminated-water issue.
Flint has been embroiled in a crisis for months , after the city began taking its drinking water from the Flint River, which caused lead levels to reach dangerous heights . The move was meant to be temporary as the city cut costs by switching from Detroit's water system to another water authority.
Rep. Jason Chafftez (R., Utah), chairman of the House oversight committee, said Wednesday he issued subpoenas to two officials to force them to appear at a deposition with committee lawyers regarding Flint's water crisis.
More Flint Coverage
* Hearings Open on Flint Water Crisis
* New Trouble Knocks Flint as Mortgage Firms Require Proof of Safe Water
* Detroit Schools' Emergency Manager to Step Down
* Lead Levels in Flint Remain Extremely High at Some Locations
* State Officials in Flint Got Bottled Water Months Before Warning Not to Drink It
* U.S. Cities Scrutinize Water Systems in Wake of Flint
* Series of Mistakes Tainted Flint Water
The committee had invited three officials--Miguel Del Toral, a water official at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; former EPA Regional Administrator Susan Hedman, who resigned Monday over the crisis; and former Flint emergency manager Darnell Earley--to testify at a hearing Wednesday. It was the first congressional hearing on the crisis since it came to national attention last fall.
The three officials declined to appear.
Nichole Distefano, an associate administrator at the EPA, told the committee in a letter last week "it would be highly unusual for the agency to send a non-supervisory regional career staff member" like Mr. Del Toral to testify before Congress, the letter stated, and Mr. Del Toral was focused on addressing the crisis in Flint.
The committee had invited Mr. Del Toral because he wrote a memo to EPA colleagues in June 2015 detailing the high levels of lead in Flint's drinking water. The committee accepted his decision not to testify.
However, Mr. Chaffetz said he deployed the subpoenas, which have legal force, to bring Mr. Earley and Ms. Hedman to Washington for a deposition. Whether Mr. Chaffetz would also try to compel them to appear at a public hearing hasn't been decided, according to a panel spokeswoman.
An attorney representing Mr. Earley, A. Scott Bolden, said the former emergency manager would be willing to meet with and testify before the committee "subject to his constitutional rights and subject to any privileges he would enjoy." Witnesses can choose to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination, declining to answer questions, though Mr. Bolden didn't cite that provision in particular.
Ms. Hedman, the former EPA regional administrator for Michigan, couldn't be reached for comment.
Five other witnesses, including an official from the EPA and the director of Michigan's Department of Environmental Quality, testified Wednesday.
Joel Beauvais, acting deputy assistant administrator for the EPA's office of water, defended his agency's actions before the House committee and said the first responsibility for responding to the crisis fell to state and local governments.
Flint also took center stage Wednesday in the Senate debate on an energy bill, as Democrats and Republicans negotiated over a Democratic amendment providing $200 million in direct funds for Flint and as much as $600 million in loans and other financing.
"We're looking for some help from the federal government for a problem that was created by the state of Michigan and with thousands of victims," said Sen. Dick Durbin (D., Ill.), the second-ranking Senate Democrat.
Republicans said they were concerned about the federal government spending money to tackle a non-federal problem. The Democratic proposal "puts the cart ahead of the horse in terms of letting local and state government address what is a local and state problem," said Sen. John Cornyn (R., Texas), the second-ranking Senate Republican.
The issue has at times inflamed political sensitivities. Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, has apologized for the crisis, and Democrats have cited it as evidence of GOP neglect of infrastructure and public health. Republicans have framed it as a failure of government more broadly.
At the House hearing, members of both parties chiefly criticized the state of Michigan but also chided the EPA for not responding more aggressively when Mr. Del Toral's memo pointed to high levels of lead in Flint's water.
The EPA said there is no safe level of exposure to lead, a potent neurotoxin that is especially damaging to children because it harms development of the brain and nervous system.
Rep. Dan Kildee, a Democrat who represents Flint, said at the hearing that Michigan is the main culprit, calling it a "false equivalence" to blame city and federal officials as much as the state. "This was a state failure," Mr. Kildee said.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan, and two EPA divisions are among the agencies working on a broad criminal investigation into the lead contamination of Flint.

An earlier version of this article said the committee was issuing a subpoena for Mr. Del Toral along with two other officials. (Feb. 3, 2016)
Credit: By Amy Harder and Kris Maher

article name: Why Mike Bloomberg Can Win; Record numbers of voters are independents--who won't be satisfied with Clinton, Trump or Cruz.
article text:
As the results from the Iowa caucuses rolled in Monday, it became more clear than ever: If former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg ran for president as an independent, he would be a serious contender for the White House. I work for Mr. Bloomberg as a pollster, and as this campaign has unfolded I have been struck by the gap between voters' concerns and how the media has portrayed them.
Talking heads say that voters are angry and polarized. This misses the mass of Americans in the middle. Only 16% of voters participated in a primary or caucus four years ago, according to the Bipartisan Policy Center. Even the strong turnout Monday--more than 180,000 Republicans and 170,000 Democrats--represents a mere fifth of the 1.6 million Iowans who voted in November 2012.
That's the new silent majority: the millions of Americans who don't participate in Democratic or Republican primaries. They are equally as fed up with the status quo, but they have a different approach to problem-solving and different policy prescriptions than those on the ideological extremes.
The bulk of the people who voted in Iowa were distinctively liberal or conservative. Of Republicans caucusgoers, only 14% said they were moderates, down one percentage point from 2012. Of the Democrats, 28% were moderates, down 12 points from 2008. It shows in the results: Half of the GOP caucusgoers supported either Ted Cruz, the most dogmatic conservative, or Donald Trump, the bombastic populist. On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders is leading a lurch toward socialism, and Hillary Clinton is seeking to match if not exceed his leftist agenda.
Who is appealing to the center? Most Americans, the new silent majority, do not share the aims of the activist caucusgoers. The share of voters who identify as independents hit 43% last year, a new record according to Gallup . Only 26% were Republicans and 30% Democrats. Moreover, 60% of Americans told Gallup in September that the Republicans and Democrats "do such a poor job" representing them that they want to see a third major party emerge. That's up from 40% when the question was first asked in 2003.
Who fits the bill? Michael Bloomberg, a centrist with a clear (and arguably unique) record in business as an entrepreneur and in politics as a three-term mayor of New York. Mr. Bloomberg is a fiscally prudent conciliator who advances pro-growth policies and takes tough stands. He supports comprehensive immigration reform to strengthen the American economy, environmental protections to protect our planet for the next generation, and social policies to promote inclusiveness, public health and community safety. In short, his agenda is very different from what is being offered by Ted Cruz, Donald Trump and Marco Rubio or Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton.
As America becomes more polarized, the desire grows for a candidate in the center focused on building consensus and getting results. This is the hidden message of Monday's caucuses, the one that Mr. Bloomberg is contemplating as he considers a run for president.
The numbers bear this out: Shortly after the 2014 election a poll by this newspaper and NBC News showed that 63% of Americans favored compromise, not confrontation, to achieve policy goals. A majority, 52%, wanted the government to do more problem-solving. These attitudes suggest a constituency for a candidate who eschews partisanship and produces results. That's exactly what Mr. Bloomberg did in New York, and what he has advocated for 10 years in speeches on reforming the political system and fixing Washington.
A January poll by Frank Luntz--which was not commissioned by Mr. Bloomberg or me--illustrates the mayor's potential. Mr. Luntz, who advised Ross Perot's independent bid in 1992, found that 84% of voters could support a generic candidate who matches Mr. Bloomberg's profile. When asked about the former mayor by name, 55% said they would consider supporting him. That includes 57% of Democrats, 45% of Republicans, and 62% of swing voters.
In direct matchups--three-way races against Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Cruz, or Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Rubio--the poll puts Mr. Bloomberg at 28%, and the election almost within the margin of error. And that's before he has announced a candidacy or run a single ad.
In short, the Bloomberg message would be unique in a year when Republicans have moved sharply to the right, and Democrats sharply to the left. The Luntz survey shows that more than a third of voters, 35%, either have no opinion about Mr. Bloomberg or have never heard of him. That gives him huge potential for growth among voters who are disappointed and dissatisfied with the two major parties.
The past two independents to begin presidential candidacies from the center were not successful. In 1992 Mr. Perot went as high as 37% in the polls, but finished with 19% of the popular vote. In 1980 John Anderson hit the mid-20s, but then stalled and won only 7% on Election Day. But their candidacies were sunk by poor temperament, meager resources or an inability to get on the ballot. Mr. Bloomberg would have none of those problems.
Commentators have mistakenly characterized Mr. Bloomberg's mayoral tenure as exclusively focused on a relatively limited (but widely known) social and public health agenda, including laws to prevent gun violence and discourage smoking. They're missing the bigger picture. Over more than a decade in office Mr. Bloomberg governed with (and articulated) sensible alternatives on reforming taxes and government services, as well as revitalizing the economy. He kept New York safe from a terrorist attack for 12 years and stood firm with law enforcement to reduce crime by 32% and make it the safest big city in the nation.
A Bloomberg candidacy would make no effort to kowtow to the religious right or labor unions. Mr. Bloomberg would not and has never made deals with special interests. Because he has always been able to finance his campaigns himself, his independence is indisputable.
As this politically frenetic February wears on, the primary process will demonstrate to voters how divided and dysfunctional the nation has become. For Americans in the middle, a Mike Bloomberg candidacy will become more compelling by the day.
Mr. Schoen served as a pollster for President Bill Clinton and has advised Michael Bloomberg since 2001.
Credit: By Douglas E. Schoen

article name: Clinton's U.N. Candidate? The favorite to run Turtle Bay is Russia's preferred choice.
article text:
Hillary Clinton has made gender a major part of her pitch for the White House, and the idea is catching on. A leading candidate to become the next Secretary-General of the United Nations is a Bulgarian woman with a Communist past and a record unfriendly to U.S. interests who is being promoted by Chelsea Clinton's mother-in-law.
The Bulgarian is 63-year-old Irina Bokova, who since 2009 has run Unesco, the U.N. cultural and social welfare agency. By tradition the top job at the U.N., Secretary-General, rotates by region and it will be Eastern Europe's turn when Ban Ki-moon's term expires at the end of this year. The Bulgarian government may nominate her for the post, which given her U.N. experience would make her the favorite unless significant opposition develops.
Ms. Bokova deserves more scrutiny, not least because of her record at Unesco. Long-time Journal readers will recall that the U.S. withdrew from Unesco in 1984 after years of anti-American agitation. The U.S. rejoined in 2003 saying the agency had reformed.
But in 2011 under Ms. Bokova, Unesco tried to make an end run around the Middle East peace process by admitting the Palestinian Authority as a member state despite U.S. objections. Mrs. Clinton's State Department was then forced by U.S. law to cut off the roughly $80 million in annual U.S. funding for Unesco.
That law reflects Congress's view that U.N. recognition of a Palestinian state before there is a peace deal with Israel encourages the Palestinians to avoid direct negotiations. The cutoff probably stopped other U.N. agencies from recognizing a Palestinian state lest they also lose U.S. funds. But President Obama opposes the funding cutoff and in December asked Congress to reconsider. It declined.
We can't find a record of Mrs. Clinton's views on Unesco funding, but she's no doubt aware of Ms. Bokova, who has participated in Clinton Global Initiative events. Ms. Bokova is also friendly with women's-rights activist Marjorie Margolies, a former Democratic Member of Congress who is a senior fellow at the University of Pennsylvania's Fels Institute of Government--and Chelsea's mother-in-law. On Tuesday after Ms. Bokova delivers a lecture at the Fels Institute, she and Ms. Margolies will share a stage for a "conversation" and "Q&A" with the audience.
The following day former Ambassador Esther Coopersmith will host a dinner for Ms. Bokova in Washington "to learn more about her candidacy for Secretary General of the United Nations," as the invitation puts it. Washingtonian magazine reported in December 2013 that Ms. Coopersmith "is close to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton."
The Economist reports that Ms. Bokova is also "Russia's preferred candidate." Last year she attended Vladimir Putin's Moscow Victory Day Parade, the biggest military display in Russian history. Most Western leaders refused to attend Mr. Putin's extravaganza in protest over his depredations in Ukraine. But Ms. Bokova was on hand with the likes of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Cuba's Raul Castro.
Ms. Bokova was an active member of the Bulgarian Communist Party in the Cold War era, and her father edited the Party's house organ. She graduated from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations in 1976 when talented students were dispatched to the institute to become good Communist diplomats. And she remained a member of the Communist Party until it changed its name to the Bulgarian Socialist Party.
It's true that the Cold War ended long ago, and many former Communists in the former Warsaw Pact have become democrats in good standing. But authoritarians are again on the march in the world, Mr. Putin chief among them. As U.N. Secretary-General, Ms. Bokova would have global influence and could create trouble for the U.S. All the more so in a Hillary Clinton Administration that would want U.N. approval and consensus for its diplomatic undertakings.
If the next Secretary-General must be a woman from Eastern Europe, there is a better alternative. Kristalina Georgieva is currently a vice president at the European Commission and has worked at the World Bank. Though she isn't our ideal candidate--her fans include George Soros--she lacks Ms. Bokova's political baggage. The current center-right government in Sofia might nominate Ms. Georgieva if there's global opposition to Ms. Bokova.
The U.S. role is crucial here. No Secretary-General is likely to be approved if America is actively opposed. Mr. Obama is leaving town in 11 months, and the next President will need a U.N. leader who isn't hostile to American interests. We'd like to know where Mrs. Clinton stands on Ms. Bokova's candidacy, and the House and Senate may want to examine her record in Bulgaria and at Unesco.

article name: The Myths of Black Lives Matter; The movement has won over Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. But what if its claims are fiction?
article text:
A television ad for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign now airing in South Carolina shows the candidate declaring that "too many encounters with law enforcement end tragically." She later adds: "We have to face up to the hard truth of injustice and systemic racism."
Her Democratic presidential rival, Bernie Sanders, met with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Wednesday. Mr. Sanders then tweeted that "As President, let me be very clear that no one will fight harder to end racism and reform our broken criminal justice system than I will." And he appeared on the TV talk show "The View" saying, "It is not acceptable to see unarmed people being shot by police officers."
Apparently the Black Lives Matter movement has convinced Democrats and progressives that there is an epidemic of racist white police officers killing young black men. Such rhetoric is going to heat up as Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders court minority voters before the Feb. 27 South Carolina primary.
But what if the Black Lives Matter movement is based on fiction? Not just the fictional account of the 2014 police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., but the utter misrepresentation of police shootings generally.
To judge from Black Lives Matter protesters and their media and political allies, you would think that killer cops pose the biggest threat to young black men today. But this perception, like almost everything else that many people think they know about fatal police shootings, is wrong.
The Washington Post has been gathering data on fatal police shootings over the past year and a half to correct acknowledged deficiencies in federal tallies. The emerging data should open many eyes.
For starters, fatal police shootings make up a much larger proportion of white and Hispanic homicide deaths than black homicide deaths. According to the Post database, in 2015 officers killed 662 whites and Hispanics, and 258 blacks. (The overwhelming majority of all those police-shooting victims were attacking the officer, often with a gun.) Using the 2014 homicide numbers as an approximation of 2015's, those 662 white and Hispanic victims of police shootings would make up 12% of all white and Hispanic homicide deaths. That is three times the proportion of black deaths that result from police shootings.
The lower proportion of black deaths due to police shootings can be attributed to the lamentable black-on-black homicide rate. There were 6,095 black homicide deaths in 2014--the most recent year for which such data are available--compared with 5,397 homicide deaths for whites and Hispanics combined. Almost all of those black homicide victims had black killers.
Police officers--of all races--are also disproportionately endangered by black assailants. Over the past decade, according to FBI data, 40% of cop killers have been black. Officers are killed by blacks at a rate 2.5 times higher than the rate at which blacks are killed by police.
Some may find evidence of police bias in the fact that blacks make up 26% of the police-shooting victims, compared with their 13% representation in the national population. But as residents of poor black neighborhoods know too well, violent crimes are disproportionately committed by blacks. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, blacks were charged with 62% of all robberies, 57% of murders and 45% of assaults in the 75 largest U.S. counties in 2009, though they made up roughly 15% of the population there.
Such a concentration of criminal violence in minority communities means that officers will be disproportionately confronting armed and often resisting suspects in those communities, raising officers' own risk of using lethal force.
The Black Lives Matter movement claims that white officers are especially prone to shooting innocent blacks due to racial bias, but this too is a myth. A March 2015 Justice Department report on the Philadelphia Police Department found that black and Hispanic officers were much more likely than white officers to shoot blacks based on "threat misperception"--that is, the mistaken belief that a civilian is armed.
A 2015 study by University of Pennsylvania criminologist Greg Ridgeway, formerly acting director of the National Institute of Justice, found that, at a crime scene where gunfire is involved, black officers in the New York City Police Department were 3.3 times more likely to discharge their weapons than other officers at the scene.
The Black Lives Matter movement has been stunningly successful in changing the subject from the realities of violent crime. The world knows the name of Michael Brown but not Tyshawn Lee, a 9-year-old black child lured into an alley and killed by gang members in Chicago last fall. Tyshawn was one of dozens of black children gunned down in America last year. The Baltimore Sun reported on Jan. 1: "Blood was shed in Baltimore at an unprecedented pace in 2015, with mostly young, black men shot to death in a near-daily crush of violence."
Those were black lives that mattered, and it is a scandal that outrage is heaped less on the dysfunctional culture that produces so many victims than on the police officers who try to protect them.
Ms. Mac Donald is the Thomas W. Smith fellow at the Manhattan Institute and author of "The War on Cops," forthcoming in July from Encounter Books.
Credit: By Heather Mac Donald

article name: Bernie Sanders's Path to Democratic Nomination Impeded by Nevada Result; Vermont senator looks forward to Super Tuesday contests on March 1 as next best chance for a victory against rival Hillary Clinton
article text:
LAS VEGAS--Sen. Bernie Sanders's path ahead in the Democratic presidential primary was already challenging, and it was made more so by his defeat Saturday in the Nevada caucuses.
Hillary Clinton now claims victory in two of the first three contests , and she's favored to win the Feb. 27 South Carolina primary, too. Mr. Sanders, who won the New Hampshire primary, won't see his next best chance for a second victory until March 1, when 11 states host primaries and caucuses.
In his remarks in Nevada, Mr. Sanders briefly noted that he's traveling to South Carolina on Sunday, but then he quickly pivoted to the next round of primaries with nearly 900 delegates up for grabs.
"We're going to be competing in 11 states all across this country on Super Tuesday," Mr. Sanders said. "And I believe that on Super Tuesday, we have got an excellent chance to win many of those states."
On Monday, he will go to Massachusetts and on Tuesday he goes to Virginia, both contests that will follow South Carolina.
His campaign is already running paid TV ads in Minnesota, Colorado and Oklahoma, as well as Massachusetts, four states where advisers see their best chances for victory. Minnesota and Colorado are caucus states, which tend to attract the more liberal voters that he appeals to, his advisers said.

* LIVE BLOG: The Latest From the Races in South Carolina, Nevada
* Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Democratic Caucuses
* Ace Beats Six: Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Delegate in Card Draw Tie-Breaker
* In GOP Primary, South Carolina Lives Up to Mudslinging Reputation
* South Carolina's Clyburn Endorses Clinton
* Pope Francis and Trump Spar Over Immigration and Candidate's Faith
* Critics See Racial Subtext in Obama-Rubio Photo Mashup
Mr. Sanders also holds a huge advantage in his home state of Vermont, another March 1 state.
Also voting the same day are Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and Arkansas, all contests that will feature a significant number of African-American voters. That should provide an advantage to Mrs. Clinton, whose support in the black community was reaffirmed in Nevada, where entrance polls showed three-fourths of African-Americans backed her. She's expected to see similar support in South Carolina.
Mr. Sanders's campaign manager Jeff Weaver said Saturday that the campaign will compete in the Palmetto State even though they know the Vermont senator is the underdog. "We're going to go down and we're going to fight in South Carolina. It's obviously an uphill fight for us there," he said. "Then we're going to go to Super Tuesday."
After that, the Sanders campaign sees potential victories on March 5 in Kansas and Nebraska and on March 6 in Maine--all three caucus states. Sanders aides are also focused on the big prize of Michigan, where a primary is set for March 8. Mr. Weaver referred to the contest there as a "a big showdown."
Mr. Weaver also noted that under Democratic Party rules, delegates are allocated proportionately, meaning that if a race is close, both candidates win substantial delegates.
There are no winner-take-all states in the Democratic primary race, which prevents one candidate from pulling far away from a competitor. At the same time, though, this system makes it very hard to catch up once a candidate falls behind.
When challengers are forced to drop out, it is usually because they run out of money, and Mr. Sanders shows no signs of that. He collected more than $6 million in the 24 hours after winning the New Hampshire primary. On Saturday, the Vermont senator asked his backers to continue to lend their financial support, saying that "taking on the establishment" isn't easy.
Still, he'll need to notch some quick wins if he is to seriously threaten Mrs. Clinton. "He has the money and resources to keep going, but he needed Nevada to fuel his momentum because he will lose South Carolina," said Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist who is neutral in the race.
"Realistically, this hill became very high to climb," Mr. Kofinis said. "Short of a stunning loss [by Mrs. Clinton] on Super Tuesday, we're seeing the limits of his candidacy."
Byron Tau contributed to this article.

Credit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton Seize Leads for Their Parties' Nominations; Weekend wins give both candidates the upper hand in amassing delegates in next state contests
article text:
PAHRUMP, Nev.--Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton emerged from a weekend of voting as the clear leaders in the fight for their parties' presidential nominations, with smoother potential paths to victory than seemed likely a few weeks ago.
After winning the South Carolina primary , Mr. Trump should continue to benefit from a splintered Republican field that allows him to rack up convention delegates elsewhere in the South. Meanwhile, Mrs. Clinton's win in Nevada's caucuses has helped dispel doubts about her candidacy just as it heads on to favorable turf in the South, where she always figured to be stronger than her competitor Sen. Bernie Sanders.
Both front-runners still face obstacles. Mr. Trump may soon be hit with more direct attacks, and, as the field winnows, a pair of winner-take-all primaries in March could allow a competitor to make up ground quickly. And Mrs. Clinton faces a rival who has a fervent base of support in some states that lie ahead, while she has lower levels of support than her campaign would like in some pockets of the Democratic electorate.
In the short term, though, both will benefit from a primary map that is likely to give them some running room in the delegate hunt.
Mr. Trump is expected to win Nevada's Tuesday caucuses, and the state's 30 delegates, and then 12 states vote on Super Tuesday, March 1. Seven of those states are Southern contests that are key to Sen. Ted Cruz's path to victory. But Mr. Trump's convincing victory in South Carolina has put the Texan's proposition that he will be the choice of the region's social conservatives on shaky ground.
A total of 989 Republican delegates are at stake between March 1 and March 12, to be awarded proportionally, giving Mr. Trump a chance to build a significant advantage before the start of the winner-take-all primaries March 15. A total of 1,237 delegates are needed to secure the GOP nomination.
"If Trump can't be stopped from taking a majority of Super Tuesday delegates it's hard to see how he's not going to be the nominee," said Walker Stapleton, the Colorado state treasurer who was co-chairman of Jeb Bush's campaign in Colorado. The former Florida governor dropped out of the race Saturday after a poor showing in South Carolina.
A string of losses in the Southern states could be debilitating to Mr. Cruz, the Iowa caucus winner who is jockeying with Florida Sen. Marco Rubio to become the primary alternative to Mr. Trump. Mr. Rubio took second place in South Carolina but is under growing pressure to show he can win a state. His home turf, Florida, holds a winner-take-all contest on March 15.
Speaking to reporters here Sunday, Mr. Cruz predicted he would defeat Mr. Trump in a one-on-one matchup should the party choose him as the alternative to the businessman.
"Donald Trump has demonstrated that he has a relatively high floor of support, but he's also got, I think, a ceiling," Mr. Cruz said. "You've got nearly 70% of Republican primary voters that don't believe Donald is the right person to represent our party in the general election against Hillary Clinton."
Lying in wait outside of the South is Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who finished in fifth place in South Carolina with less than 8% support after his surprise second-place showing in New Hampshire. His campaign is working Massachusetts, another March 1 state, and will need a strong showing in the March 8 Michigan primary to justify his candidacy.
Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson took sixth in South Carolina but is remaining in the race.
The longer the non-Trump vote is divided four ways, or even split between two candidates, the more delegates Mr. Trump will collect by winning with a plurality of the primary votes rather than a majority.
Beyond the map, the rhetoric on the campaign trail has leaned Mr. Trump's way, with most rivals avoiding attacking him so as not to draw his fire.
It is a stark difference from 2012, when after Newt Gingrich won South Carolina's primary, the rival Mitt Romney campaign launched a full-scale effort to take down the former House speaker in Florida, the next voting state. Romney surrogates, such as Utah Rep. Jason Chaffetz, trailed Mr. Gingrich at his events and attacked his record to reporters while the campaign and supportive super PAC peppered the airwaves with TV ads hitting Mr. Gingrich.
No campaign has even attempted anything similar to attack Mr. Trump. Mr. Gingrich said Sunday it probably wouldn't work anyway.
"You can't have the Romney effect this year," Mr. Gingrich said. "Nobody can raise enough money, and furthermore, we don't know of any message that works" against Mr. Trump.
Of the roughly $215 million that super PACs have spent so far on advertisements, phone calls and mailers promoting or attacking candidates of both parties, just about $9 million--or 4%--has been spent opposing Mr. Trump, who has been leading national polls since July.
The biggest hit was from Our Principles PAC, a group created by a former aide to Mr. Romney's 2012 campaign. The group has spent about $3.8 million so far attacking Mr. Trump, though $3 million of its fundraising has come from just two donors: Marlene Ricketts, the wife of TD Ameritrade founder Joe Ricketts, and Wisconsin shipping executive Richard Uihlein, according to the latest campaign-finance reports.
Mr. Chaffetz, who now backs Mr. Rubio, arrived in Nevada on Sunday. But he has no plans to attend Mr. Trump's Las Vegas rally Monday.
Instead, the House Oversight Committee chairman drove an hour to Pahrump, a retirement community near the California border, to "provide oversight" for Mr. Cruz outside a sports bar, where the Texan appeared for a rally.
Asked why he isn't trying to distract the front-runner, Mr. Chaffetz replied, "I don't even know if that's possible with Mr. Trump....If you're a Trump fan, you're a Trump fan."
Clinton campaign officials, for their part, believe the Nevada victory bodes well for the racially diverse set of states that come up next on the calendar.
"Nevada posed the first test for both campaigns in a diverse state--the first test of whether Sen. Sanders could broaden his appeal....And he came up short," Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon said.
Mr. Sanders said on CNN Sunday that his campaign is gaining support among Hispanic voters. "I think our message is resonating," he said.
Delegates are awarded proportionally in the Democratic nomination fight, making it hard for one candidate to clinch the nomination early. But Clinton campaign aides, buoyed by the caucus win, are convinced the former senator and secretary of state is on a path to roll up an insurmountable lead by the end of March, meaning the Vermont senator would be hard-pressed to overtake her even if he notches victories in the spring.
Mrs. Clinton also already has a big lead among superdelegates, a group of Democratic Party officials who will make up about 30% of the total needed to win.
One of Mr. Sanders's strengths had appeared to be states that hold caucuses, which typically inspire candidacies that fire up party activists, rather than primaries. Yet with three contests in the books, Mrs. Clinton has won the two caucus states.
That record is making Clinton aides confident about her prospects.
"When they articulate their path, when they talk about how they're going to compete for the nomination, they talk about caucus states. We're now 2-0 in caucus states," Mr. Fallon said.
Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.
Write to Reid J. Epstein at Reid.Epstein@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com
Credit: By Reid J. Epstein and Peter Nicholas

article name: Schlesinger's Take: Gensler's Ghost Over CFTC; Hillary Clinton Takes Stand on 'Position Limits for Commodities Markets'
article text:
It's not often a presidential candidate takes a stand on "position limits for commodities markets." But Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton's campaign released Thursday a statement saying she "believes these limits are a critical tool in curbing excessive speculation..."
The quote was attributed to campaign CFO Gary Gensler. He was, in an earlier incarnation, the top regulator driving - over strong objections from financial and energy firms - the position limits as tools to combat potential price spikes in oil and other commodities.
Mr. Gensler's remarks served not just as pushback to opponents making a renewed bid to block the rule, but a prod to his successor as head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Timothy Massad. Mr. Massad has been slow to complete the regulation Mr. Gensler rushed to propose before leaving the commission in early 2014. Two years later, the rule is still grinding its way through the CFTC process.
It has become a symbol of Mr. Massad's more deliberative, consultative manner, compared with Mr. Gensler's frenetic pace and style often seen as confrontational toward Wall Street. It's a contrast that has, at times, mollified the financial industry and frustrated its critics.
The position-limits rule has a controversial history. While authorized by the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act responding to the 2008 financial crisis, it has little to do with problems exposed during that meltdown. Rather, it was inspired by the oil-price spikes that same year, which some analysts attributed to dodgy speculators. The law allowed the CFTC to expand its longstanding powers to limit the number of futures and swaps contracts a trader can hold, beyond agricultural commodities to include energy and other sectors.
Mr. Gensler first issued the rule in 2011, but was forced back to the drawing board after opponents persuaded a federal judge to toss out his original draft.
The urgency also seemed to recede when oil prices plunged from the 2008 $100-a-barrel-plus peak to $30 this year.
Mr. Massad backs the position limits rule as well, and he joined Mr. Gensler Thursday in blasting a report released by a CFTC advisory committee, dominated by industry representatives, which concluded the rules were "not demonstrably necessary."
"It strikes me a bit like saying you're against speed limits because they may make you late for work," Mr. Massad sarcastically told a panel meeting as he rejected their findings.
But Mr. Massad hasn't offered a timetable for completing the regulation and putting it to a vote before his divided commission. He has said he's been taking his time in order to best calibrate it, incorporating what he considers the constructive suggestions from critics.
Yet if Mr. Massad doesn't push for finalization soon, the effective date could spill past President Barack Obama's term - leaving it vulnerable to being blocked by the next president, should Mr. Gensler's boss fail to win that slot.
Andrew Ackerman contributed to this report.
Write to Jacob M. Schlesinger at jacob.schlesinger@wsj.com
Credit: By Jacob M. Schlesinger

article name: Justice and Clinton's Email Probe; A 'career' official doesn't guarantee an honest investigation.
article text:
Attorney General Loretta Lynch this week tried to assure House Republicans about the impartiality of her department's investigation into Hillary Clinton's State Department emails by noting that it would be handled by career government officials. This claim could stand a little parsing.
The probe into her possible mishandling of classified information "is being handled by career independent law enforcement agents--FBI agents--as well as the career independent attorneys in the Department of Justice," Ms. Lynch said Wednesday. "They follow the evidence, they look at the law and they'll make a recommendation to me when the time is appropriate," adding that the probe is being "conducted as every other case."
That's what they always say, and it is nice to think so. But there's reason to doubt given the example of Justice's investigation into the IRS targeting of conservative groups before the 2012 election. To lead that probe, then Attorney General Eric Holder appointed Barbara Bosserman, a trial attorney in the department's Civil Rights Division.
Ms. Bosserman's appointment was curious given that her area of expertise is civil rights, not tax law. She had also donated $6,100 to President Obama's campaigns and the Obama Victory Fund in 2008 and 2012. That's no small donation on a career employee's salary and suggests some serious political loyalty.
Ms. Bosserman's conflict of interest came to light only after Justice stonewalled congressional requests for information about the status of the IRS probe. The House Oversight Committee then began investigating Justice's investigation. In September 2014 we wrote about the involvement of former department spokesman Brian Fallon , now a press secretary for the Clinton presidential campaign.
The House also discovered that Justice had assigned former IRS tax attorney Andrew Strelka to the case brought against the agency by Z Street, a pro-Israel group that claimed its tax-exempt status had been delayed because of its political leanings. Mr. Strelka had previously served as a presidential management fellow working in the IRS tax-exempt office managed by Lois Lerner, who by the way was also a career government official with clear anti-Republican political leanings. Mr. Strelka was removed from the case before being deposed as a witness.
Justice closed its investigation of the IRS last October with no criminal charges.
We'll hope for the best from Ms. Lynch's career prosecutors, and especially from the FBI. But whoever handles the case, at either the State or Justice Department, will presumably create a paper trail of evidence and legal analysis. If a Republican wins the presidential election, his appointees will be able to look at the files and judge the evidence independently.

article name: Valeant CEO Races to Repair Drug Maker's Reputation; Pearson Holds One-on-One Sessions With Supportive Analysts; Company Challenges Clinton Campaign Ad
article text:
Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc. Chief Executive Michael Pearson just got back from a two-month sick leave, and immediately faced a fresh round of criticism and doubts about the company's financial disclosures and business practices.
In response, Mr. Pearson spoke with a select group of Wall Street analysts. In one-on-one calls Tuesday with some who have generally stuck by the drug company, Mr. Pearson indicated he was bullish about Valeant's prospects and predicted performance not too far off what the company had initially forecast, but later took back, according to the analysts.
The company also challenged a new television ad from Hillary Clinton's campaign, in which the Democratic presidential candidate said she was "going after" Valeant for what she called "predatory pricing" of one of its migraine drugs.
Valeant posted a rebuttal on its website, saying a patient cited in Ms. Clinton's ad doesn't face "significant" out-of-pocket costs for the drug, and that low-cost generics far outsell the Valeant product, which has just $1 million in yearly sales. The company declined further comment.
Once a high-flying stock, Valeant has lost about three-quarters of its value since peaking last summer, as it met with questions about its business practices and disclosures of government investigations.
The drug maker became a poster child for criticism of high drug prices, and a target of congressional inquiries, after The Wall Street Journal reported Valeant was buying the rights to certain treatments and quickly raising their prices by substantial amounts.
Amid the controversies, Mr. Pearson had to step away from the company late last year to be treated for a case of severe pneumonia. The company announced his return on Sunday.
The CEO's outreach efforts on the company's behalf seemed to have had an impact; shares in Valeant, which plunged 18% Monday, recovered from a further drop in early trading Tuesday and finished the day only modestly lower at $65.45.
But even some supportive analysts have criticized what they call an information vacuum around the company.
Valeant previously withdrew its financial guidance for this year, and said it needed to restate some earnings after a board committee's probe of the company's relationship with a mail-order pharmacy found Valeant booked $58 million in revenue too early.
Late Monday, Valeant said it would miss an extended government deadline this month for reporting its annual performance.
Valeant is a "black box at this point in time," said Jefferies analyst David Steinberg, who kept his buy rating on Valeant, saying it has some strong brands in gastroenterology and eye health, but he cut his price target for the company's stock on Tuesday to $106 from $172.
Mr. Steinberg said a big question for the company involved a key product: toenail-fungus treatment Jublia. He said he couldn't estimate how Jublia would do in 2016 without more information on how Valeant will divvy up revenues with Walgreens Boots Alliance pharmacies, which recently agreed to replace mail-order pharmacy Philidor Rx Services LLC and help fill prescriptions.
"We have no information on the terms of the collaboration between Valeant and Walgreens," Mr. Steinberg said. Mr. Steinberg said he wasn't one of the analysts who spoke with Mr. Pearson on Tuesday.
Valeant's talking only with select analysts "isn't per se a problem," said Jill Fisch, a law professor and corporate-governance expert at the University of Pennsylvania.
If Mr. Pearson discussed significant information with the analysts that the public doesn't know about, "that would be a concern," Ms. Fisch said. But if he simply wanted to touch base as he returns to Valeant and help analysts get comfortable with the flood of news Valeant has put out over the past two days, "that's probably OK," she said.
Companies are barred from selectively disclosing material information to analysts or big investors without disclosing it to everyone, under the Securities and Exchange Commission's Regulation FD. But one-on-one analyst calls are generally permitted as long as executives don't reveal anything significant that hasn't been made public.
The analysts who spoke with Mr. Pearson said afterward in notes or calls with investors that they ultimately expect Valeant to lower its guidance. But they said talking with Mr. Pearson left them with the impression that there were no more major surprises in store for investors.
Evercore ISI analyst Umer Raffat told investors in a Webcast that he expects Valeant to give guidance in the next one to two weeks, and that it wouldn't be much different from what the company had provided earlier.
Shibani Malhotra from Nomura Securities said she expects the company's forecast to be lowered slightly due to the stronger dollar, the weaker-than-expected performance of its new female-libido drug Addyi, and certain businesses that may not have performed as well as expected.
"Nothing we heard changes our positive view," UBS Group AG's Marc Goodman said in a note.
Still, Valeant faces some serious challenges to its business. Moody's Investors Service is reviewing Valeant's credit rating for a possible downgrade, saying its operating performance was worse than expected and could hurt its ability to lower its debt, which stood at $31 billion at the end of September.
Drug-benefit managers like Express Scripts Holding Co. and CVS Health Corp., which play key roles paying for prescriptions, have said they are reviewing Valeant's often-costly medicines. Decisions to block coverage of Valeant drugs could damp sales.
And Valeant is facing serious threats to inflammatory-bowel-disease drug Xifaxan, which it is counting on for sales growth. Rival Allergan Inc. is selling a competing drug called Viberzi, and has asked the Food and Drug Administration to let it sell a generic version of Xifaxan.
Michael Rapoport and Liz Hoffman contributed to this article.
Credit: By Jonathan D. Rockoff and Maureen Farrell

article name: Front-Runners' Wins in Virginia on Super Tuesday Point a Way Forward; Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton show they can forge needed voter coalitions in diverse swing state
article text:
Of all their primary victories Tuesday, the wins by Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton in Virginia did the most to show they can forge the voter coalitions needed to win their party's presidential nominations.
Racially diverse, with big, urban centers and a large share of college graduates, Virginia stood as a proving ground for candidates in both parties as the nomination races move in coming weeks to other large, diverse states, including Ohio and Florida.
The parties' two front-runners won the state in different ways: Mrs. Clinton expanded the coalition she had built in earlier contests; Mr. Trump, while showing growing support among some voter groups, won in large part due to greater intensity among voter groups who were already part of his natural base.
Coming in the largest presidential swing state to vote so far, the two paths to victory give clues to the coalitions each candidate might try to form as a party nominee.
Mr. Trump has built a dominating position in the presidential race by carrying lower-income voters and those without a four-year college degree. In Virginia, he won those groups with larger margins than he had in prior contests, preliminary exit poll results reported by various media show.
Mr. Trump carried a remarkable 52% of voters with household income under $50,000, a far larger share than in his victories in the New Hampshire and South Carolina primaries. He won 44% of voters without a college degree--a larger share than in three of the four contests before Super Tuesday. Those voter groups remain the pillars of his candidacy.
At the same time, Mr. Trump was able to deprive Sen. Marco Rubio, his top rival in the state, of big margins among his own natural base, including college graduates and voters with the highest incomes. Mr. Rubio won those groups--but not by the vote totals needed to overcome the bounding support Mr. Trump enjoyed among his own core groups. With almost all precincts reporting, Mr. Trump edged Mr. Rubio in the state, 35% to 32%.
Mr. Trump's coalition took on different contours that suggest growing acceptance by some parts of the party and hesitancy among others after weeks of a coarsening nomination battle. Mr. Trump's share of self-described moderate voters in Virginia was lower by far than in any prior contest. He carried only 23% of that group, exit polls reported by media showed, compared to about one-third of voters in three prior contests and 55% in the Nevada caucuses.
At the same time, he won a larger share of evangelical Christians than in any prior contest but one.
Mrs. Clinton, in contrast to Mr. Trump, expanded the coalition she had built in prior contests.
She carried 58% of white voters, preliminary exit poll results showed, compared to 54% in last weekend's South Carolina primary. Mrs. Clinton had lost white voters to Sen. Bernie Sanders in the course of winning the Nevada caucuses. With almost all precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton won Virginia with 64% to Mr. Sanders's 35%.
At the same time, Mrs. Clinton reduced Mr. Sanders's margins among younger voters, and he carried only 52% of voters younger than age 45, exit polls showed. That was a far smaller share than the 74% Mr. Sanders won during his landslide victory last month in New Hampshire.
Mr. Sanders won only 36% of voters without a four-year college degree, a group he had carried in some prior contests.
Mr. Trump's working-class coalition held together in many other states. In Arkansas, he won Republican voters with household income under $50,000 while losing higher-income voters to Sen. Ted Cruz. Similarly, he won Arkansas Republicans who don't have a college degree, while losing college graduates to Messrs. Cruz and Rubio.
Mr. Trump also lost among Republicans with a college degree in Vermont, while winning those without a degree.
Voters who went to the polls Tuesday also reflected the nation's widening partisan divide: Republicans in many states leaned more conservative than in their last competitive primaries, while Democrats were more liberal.
In Tennessee, for example, 83% of GOP voters rated themselves as conservative, compared with 73% who said so in 2012.
By contrast, the Democratic voter pool in Virginia was more liberal than during the party's last contested primary, in 2008. Some 68% of Virginia Democrats who voted on Tuesday called themselves liberal, the preliminary exit poll results showed, compared with 50% in 2008. The share of self-described moderates fell nine percentage points to 29%.
Write to Dante Chinni at Dante.Chinni@wsj.com
Credit: By Aaron Zitner and Dante Chinni

article name: Ted Cruz Grabs Early Win in Kansas as Rivals Seek to Slow Donald Trump; Senator's decisive win comes as Democrat Hillary Clinton tries to widen her lead
article text:
Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas won the Kansas Republican caucuses on Saturday, notching another victory in his drive to slow the momentum of front-runner Donald Trump.
With more than half of the vote counted, Mr. Cruz, of Texas, had 49% of the vote, versus 25% for Mr. Trump, according to the Associated Press. Sen. Marco Rubio had nearly 15% of the vote, and Ohio Gov. John Kasich had nearly 10%.
Kansas allocates its 40 convention delegates on a proportional basis to candidates who earn at least 10%.
The state, one of four to vote in the Republican contests on Saturday, was expected to be favorable ground for Mr. Cruz because evangelicals make up about one-third of the total population. In past GOP nominating contests, the state has gone with the evangelical favorite--former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum in 2012 and former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee in 2008.
Mr. Cruz had made Kansas his first campaign destination after the Super Tuesday contests, making two stops in the state Wednesday. Both he and Mr. Trump made a last-minute pitch for the Kansas contest with appearances in Wichita on Saturday.
A poll of Kansas Republicans released a week ago by Fort Hays State University had shown Mr. Trump in the lead with 26%, followed by Mr. Cruz with 14%.
Mr. Rubio, in Kansas as in other states, had drawn endorsements from top GOP luminaries including Gov. Sam Brownback, Sen. Pat Roberts and Rep. Mike Pompeo. Mr. Cruz was endorsed by conservative Rep. Tim Huelskamp. Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach endorsed Mr. Trump.
Read More on Campaign Wire
* At CPAC, Rubio Warns of 'Hijacked' Conservative Movement
* Trump Reverses His Stance on Torture
* RNC Chair Says Contested GOP Convention Is 'Highly Unlikely'
* Bernie Sanders's Plan Would Raise Taxes by 34%, Analysis Finds
* Hillary Clinton Proposes Tax Hit for Companies Moving Jobs, Production Overseas
Elsewhere on Saturday, Republicans in Kentucky and Maine were gathering for caucuses, while Louisiana was holding its presidential primary.
Democrats, meanwhile, were voting in three states Saturday--Kansas, Louisiana and Nebraska--as front-runner Hillary Clinton seeks to widen her delegate lead over rival Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont.
For Republican challengers still hoping to block the party's front-runner, every state affords an opportunity to keep delegates out of the hands of Mr. Trump because the states aren't winner-take-all contests.
What is more, these states give the businessman's more-experienced competitors an advantage because they are Republican-only nominating contests: Much of Mr. Trump's support has come from unaffiliated voters in states like New Hampshire where non-Republicans can vote in the primary.
Here is a look at the other Saturday states:
Maine
With 5% of the vote counted from the state's caucuses, Mr. Cruz was leading here also, with 48%, compared with 35% for Mr. Trump. The state is awarding 23 delegates; If a candidate gets more than 50% of the vote, he will win them all. Otherwise, delegates will be awarded proportionately to candidates who get at least 10%.
There is no public polling to gauge the race. Mr. Trump took a detour to hold a big rally in Portland Thursday, on route from Florida to Detroit for the GOP candidate debate . He has enjoyed the support of Maine Gov. Paul LePage. Mr. Cruz held a rally in Bangor Friday morning.
Democrats meet in their caucuses Sunday, and Mr. Sanders is hoping for a strong showing there in a state that is neighbor to his home state of Vermont and borders New Hampshire, where he won his biggest victory over Mrs. Clinton.
Kentucky
Kentucky Republicans for the first time are holding presidential caucuses rather than a primary--a change that had been made to help favorite son Sen. Rand Paul in his presidential bid, but he has since dropped out.
The state awards delegates proportionately, but only to candidates who earn at least 5% of the vote.
Sen. Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) hasn't endorsed a candidate, but has been a vocal critic of Mr. Trump and repeatedly at odds in the Senate with Mr. Cruz, who once called Mr. McConnell a liar for his handling of Export-Import Bank legislation opposed by conservatives.
A recent Big Red Poll by Western Kentucky University found Mr. Trump leading with 35% of likely caucus participants, followed by Mr. Rubio with 22%, Mr. Cruz with 15%, and Mr. Kasich with 6%. Some 15% of likely caucus participants indicated they were still undecided.
Mr. Trump held a rally in Louisville earlier this week, an event that was marred by violence between black protesters and Trump supporters.
Democrats won't hold their nominating contest until May 17, when the state holds its primary election.
Louisiana
Both parties are holding primary elections in the state, which awards 46 Republican delegates and 51 Democratic delegates. Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton have a chance to repeat big victories they have had in other Southern states.
The two front-runners held rallies in Louisiana Friday night. A recent poll by the Trafalgar Group found that Mr. Trump has a solid lead in Louisiana, like other Deep South states he swept on Super Tuesday. Mr. Trump led with 44%, followed by Mr. Cruz with 26%, Mr. Rubio with 15% and Mr. Kasich with 5%.
On the Democratic side, Mrs. Clinton is the front-runner, building another victory on the strength of support among African-American voters. A recent Magellan Strategies poll gave her a lead of 61% to 14% over Mr. Sanders.
Nebraska
The Nebraska Democratic caucus will award 25 delegates on a proportionate basis. Sanders supporters are hoping the state will go the way of Oklahoma, which favored the senator in its Super Tuesday primary. He spoke to a packed crowd on a college campus in Lincoln Thursday.
Mrs. Clinton hasn't appeared in the state since December, but former President Bill Clinton held campaign appearances for her in Omaha and Lincoln on Friday.
Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.com
Credit: By Janet Hook

article name: Fed Governor Brainard Donated to Clinton Campaign; Official made three contributions totaling $750 between mid-November and mid-January
article text:
WASHINGTON--A Federal Reserve governor donated to Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign in recent months, a rare sign of political favor by a member of the central bank's powerful board.
Lael Brainard, who was nominated to the board by President Barack Obama, made three contributions totaling $750 between mid-November and mid-January, according to Federal Election Commission records. The donations were earlier reported by Bloomberg News.
The contributions didn't violate any central-bank rules, a Fed spokeswoman said. Fed board members can make campaign donations but are barred from engaging in partisan political activities, in line with rules that apply to the executive branch. When asked if Ms. Brainard would comment, a Fed spokesman said, "We have nothing more for you."
News of the donations to the leading Democratic presidential candidate follows Republican lawmakers' complaints last year that Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen had politicized the central bank by meeting more with Obama administration officials, Democrats and liberal advocacy groups--allegations she rejected.
House Financial Services Committee Chairman Jeb Hensarling (R., Texas) on Tuesday bemoaned the Fed's "exceedingly close relationship" with the White House, adding that Ms. Brainard's donation "is just more evidence proving that the greatest threat to the Fed's supposed monetary policy independence is its cozy ties to the executive branch."
Mark Calabria, a former aide to Senate Banking Committee Chairman Richard Shelby (R., Ala.) and the director of financial-regulations studies at the Cato Institute, questioned the judgment of Ms. Brainard's donations. "Given the perception of how close the Fed is to this administration and the Clintons already, it reinforces a bad impression," he said.
Stephen Oliner, a former senior Fed economist and resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said that "we're talking about relatively small sums of money," and noted that Ms. Brainard's actions were legal. However, he said "the Fed is under so much scrutiny on the Hill, so anything that inflames the perception of political favoritism is not helpful to the institution."
Sarah Binder, a professor of political science at George Washington University specializing in Congress and the Fed, said the main issue surrounding the Brainard donation "is the appearance of favoring one party of another." Given the governor's background, it is no surprise that Ms. Brainard might favor Democrats over Republicans, Ms. Binder said, but the donation "makes it harder for the Fed to maintain a squeaky clean reputation" amid accusations by Republican lawmakers that the Fed is too close to the Treasury.
Ms. Brainard, who joined the Fed board in June 2014, served as an economic adviser to former President Bill Clinton and later worked as a senior Treasury official during the Obama administration. Her husband, Kurt Campbell, worked as assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs when Hillary Clinton was secretary of state.
Ms. Brainard is the only current Fed governor to have made itemized donations to a presidential campaign in the run-up to this year's election, according to the FEC's records.
The FEC records itemize donations exceeding $200 in total over a two-year period, but not donations below that threshold. The Fed said it doesn't separately track or maintain records of donations to political committees.
Every sitting governor, including Ms. Yellen, made political campaign donations before joining the Fed board. And several have worked for previous administrations. Ms. Yellen and Fed governor Daniel Tarullo also worked at the Clinton White House, while governor Jerome Powell was a senior Treasury official under Republican President George H.W. Bush.
The FEC records show at least five of the 12 regional Federal Reserve bank presidents have donated to political campaigns, both before and during their terms of office.
Before becoming Minneapolis Fed President in January, Neel Kashkari, gave the maximum permitted individual donation to Jeb Bush's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. Mr. Kashkari, who ran unsuccessfully as a Republican candidate for governor of California in 2014, donated $2,700 in July last year, according to records confirmed by the Minneapolis Fed.
In 2014, Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart gave $2,000 to Georgia Democrat Michelle Nunn's campaign for the Senate, the records show. Mr. Lockhart also made a 2014 donation to Democratic gubernatorial candidate Jason Carter, grandson of former President Jimmy Carter, an Atlanta Fed spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman said Mr. Lockhart believes that donation was $1,000.
Several other regional Fed presidents gave money to campaigns before their appointments. For example, FEC records show New York Fed President William Dudley and Dallas Fed President Robert Steven Kaplan donated to Democratic presidential campaigns. Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker contributed to both Democratic and Republican presidential campaigns before joining the central bank.
Write to Harriet Torry at harriet.torry@wsj.com
Credit: By Harriet Torry

article name: Clinton, Sanders Face Off in Democratic Debate
article text:
Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders meet in Milwaukee for their sixth debate, days after Sen. Sanders's resounding win in New Hampshire
Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton square off Thursday during the sixth Democratic presidential primary debate of the 2016 election cycle.
'I think that the best analysis that I've seen based on Sen. Sanders's plans is that it would probably increase the size of federal government by about 40%,' Hillary Clinton said during the presidential primary debate.
'I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend,' Sen. Bernie Sanders said in criticizing Hillary Clinton for receiving advice from former Secretary of State Kissinger.
Demonstrators infiltrated the Student Union at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee on Thursday in support of increased minimum wage and immigrant justice before the Democratic presidential debate in Milwaukee.
Sen. Bernie Sanders appears at the 'PBS NewsHour' democratic debate, where he called the campaign finance system 'corrupt' and that the economy 'rigged.'
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton participates in the 'PBS NewsHour' Democratic presidential candidate, where she accused Sen. Bernie Sanders of 'trying to start all over again' on health-care reform.
The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee hosts Thursday night's debate.
Democratic presidential candidates Sen. Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton take the stage before their presidential primary debate at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee on Thursday.
People show support outside the Democratic presidential debate Thursday, the final debate before the Nevada caucuses scheduled for Feb. 20.
Supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders gather outside the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee student union before the Democratic presidential primary debate Thursday.
[Interactive content available online]

article name: Democrats' Battle Shifts --- As race moves to friendlier ground for Clinton, Sanders works to broaden his appeal
article text:
Democrats headed south and west after Sen. Bernie Sanders's resounding New Hampshire victory over Hillary Clinton, facing the twin questions of whether his appeal is broad enough to replicate his performance elsewhere -- and whether her support is strong enough to reverse the tide.
Lying at the crossroads of those two questions are the minority voters who have transformed the Democratic Party in the past few decades and hold the promise of sustained success in the future.
Mr. Sanders's first act after his 22-point victory in predominantly white New Hampshire was to travel to Harlem in New York on Wednesday and have breakfast with high-profile civil-rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton.
In an interview, Rev. Sharpton said that by coming to Harlem after "such a big victory," Mr. Sanders "wanted to send a signal" to the party's minority voters. "She has deeper ties [to the black community] and longstanding friends," Mr. Sharpton said of Mrs. Clinton, "but that doesn't mean he can't win voters."
Meanwhile, the Clinton campaign arranged a conference call Wednesday with prominent African-American figures who support the former secretary of state. They cast Mr. Sanders as an arriviste who has ignored issues important to African-Americans.
"It's good to have new friends -- I would prefer to have true friends," said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.), who plans to go to South Carolina to campaign for Mrs. Clinton.
Mrs. Clinton now is calling on the Clinton network of African-American supporters, looking to shore up the "firewall" her campaign says it has built in coming contests in South Carolina and other Southern states with large minority populations. The campaign is also tapping into her Hispanic network to sway Nevada voters.
On primary night, the Clinton campaign understood that a defeat was coming in the Granite State. But the breadth of the loss left some of her supporters rattled and former President Bill Clinton angry, according to two people familiar with his thinking.
Mr. Sanders beat her among women voters and won every age category save for voters over 65. He bested Mrs. Clinton not only among independents who participated in the primary -- and by a lopsided margin -- but topped her among Democratic Party members, 52% to 48%, exit polls showed.
That could prove important, as the next primaries and caucuses will have far larger shares of Democrats and smaller shares of independents, who are barred entirely from party primaries in some states. Some 58% of voters in the New Hampshire primary were Democrats. By contrast, Democrats accounted for 81% of Nevada caucus-goers and 73% of South Carolina primary voters during the last competitive contests, in 2008.
But Mr. Sanders's strength within the party's membership remains an open question. Mrs. Clinton carried Democratic Party members by 17 points in her narrow victory in Iowa's caucuses last week. And the Democrats in contests to come won't look like those in New Hampshire.
Where 93% of New Hampshire's Democratic primary voters were white, only 43% of South Carolina primary voters and 65% of Nevada caucus-goers in 2008 were white. The New Hampshire primary didn't test one of the most important features of the coming contests -- whether Mrs. Clinton is retaining the substantial advantages she has shown among African-American and Hispanic voters in opinion polls.
Members of the Congressional Black Caucus are planning to fan out in South Carolina in advance of the state's primary on Feb. 27, talking up Mrs. Clinton's credentials in a state where African-Americans account for more than half of the Democratic electorate.
"I'm going to preach and teach, tell people to get out and vote for Hillary," said Rep. John Lewis (D., Ga.), who was beaten by state troopers in Selma, Ala., in 1965 during a voting-rights protest.
Rep. Gregory Meeks (D., N.Y.), the chairman of the black caucus's political-action committee, said that the group's board last week overwhelmingly voted to endorse Mrs. Clinton. Their formal announcement is expected on Thursday.
Brian Fallon, a Clinton campaign spokesman, noted that the contests on March 1 include Texas, Alabama and Georgia -- states with substantial "communities of color."
But Mr. Sanders is ceding no ground as his campaign has gained momentum. He won the endorsement of former NAACP President Ben Jealous, and he is about to roll out an ad that shows him marching with Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1963 March on Washington, according to former South Carolina Democratic Party Chairman Richard Harpootlian.
"His bona fides are beyond question on civil rights, so older African-American voters as they see the TV commercial or radio ad will understand he's not some newcomer to their cause," Mr. Harpootlian said.
The tug of war between the Clinton and Sanders camps is putting pressure on one of South Carolina's most prominent officials to come forward with an endorsement.
Rep. Jim Clyburn, the only Democrat in South Carolina's delegation and a civil-rights leader with big sway in the state, has stayed neutral, but he may be coming off the fence soon, people familiar with the matter said.
"I'm feeling it," said Mr. Clyburn, declining to say whom he might endorse. "I have a wife and three daughters" and "they are telling me that I need to take a stand."
---
Valerie Bauerlein contributed to this article.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Raises Most Beltway Cash
article text:
WASHINGTON -- In a year in which campaigning against Washington is good politics, Hillary Clinton is vacuuming up campaign donations from all corners of the city -- and much of the suburbs.
Financial reports made public Sunday show Mrs. Clinton and her backers are trouncing their opponents when it comes to raising money from lobbyists, Washington insiders and large national labor unions. Of the 16 industries tracked by the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan group that tracks campaign giving, she outraised all other candidates in all but two business sectors -- the tobacco industry and the oil and gas sector.
The former senator and secretary of state raised twice as much money last year from the city's biggest lobbyists as all of her Republican and Democratic opponents combined. Meantime, a super PAC run by Mrs. Clinton's political backers raised more than $4 million from large national labor unions.
To be sure, campaign donations from lobbyists and the Washington establishment make up a fraction of the total amount of money contributed to the presidential candidates and super PACs each election. In 2012, lobbyists were responsible for about $1.7 million of the $850 million given to super PACs.
The lobbying industry ranks far below more lucrative sectors such as Wall Street, health care, Hollywood and home builders when it comes to campaign donations. But money from lobbyists and the Washington establishment could prove more symbolic this year, with so many candidates on both sides of the political spectrum talking up their distance from the entrenched political class.
In his speech after the Iowa caucuses Monday, Mrs. Clinton's chief rival, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, sought political gain from his lack of money from Washington and Wall Street. He said, "We don't want their money, and I am very proud to tell you that we are the only candidate on the Democratic side without a super PAC."
The three Republicans topping national polls -- Donald Trump, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio -- call themselves outsiders on the campaign trail, promising to "take on Washington" and complaining about being attacked by the establishment.
Mrs. Clinton, a former first lady, hasn't attempted to distance herself from the Washington establishment. But on the campaign trail, she has frequently called for overhauling the campaign-finance system -- either through appointing justices to the Supreme Court who would uphold campaign-contribution limits or through a constitutional amendment.
At a recent stop in Urbandale, Iowa, she said she cares more about "protecting an individual's right to vote than a corporation's right to buy an election."
Campaign money from lobbyists can be tallied in two different ways.
