Under the law, candidates must file reports with the Federal Election Commission showing how much money lobbyists have raised, or "bundled," for their campaigns from clients, family members and other parts of their fundraising networks. Candidates are also required to disclose the occupations and employers of their donors.
A Wall Street Journal analysis shows Mrs. Clinton leads all others in donations from lobbyists by either measure -- though Mr. Rubio hovered close to her on one of them.
The bundling reports show that Washington lobbyists helped raise more than $2 million for Mrs. Clinton last year, the largest of any candidate. Mr. Rubio nearly matched her total from lobbyists in the final three months of 2015. Lobbyists raised about $715,000 for Mrs. Clinton in the period and about $675,000 for Mr. Rubio.
Overall, lobbyists raised a total of $1 million for Mr. Rubio's campaign last year, far less than for Mrs. Clinton, but more than for any other Republican. Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush raised $400,000 from lobbyists last year, according to the reports.
A Wall Street Journal analysis of fundraising reports also shows Mrs. Clinton outpaced the field when it came to campaign donations directly from lobbyists to her campaign.
Mrs. Clinton raised $575,000 in donations from individuals who work at the 20 largest lobbying firms in Washington last year. Mr. Sanders raised $6,650 from individuals at the same firms last year.
Mr. Bush led Republicans with about $150,000 in donations from the top 20 lobbying shops in 2015, followed by Mr. Rubio with just more than $100,000.
Credit: By Brody Mullins and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Clinton, Sanders Locked in Tie
article text:
DES MOINES, Iowa -- Battling for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders were locked in razor-tight contest for Iowa's delegates and the momentum that comes with a win in the nation's first contest.
Throughout the night, less than a percentage point separated the pair, with Mrs. Clinton in the lead. With 96% of precincts reporting, her advantage was just 49.9% of the delegates versus 49.6% for Mr. Sanders, according to tabulations from the Iowa Democratic Party.
"Tonight while the results are still not known it looks like we are in a virtual tie," Mr Sanders told cheering supporters. He added, "I think the people of Iowa have sent a very profound message." His cheering supporters replied, "Feel the Bern!"
Mrs. Clinton, addressing her own supporters in Des Moines, said, "It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for." She added that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief," though she didn't declare victory.
The results amounted to a virtual tie, and mean that Iowa will send roughly an equal number of delegates for each candidate to the party's national convention this summer, where the nominee will be officially selected. They also offer a dose of good news for both campaigns. Mr. Sanders can say that he battled the prohibitive front-runner to a tie, while Mrs. Clinton avoids what would have been an embarrassing defeat.
The upstart Vermont senator, whose entry to the Democratic presidential race barely registered, has both new money and new momentum. In January, Mr. Sanders raised $20 million, and with most of his donations well below the legal limit, he can go back to his donors for more.
"The thing that generally ends campaigns is lack of resources," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories. "This does not seem to be a problem for the Sanders campaign, which continues to do prodigious grass-roots fundraising."
Earlier, in a sweltering school lunchroom in Windsor Heights, a suburb of Des Moines, Clinton backers wooed their neighbors with offers of bottled water. A few miles away, in Clive, Sanders supporters ran out of seats so stood against the wall, beneath Sanders signs reading, "A Future to Believe In."
"She has the experience, she has the knowledge, she is qualified, she will get things done," said Vicky Daniel, who caucused for Mrs. Clinton in Windsor Heights. She flew back to Iowa from her winter home in Florida to participate, and when Mrs. Clinton was announced the winner in her caucus, "I said, `yes, yes, yes.'"
But in Clive, west of Des Moines, Carol Ferrell, 59, decided at the last minute to support Mr. Sanders. "As much as I admire Hillary Clinton, she's got a lot of baggage," she said.
Mrs. Clinton's showing was an improvement over her third-place finish in Iowa eight years ago, which made clear that her once-inevitable campaign faced a serious threat from another challenger, then-Sen. Barack Obama.
The Clinton campaign said it was well positioned for a long slog, and Mr. Sanders vowed to press on no matter the results.
Both candidates were traveling overnight to New Hampshire to begin a weeklong sprint to the Granite state primary, where Mr. Sanders is 18 points ahead of Mrs. Clinton, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls.
Mrs. Clinton, a former senator and secretary of state, is ahead in the states that come after that, and nationally. But the Sanders campaign believes a win in New Hampshire on top of a strong showing in Iowa would compel voters to give his campaign a second look.
"We've done what we came to do, which is establish him as a serious candidate," Sanders strategist Tad Devine said Monday, before the caucuses.
The Clinton campaign was bracing for a loss in New Hampshire, the state that rescued Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign and revived Mrs. Clinton's 2008 effort.
"There are a lot of headwinds in New Hampshire," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said, noting that candidates from neighboring states, like Mr. Sanders, have almost always won New Hampshire in recent years.
But Mr. Mook said he feels optimistic looking ahead. He pointed to Mrs. Clinton's strong position in Nevada and South Carolina and in the swath of Southern states that will award a quarter of the delegates at stake on March 1. These states, where the Clinton campaign began organizing last summer, have more nonwhite voters than the states in the first two contests. Mrs. Clinton polls strongly among these voters and would continue to emphasize matters important to African-Americans, including her association with Mr. Obama, gun restrictions and the water crisis in Flint, Mich.
Former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who has lagged far behind his competitors and had dwindling resources, suspended his campaign for the Democratic nomination after earning scant support in Iowa.
Over dozens of trips to Iowa high schools and diners, in small discussions and big rallies, the two leading candidates engaged in a vigorous and sometimes sharp debate as Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as a pragmatic, can-do fighter, while Mr. Sanders appealed to the party's most deeply held ideals.
She battled reports that classified material was sent via her private email system. He battled suggestions that he couldn't win a general election, and that he has no real plan to implement his agenda.
Still, he inspired voters who said they were attracted to his rejection of big-money politics and promise of a "political revolution." He drew crowds to arenas and a loyal online following, where backers taunted detractors to "feel the Bern."
In speeches that remained almost identical across months of campaigning, Mr. Sanders promised to break up large banks, said Wall Street is built on fraud and unapologetically vowed to impose higher taxes to provide universal health care, free tuition at public colleges and more generous Social Security benefits. At a rally Saturday, as Mr. Sanders ticked off society's problems, the crowd spontaneously began chanting, "Enough is enough!"
"He has an extraordinary amount of conviction," said Zachery Love, a 19-year-old University of Iowa student, one of more than 4,000 people to turn out for a Sanders concert and rally Saturday night.
Mrs. Clinton, for her part, highlighted her perseverance and qualifications along with what she describes as a pragmatic, effective approach to governing. She also portrayed herself as the most electable candidate whose nomination is necessary to block Republican ideas.
Her policy platform includes a new program for debt-free tuition and an increase in solar panels, as well as change in health care and Social Security that are more modest than her rival's.
Her supporters, including many older women who grew up in a time of outright sex discrimination, say they are inspired by the idea of electing the first female president. And backers often say she is the most qualified candidate for the presidency they have ever encountered.
On Monday night, Deidre Fudge arrived early to her West Des Moines caucus to register support for Mrs. Clinton. "I'm just a little worried about Bernie and his naivete," Ms. Fudge said. "I appreciate her experience and level-headedness about what can actually get done."
Credit: By Laura Meckler, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: How Sanders Exposed Clinton
article text:
Democrats awoke Wednesday with a thought usually reserved for Republicans: Hillary Clinton is a disaster. The marvel is that she fooled them for so long.
Picture Bernie Sanders as a small child in the court of Empress Clinton, and you have a modern twist on Hans Christian Andersen. The adoring Democratic townspeople oohed and aahed over their "tough" and "experienced" and "masterful" leader, the anointed heir to the Clinton throne. Then Bernie murmured what was obvious, and the crowd looked again.
What they saw in New Hampshire was a dour, 68-year-old woman, shouting at her audience in her best impression of emotion. They saw a gaunt former president, rambling to half-empty forums, grumping about his wife's political opponent. They saw the candidate's surrogates try to snag the votes of young women by threatening them with eternal damnation. They saw a campaign in disarray, dragging carload upon carload of ethical baggage. They saw that the empress has no (or very few) clothes.
No one knows whether Bernie Sanders can pull off a nomination. But what everyone does know now is that Hillary has (and is) a problem either way. Let's dispense with some spin: Bernie never had a lock on the Granite State. New Hampshire had stepped up for the Clintons twice before, in 1992 and 2008. This year Hillary went into the contest with endorsements, a huge operation and plenty of money.
What she didn't have was the interest of voters. They'd had their eyes opened, and they chose to use their primary to highlight Mrs. Clinton's many and obvious political weaknesses. She may still be the favorite to hold her party's banner, but the mantle of inevitability has been stripped away.
New Hampshire exposed again what a wooden candidate Hillary is. Mr. Sanders strolls on stage and makes his audience sing and cheer. Mrs. Clinton's events begin with propaganda videos about her past, followed by a tutorial on why she deserves this. They are heavy, and droning.
She cannot do uplifting. She had the same likability problem in her 2000 race for the Senate, when she had to spend a fortune to beat an unknown Republican in liberal New York. The same problem popped up in 2008, against Barack Obama. Why anyone thought she would improve on a third go is a mystery.
New Hampshire also uncovered the mismanagement that always attends the Clintons. Hillary wakes up every day with a new campaign. She ignores Mr. Sanders. Then she runs left. Then she attacks him. Then she softens. Her staff has endless debates, which always end up leaked to the press, about whether she needs to appear "stronger," or more "human," or "sharper," or "softer," or more "pragmatic," or more "lofty."
She has a habit of unceremoniously firing campaign teams. And this scattershot approach comes from a woman who has been plotting to be president for at least a decade? All this shifting may be another reason why the public sees her as "untrustworthy."
To that point, New Hampshire proved that concerns about Mrs. Clinton's ethics aren't merely a right-wing talking point. They've permeated the electorate. Some stunning numbers: Among the one-third of Democratic primary voters who said "honesty" was the top quality they wanted in a nominee, Mr. Sanders won 91%. Among the quarter who said they focused on a candidate who "cares about people like me," Mr. Sanders won 82%.
Finally, New Hampshire exposed how out of touch the Clinton machine is with the modern liberal movement. Mrs. Clinton based her campaign on the tropes of a fading Democratic establishment. She figured that women would vote for her simply because she had the right anatomy. She figured that college grads and wealthier Democrats would vote for her because she had more pragmatic policies. She figured that the bulk of voters still viewed the Clinton operation as a sure ticket to the White House.
In fairness, she won her age group -- those 65 or older, who grew up with the Clintons. But she lost everyone else: women, men, college grads, blue-collar workers. She lost every income level except those making more than $200,000. She lost liberals. And moderates.
What makes Mrs. Clinton's miscalculation notable is that the party's shift was on full, neon view before she even entered the race. It was walking around in the form of Elizabeth Warren. The worry for Mrs. Clinton is that she might be unable to heal the rifts. Barack Obama's soaring rhetoric was able to reunite his party in 2008. Hillary doesn't have his skills.
Responsibility for her crushing New Hampshire defeat can't be placed on Mrs. Clinton alone. Her party leadership is in it with her. Since 2008 the Clinton juggernaut has projected Hillary as the party's only option, and Democrats bought it. They closed their eyes to her flaws and scandals, ignored the shifting progressive winds, pushed potential rivals aside, and raved about the empress's lovely clothes. Then Bernie started whispering.
Credit: By Kimberley A. Strassel

article name: Election 2016: Clinton, Sanders Clash Over Cost of Plans --- Former secretary of state also questions the senator's loyalty to President Obama
article text:
MILWAUKEE -- Hillary Clinton pressed Bernie Sanders on the viability of his proposals for free health care and college tuition in a Democratic presidential debate Thursday, and questioned his loyalty to President Barack Obama for past statements calling the president weak and a disappointment.
In a wide-ranging exchange, the first after the candidates split victories in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, the Democratic contenders agreed with each other more than they disagreed and appealed to the minority voters who will play a larger role in the next two races, in South Carolina and Nevada.
Mrs. Clinton tethered herself to Mr. Obama, who remains enormously popular with the African-American voters she is relying on to help her campaign. She cast herself as the keeper of his legacy, repeatedly injected praise for his record and attacked Mr. Sanders for criticism he has leveled against the president.
"The kind of criticism we've heard from Sen. Sanders about our president I expect from Republicans -- I do not expect from someone running for the Democratic nomination," she said. "That is a low blow," he replied, saying he has worked closely with Mr. Obama. But he added: "Last I heard, we lived in a democratic society. Last I heard a U.S. senator had the right to disagree with the president. So I have voiced criticisms."
Mrs. Clinton said that disagreement was fine but Mr. Sanders went too far suggesting a primary challenge to him in 2011, calling him weak and a disappointment. The Vermont senator's final retort, harking back to the 2008 Democratic primary: "One of us ran against Barack Obama. I was not that candidate."
The debate elicited few surprises and revealed no significant change in tactics by either camp that could shift the dynamics of what appears to be a highly competitive fight for the Democratic Party presidential nomination that isn't likely to be resolved for months.
Mr. Sanders didn't hesitate to stand by his proposal to impose new taxes on the wealthy and Wall Street to provide new government services. However, he appeared to have no reply when the former secretary of state pointed out that his education proposal would require Republican governors to spend more money to make it happen.
Mr. Sanders's plan "rests on making sure that governors, like Scott Walker [of Wisconsin], contribute $23 billion on the first day to make college free. I'm a little skeptical," she said, to loud applause.
An unexpected historical figure made his way into the debate: Henry Kissinger, who served as secretary of state and national security adviser under President Richard Nixon. Mr. Sanders sought to put Mrs. Clinton on the defensive, noting that she has said she has taken advice from Mr. Kissinger and citing his role in the secret bombings of Cambodia during the Vietnam War.
"I happen to believe that Henry Kissinger was one of the most destructive secretaries of state in the modern history of this country," Mr. Sanders said. "I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend. I will not take advice from Henry Kissinger."
Mrs. Clinton struck back, seeking to portray Mr. Sanders as unprepared for the world's foreign policy challenges. "Journalists have asked, who do you listen to on policy and we have yet to know who that is," Mrs. Clinton said. "Well, it ain't Henry Kissinger, that's for sure," Mr. Sanders said.
While the exchange seemed an unusual detour, the Sanders campaign followed it with a memo to reporters detailing its view on Kissinger's policies.
The debate opened with a tense exchange over one of the pair's sharpest policy differences -- Mr. Sanders's proposal to create a single-payer health-care system that would replace private insurance with a government-funded system.
Mr. Sanders said it is imperative for the U.S. to guarantee health care as a right, not a privilege. Mrs. Clinton questioned his assertion that a typical American family will see $500 more in taxes while saving $5,000 in health-care costs.
"The numbers don't add up," she said. "That's a promise that cannot be kept."
Mr. Sanders responded by speaking of a general imperative. "Here is the reality, folks. There is one major country on Earth that does not guarantee health care to all people," he said.
Mrs. Clinton replied that the U.S. system is fundamentally different from European countries, which have government systems, and that the Affordable Care Act was meant to build on the employer-based system in place.
Mrs. Clinton suggested that her opponent was promising more than he could deliver as president and would plunge the country back into another protracted debate over health care: "We have a special obligation to make clear what we stand for, which is why we should not make promises we can't keep."
She said she has specified what her proposals would cost -- $100 billion a year. "Once I'm in the White House, we will have enough political capital" to close tax loopholes and raise taxes on wealthy Americans -- steps that would pay for her programs, she said.
In reply, Mr. Sanders seized on her prediction that she will be the next president. "Secretary Clinton, you're not in the White House yet," he said.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Clinton's Wall Street Talks Were Highly Paid, Friendly
article text:
In the two years between resigning as secretary of state and launching her presidential campaign, Hillary Clinton personally received $4.1 million in fees from financial institutions for closed-door talks that attendees described as friendly and light.
Today, the speeches have become an issue in her campaign. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, her rival in the Democratic primary, has repeatedly attacked her ties to Wall Street, including her large speech fees.
Most of Mrs. Clinton's comments steered clear of anything that could become controversial in her fight for the Democratic nomination, say people who attended some of these events or were briefed on them. She didn't often talk about the financial crisis, but when she did, she almost always struck an amicable tone, according to these people.
In some cases, she thanked the audience for what they had done for the country, the people said. One attendee said the warmth with which Mrs. Clinton greeted guests bordered on "gushy."
In a discussion with Goldman Sachs Group Inc. executives and some of its asset-management clients in October 2013, she spoke sympathetically about the financial industry, according to an attendee. Asked about the poisoned national mood toward Wall Street, Mrs. Clinton didn't single out bankers or any other group for causing the 2008 financial crisis. Instead, she effectively said, "We're all in this together, we've got to find our way out of it together," the attendee said.
Mrs. Clinton has said she would look into releasing the contents of her talks, many of which were transcribed by a stenographer that she requested be present. Her team is reviewing transcripts from dozens of speeches to assess potential pitfalls of releasing them to the public, people close to Mrs. Clinton said.
Some in the Clinton camp are concerned that comments not just about Wall Street, but also on the health-care law and foreign leaders could be taken out of context in an election season, they added.
A campaign spokesman declined to comment on whether transcripts would be released.
Mr. Sanders, in his attacks on Mrs. Clinton, has questioned why firms such as Goldman paid her $225,000 a speech. When asked at a CNN event last week to explain why she was paid these sums, Mrs. Clinton said, "I don't know, that's what they offered."
The fees and other details were negotiated on behalf of Mrs. Clinton by the Harry Walker Agency, a speakers' bureau that represented her. The agency didn't respond to a request for comment. Mrs. Clinton's profile page was missing from its website as of last week.
Beginning in early 2013, after leaving the State Department, Mrs. Clinton embarked on a two-year speaking career, making $21.7 million from about 100 speeches to universities, economic clubs, trade groups, investment banks, private-equity firms and several Canadian entities.
About one in five dollars that Mrs. Clinton collected while giving speeches from February 2013 to April 2015 came from banks and financial institutions.
She spoke at three client conferences hosted by Goldman Sachs; twice at Deutsche Bank AG; once each at events organized by Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Corp. and UBS; and also at gatherings hosted by private-equity firms KKR & Co., Apollo Management Holdings LP and GTCR LLC.
The Goldman alternative investments conference, where she also addressed the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial-overhaul law, was one of the few times Mrs. Clinton directly addressed questions about the financial crisis when speaking to Wall Street firms, according to people familiar with the matter. She said Dodd-Frank was working, but that there were ways it could be strengthened, the people said.
More often, Mrs. Clinton was asked about her four-year term as secretary of state, with people in the financial community curious to know what she thought of foreign leaders, U.S. foreign policy and whether she planned to run for president in 2016, said people familiar with the matter.
In April 2013, she was invited by Morgan Stanley to speak to clients of its fixed-income business at a conference dinner at the Library of Congress. In a 20-minute question-and-answer session, Thomas Nides, a Morgan Stanley vice chairman who had just returned to the bank after working as Mrs. Clinton's deputy in the State Department, lobbed what people familiar with the session described as gentle questions at his former boss.
Mrs. Clinton recounted the events leading to the capture of Osama bin Laden, among other topics. At the end of the event, she posed for photographs with attendees, as stipulated in her contract. Little was said about the financial crisis, according to people familiar with the conversation. The bank paid her $225,000.
Although some of her paid speeches were open to the public, those she made to financial firms were confidential. The contracts sent around by Mrs. Clinton's agency to these and other firms usually included extensive stipulations. They barred audio and video recordings, as well as broadcasts.
High-profile political speakers often ban recordings, but Mrs. Clinton was unusual in requiring that a stenographer be present to record and transcribe her remarks. In these cases, she had the sole right to distribute the transcripts.
Many of the events hosted by the financial firms were moderated discussions or Q&A sessions; in some, Mrs. Clinton typically made prepared remarks before taking questions from the audience.
In late October 2013, she sat down for an evening Q&A with Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs. The audience at the Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain, Ariz., was mostly technology entrepreneurs and senior Goldman executives. Mr. Blankfein started out by asking Mrs. Clinton for a "survey of the world," according to an attendee and a person briefed on the matter.
She told the audience how world leaders often asked her why politics in the nation's capital had become so gridlocked, saying it was hurting the U.S.'s reputation abroad.
Credit: By Anupreeta Das and James V. Grimaldi

article name: Election 2016: Subpoena Said to Be Issued To the Clinton Foundation
article text:
Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's family charitable foundation received a subpoena from government investigators last year, a person familiar with the matter said.
The Clinton Foundation was asked to turn over records and documents to the State Department's Office of Inspector General, the agency's independent watchdog.
The subpoena asked for information on some of the foundation's charitable work that may have required government approval, as well as records about longtime Clinton aide Huma Abedin, according to the Washington Post, which first reported the news. The Clinton Foundation didn't return requests for comment.
Ms. Abedin, who held simultaneous roles with the State Department and the foundation, has previously been the target of a probe by the Republican-led Senate Judiciary Committee. The State Department's inspector general also found that Ms. Abedin was overpaid by almost $10,000 for unused paid leave time when she left the government -- a finding she disputed.
A spokesperson for the State Department inspector general declined to comment. An attorney for Ms. Abedin didn't respond to a request for comment.
Brian Fallon, Mrs. Clinton's campaign spokesman, said "there are questions that need to be asked about the independence of that office." Speaking on CNN about the State Department inspector general, he said the office has engaged in "partisan fishing expeditions."
Separately, a federal judge on Thursday ordered releases of Mrs. Clinton's emails in advance of three primary elections or caucuses, citing public interest in the Democratic presidential candidate's records.
In an order as part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit brought by Vice News reporter Jason Leopold, U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras instructed the State Department to post all the emails ready for release in four batches on Feb. 13, Feb. 19, Feb. 26 and Feb. 29. Three of those dates fall the day before important Democratic election days -- injecting an element of uncertainty and political drama into the final releases of Mrs. Clinton's email trove.
Mrs. Clinton is locked in a close primary battle with Sen. Bernie Sanders. She beat the Vermont senator narrowly in Iowa; he came back to defeat her by 22 points in the New Hampshire primary this week.
Established as a vehicle to further the post-presidential work of former President Bill Clinton, the foundation is best known for its work on global development issues.
The State Department inspector general is also probing information management issues at the State Department, including Mrs. Clinton's use of a personal email server for government work.
In last week's Democratic debate, Mrs. Clinton said she was "absolutely" certain the investigations into her time at the State Department wouldn't affect her candidacy -- portraying them as political fishing expeditions.
Credit: By Byron Tau and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: An Empty Obama-Clinton-Sanders Plan on Drug Costs; Requiring drug-by-drug data on R&D spending shows a misunderstanding of how my industry works.
article text:
President Obama's latest budget includes proposals--echoed or one-upped on the presidential-campaign trail by Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton--that would require pharmaceutical companies to release data on the cost of research and development (R&D) and the extent of discounts offered to insurers for each drug brought to market. Yet the key numbers already are disclosed freely--and we know how to get better value from medicines and improve their affordability to patients.
The company I lead, Lilly, discloses its annual R&D spending in audited financial statements every year, like other public companies. Lilly's number for 2015 was $4.8 billion--part of the $50 billion invested in R&D each year by the members of our industry association alone. That's more than 20% of all R&D spending by all U.S. businesses. Seen against that staggering total, the proposal to mandate the nearly impossible task of assembling drug-by-drug R&D-spending figures misses the whole point.
Pharmaceutical companies' R&D feeds innovation from the earliest identification of leads through to clinical trials, real-world data collection and the refinement of existing treatments. It includes the cost of myriad failures--part of every scientific enterprise--along with further research on approved medicines, right up to their patent expirations. Money made on the sale of today's new medicines feeds all of the indispensable streams in this complex ecosystem.
Averages are easy enough to come by--a new academic study in the Journal of Health Economics says it takes about $2.6 billion in R&D investment per new medicine launched. Calculating a precise number for an individual product is quite another matter. Consider Lilly's investment of billions of dollars in R&D related to Alzheimer's disease over the last quarter century. Since there are several candidates in our pipeline that emerged from past work, to which future product and in what proportion should these costs be allocated? And to what end?
The key insight is beyond dispute. Developing medicines is risky, expensive and time-consuming, and everyone would be better off if it were less so. Rather than meaningless disclosure mandates, policy efforts instead should encourage whatever can be done, without compromising patient safety, to shave precious weeks off development and regulatory-approval timelines.
There are effective ways to do that. For example, pooling access to potential new molecules and sharing "pre-competitive" research on promising treatment paths could avoid costly duplication. Industry and the FDA could ramp up the use of "adaptive clinical trials" that refocus themselves based on real-time findings rather than starting over. And large-scale efforts to capture the real-world outcomes of treatments in genetically profiled patients--and feed these insights back to R&D labs--would accelerate progress significantly.
Mandating further disclosure of discounts negotiated by drug companies also is a route to nowhere. Lest anyone doubt that the discounts are substantial, allow me to report freely that the average net prices paid last year by Lilly's customers in the U.S. ranged from a high of 67% of list prices paid by commercial health plans to a low of 19% paid by government purchasers including Medicaid. That's right: The average discount off list price was more than 80% for government payers.
I'm not cherry-picking these figures--they cover Lilly's entire portfolio of established products. But forcing Lilly, or other companies, to disclose product-by-product and payer-by-payer discounts would be an unprecedented affront to free-market competition.
The list prices of medicines that feed media sensationalism are paid by essentially no institutional or government buyer in a hotly competitive marketplace. Yet affordability remains a problem for many patients. That's because insured patients in the U.S. today pay an average of about 20% of their prescription-drug costs out-of-pocket compared with about 5% of their hospital costs. Some patients' cost shares are much worse--due to complex insurance "tier" systems for drugs and the rise of "combined deductibles," in which drug expenses get lumped together with major-medical costs, and benefits hinge on reaching a high expense threshold.
The insurance bias against medicines needs to be addressed head-on, at the very least so that patients benefit from the savings negotiated by their insurers. Clearing the Food and Drug Administration's huge backlog of generic-drug applications would also be a great help.
Lilly and Anthem, a major insurer, recently asked for changes in federal regulations that make it difficult to set up "outcomes-based contracts." These would link payment for a drug to the presentation of evidence that patients achieved the health benefits expected from the drug, for example.
The realities that determine the cost of medicines to patients don't require mandated disclosures. They are as plain as day. They simply need to be acknowledged and acted upon rather than distorted and ignored.
Dr. Lechleiter, a chemist, is chairman, president and CEO of Eli Lilly and Company.
Credit: By John C. Lechleiter

article name: Election 2016: Nevada Union's Silence Clouds Caucus --- Clinton, Sanders battle for support of culinary workers after group forgoes endorsement
article text:
LAS VEGAS -- Eight years ago, Nevada's powerful Culinary Union mobilized to support its chosen candidate, Barack Obama, helping to boost turnout in the Democratic presidential caucuses and build credibility for what was still a long-shot campaign.
This time around, casino workers and their family members are up for grabs.
Leading into Saturday's Democratic caucus,the Culinary Union has withheld an endorsement, adding to the uncertainty around voter turnout and the outcome. It has also pushed the campaigns of Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders to go to aggressive lengths to find and court the union workers who cook, wash dishes, waitress and clean rooms in this tourism mecca.
Mr. Sanders came to the union offices last year even before he announced he was running for president, and he showed up this week at a protest outside a hospital, which Mrs. Clinton also attended. Earlier, his representatives went into employee dining halls at casinos and talked to workers while wearing union pins, a tactic the union said was inappropriate. Mr. Sanders' campaign chalked the issue up to a misunderstanding.
Mrs. Clinton in November appeared at an organizing rally outside a hotel co-owned by Donald Trump to support a union-organizing campaign there. She has met union members at several casinos in the last week.
"Both have shown a lot of support to come speak to us," said Nelson Lucero, a barista at the New York New York casino, who said he hadn't settled on a candidate. "I think that's really important."
With 57,000 members, the culinary workers' union, which is overwhelmingly Hispanic and Democratic, dominates state politics to an extent nearly unmatched elsewhere.
In past campaigns, the union made up much of the ground game for the candidates it supported. Part of its strength comes from being able to visit workers and talk to them about politics in the employee-only backhouses of casinos.
That was a factor in the 2008 and 2012 presidential races, as well as in Democratic Sen. Harry Reid's tight re-election campaign in 2010. The union also played a role in ousting several Republican state legislators, according to state political experts.
A variety of factors this year led the executive board of the Culinary Union's parent union, Unite Here, to vote in January not to endorse a candidate. The union has said that the primary factor in that decision was contract negotiations that are taking up time and resources.
"We made the decision to focus on union business over political business," said Yvanna Cancela, the union's political director.
One key issue, according to several people familiar with the matter, was a dispute with the Obama administration over some aspects of the Affordable Care Act. The union fought the so-called Cadillac tax, a 40% excise-tax increase on high-cost health-care plans, including those covering Culinary Union members. Mr. Obama signed into law a two-year delay on the tax late last year, but he had refused the union's demands that the tax be removed altogether.
Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders both supported the removal, but union officials wanted more evidence they would work against it, people familiar with the matter said.
The union learned that it "should expect more from politicians than campaign promises," one person familiar with its thinking said.
The AFL-CIO, the national union organization of which Unite Here is a part, also said this week that it wouldn't endorse a candidate in the Democratic primary.
For the Culinary Union, the nonendorsement allows it to avoid some of the awkward infighting that occurred eight years ago, when it endorsed Mr. Obama. Mrs. Clinton won the largest number of votes in the caucuses, but Mr. Obama won the most delegates.
The union's decision not to endorse a candidate could have implications for state Democrats in the fall. Some close to the Culinary Union say that with the union sitting out recent elections, they sense enthusiasm for politics could be down.
But Ms. Cancela said the union plans to heavily re-engage ahead of the general election to support the Democratic nominee.
It has started preparing by launching an organizing drive to gain citizenship for its members, so that they will be able to vote, and to register 12,000 additional members to vote.
Credit: By Alexandra Berzon and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Sanders and Clinton Vie for Rural Nevadans
article text:
ELKO, Nev. -- Hours away from the glam and glitter of Las Vegas, a fierce contest between Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is playing out in the mountains and deserts of Nevada.
State caucus rules give rural counties outsize weight in the delegate-allocation process, a directive aimed at ensuring candidates don't just campaign in the cities.
Consequently, the road to victory in Saturday's Democratic caucuses runs through places like Elko, a small mountain mining community that is the closest thing to a major city in northeast Nevada, and Pahrump, a desert town of about 36,000 that boasts a handful of casinos, a couple of brothels -- and Clinton and Sanders campaign field offices.
And both campaigns are working these sparsely populated communities, phoning supporters daily and driving to remote houses on dirt roads to knock on doors and see if the people who answer might need a lift to caucus sites.
Mr. Sanders brought his pitch to Elkoon Friday, a picturesque mountain town of 20,000 people that lies more than 300 miles north of Las Vegas in a conservative part of the state. He was following Mrs. Clinton, who flew in earlier in the week. Republican candidates, who hold their caucusesTuesday, were expected to start arriving in northern Nevada over the next few days.
"Tomorrow, the eyes of America and the eyes of much of the world are going to focus on Nevada," Mr. Sanders said at a rally. "And the issue is not just who wins the Democratic nomination. The issue is whether Nevada will play a leading role in moving this country toward a political revolution which transforms this country -- whether the people of Nevada will say enough is enough."
With polls showing the race as a dead heat, Mr. Sanders spent the day before the caucuses stumping in Elko and Reno before returning to Las Vegas for a large rally. Mrs. Clinton made stops in both Reno and Elko earlier in the week.
Though the overwhelming majority of the state's people live in and around Las Vegas, campaigns ignore the rural areas at their own peril. In the 2008 Democratic race between Mrs. Clinton and Barack Obama, she won the state but Mr. Obama collected more delegates in part because of a stronger organization and presence in the rural areas.
"She won the popular vote, but she did not win the caucus because caucuses are based on delegates," said Joan Kato, a former aide to Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign who now serves as the state director for Mr. Sanders. Nevada has 23 delegates up for grabs in this year's caucuses.
That was a mistake her campaign didn't plan to repeat. She has offices in Elko, Pahrump, and Carson City, and organizers across the state. Mr. Sanders has 12 field offices, though his campaign started organizing in Nevada months after Mrs. Clinton arrived.
The Clinton campaign says its staffers logged 1,250 miles across rural Nevada last summer, sending senior campaign leaders into communities for a listening tour that helped shape the campaign's rural strategy.
Former President Bill Clinton also visited Pahrump this month and spoke to a few hundred people at an elementary school.
Gabe Alvare, a 24-year-old Clinton volunteer visiting from New York City, spent hours knocking on doors of known supporters on Wednesday in Pahrump, making sure they planned to show up for the caucus. Another Clinton volunteer, Frank Dix, 73, lives in Pahrump and feels a special loyalty to the Clinton family. "I'm partial to strong women," Mr. Dix said.
There is no surefire way to get people to turn up at the caucus sites. One person mentioned that softball practice posed a potential conflict. A woman said her husband was planning to go, but he hasn't been feeling good lately.
At a spartan office nearby, the Sanders campaign was also working to get out the vote. Volunteers were making calls and planning a mock caucus session so attendees would know what to expecton Saturday.
Rick Bandell, a 75-year-old retiree, said he was thrilled to call one home and persuade an entire family to show up in support of Mr. Sanders. "I got four people in one call," he said. "They're going to caucus for Bernie. It's very unusual. I'd be happy to just to get one."
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Tries New Message: It's About 'We'
article text:
Hillary Clinton is voicing a new message: It isn't all about her.
The Democratic front-runner has spent much of the campaign talking about herself: how she is qualified for the presidency, how she knows how to govern, how she has gotten results. By contrast, rival Bernie Sanders has long talked about his quest for a political revolution as a collective effort that wouldn't succeed without the support of millions of Americans.
Now, there appears to be a subtle shift under way in Mrs. Clinton's rhetoric.
In her speech the night of this month's Iowa caucuses, she used "I" 37 times, and "we" or "we're" 25 times. In New Hampshire a week later, she used "I" 38 times and "we" 12 times.
Those numbers were reversed on Saturday after her victory in Nevada. She used the word "I" just 11 times, and "we" or "we're" 47 times.
"We're going to go into the future together," she said Saturday. Talking about the need for corporate responsibility, she said, "We all have to do our part." And in a move perhaps most important to her campaign, she challenged young people, who have overwhelmingly favored Mr. Sanders, to think not just about government solutions but community solutions -- a contrast with the Vermont senator's promise for free college and free national health care.
"It can't be just about what we're going to give you," she said. "It has to be about what we're going to build together."
It is an open question as to whether these shifts can address Mrs. Clinton's key vulnerabilities. In all three states to have voted, surveys showed that Mr. Sanders overwhelmingly won voters who said their priority was choosing a candidate who cares about people like them. He also easily won voters who said they most want a candidate who is honest and trustworthy.
Changing these perceptions won't be easy, Mrs. Clinton acknowledged Sunday on CNN.
"I think there's an underlying question that maybe is really in the back of people's minds. And that is, you know, is she in it for us, or is she in it for herself? I think that's . . . a question that people are trying to sort through," she said. "I have to . . . make my case."
In fits and starts, Mrs. Clinton has worked to show a different side of herself to voters.
She naturally gravitates toward a discussion of policy, and she often revs up the crowd with high-volume denunciations of the nation's ills. Many observers, including some of her top aides, think it is important that she mix in the softer side of her personality that comes through in quieter moments.
The campaign found one such moment in Las Vegas, and turned it into a powerful TV spot. During a forum on immigration, a 10-year-old girl told Mrs. Clinton that she is scared her parents would be deported. Mrs. Clinton brought her to stand close by and promised to do everything she could to help.
"You're being really brave," she told the girl, saying her parents don't want her to worry. "Let me do the worrying. I'll do all the worrying. Is that a deal?"
The ad reinforce Mrs. Clinton's support for legalization of people in the U.S. illegally, but it showcased the emotions, not the policy.
It was reminiscent of a TV spot earlier in the campaign featuring a little girl asking Mrs. Clinton whether she would be paid the same as a man if she is president. Its power was in the way Mrs. Clinton answered the question, and less about the underlying question of gender pay equity, one adviser said.
The new ad with the scared little girl helped win Nevada, the adviser added. "The side of Hillary Clinton that we know but need to show is that person who is understanding and connects," he said.
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Democrats Weak on Social Security Reform; None of the Social Security reform proposals put forward by Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders is new.
article text:
Regarding Andrew G. Biggs's "Hillary's and Bernie's Pie-in-the-Sky Social Security Proposals " (op-ed, March 18): None of the Social Security reform proposals put forward by Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders is new. All their proposals mirror features of European state pension plans, all of which face financing problems due in part to their rich benefits but mainly as a result of a lack of economic growth and demographic decline.
A serious policy to stabilize Social Security would gradually raise the retirement age to 69. The ceiling below which earnings are liable to the OASDI tax would be raised so that it covers 90% of earnings. If those two measures prove inadequate, tax should be increased modestly.
We should scrap the 75-year financial-planning window. No one knows how the economy will perform up to 2091 or how it will perform over the next five years. We should separate the finances of the retirement plan from the disability plan. We should stop cross-subsidizing the disability plan using funds from the retirement plan's reserve. We should take steps to stabilize the finances of the disability plan, primarily by limiting access to it so that it cannot be used as a de facto retirement program.
The government should implement policies that will promote economic growth by reducing both corporate and personal income-tax rates, allowing multinational companies to repatriate profits earned overseas without taxing them, reducing the burden of regulation, promoting immigration and reversing the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The single most important short-term obstacle to solving Social Security's financial problems is the federal government.
Prof. Alfred C. Mierzejewski
University of North Texas
Denton, Texas

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Keeps Up Heat on Clinton
article text:
PORTLAND, Maine -- Sen. Bernie Sanders and his top aides showed no sign they would dial back their harsh words for Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton on Wednesday, and promised to press ahead in the face of her growing delegate lead.
At a rally here ahead of Maine's caucuses this Sunday, Mr. Sanders pressed Mrs. Clinton to release transcripts of her paid speeches to Wall Street firms and mocked the idea that anything she said could have been worth the six-figure speaking fees she collected. He also reminded his audience that Mrs. Clinton once had been considered "the inevitable nominee."
"Guess what? She's not so inevitable today," he said. He celebrated the four states he won in voting on Tuesday without mentioning the seven states -- most of them much bigger -- that she carried.
Mr. Sanders has the money to press on as long as he wants, though Democrats may grow impatient with him out of fear that he will damage the woman who may ultimately represent them in November.
"Given the current trajectory, there may come a point when he will have to make a judgment about whether he can still win and how aggressively on the attack he wants to be if he can't," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories.
The Clinton campaign argued the contest was fast growing out of Mr. Sanders's reach. After Tuesday's voting, her lead among delegates chosen by voters grew to nearly 200, a bigger margin than Mr. Obama ever enjoyed in his 2008 battle for the nomination against Mrs. Clinton.
"Over the upcoming weeks, we intend to steadily add to Hillary Clinton's already sizable lead in delegates, and as we do, it will become harder and harder mathematically for Sen. Sanders to ever catch up," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook wrote in a "state of the race" memo.
After Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton was assured of at least 581 pledged delegates, who are chosen by voters, with Mr. Sanders claiming at least 388. The Mook memo contrasts Mr. Sanders's biggest win in his home state of Vermont, where he netted 16 delegates, to Mrs. Clinton's biggest victory of the night, in Texas, where she took 78.
Mrs. Clinton also has a huge lead among super delegates, party leaders who can vote for anyone. When those are included, her total tops 1,000, almost halfway to the number needed to clinch.
Tad Devine, a senior strategist for Mr. Sanders, said their campaign would make up ground as the race shifts to states with more favorable demographics. Mrs. Clinton's blow-out wins across the South were built on strong support from African-American voters, whereas coming states have larger share of white voters, who support Mr. Sanders in greater numbers.
However, after losing the white vote in Nevada, Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday rebounded, capturing 57% of the white vote in Virginia and essentially tying with Mr. Sanders among white voters in Massachusetts. She also won the white vote in Tennessee and Georgia.
Mr. Sanders's next opportunity comes this weekend with caucuses in Nebraska and Kansas, as well as Maine. He is also targeting Michigan's primary on Tuesday.
"We have to win a lot of places, beginning this weekend, and that's what we intend to do," Mr. Devine said.
Mr. Mook wrote that Mr. Sanders may win in the weekend's caucuses, but said Mrs. Clinton will more than make up any deficit with a victory in Louisiana, which votes Saturday. If Mr. Sanders wins in Michigan on Tuesday, Mr. Mook said, Mrs. Clinton will offset that with a bigger win in Mississippi, whose primary is the same day.
"The end result is that Sen. Sanders will spend millions of dollars in Michigan but not make any net gain in pledged delegates because he isn't competing in states like Mississippi," Mr. Mook predicted.
But if the race was all but over, it wasn't obvious in Maine, where a line of Sanders supporters snaked for blocks along downtown streets in near-freezing weather waiting to crowd into a local theater to hear him speak.
"The states that are coming up are lot more favorable than some of the ones on Super Tuesday, and he has a really good shot," said Evan O'Day-Senior, 30 years old.
The crowd numbered 2,400, though almost all the faces were white, a sign Mr. Sanders is still struggling to expand his coalition despite his campaign's promises, repeated on Wednesday, to do just that.
Given Mrs. Clinton's advantage, some Democrats were itching for Mr. Sanders to tone down his attacks. "If his goal is to simply deliver a message, he should think twice before criticizing the likely nominee who is on the verge of entering what promises to be a brutal general election campaign that will require Democrats to be unified," said Democratic strategist Ben Labolt, a former Obama aide.
Sanders aides explicitly rejected any suggestion that he is a "message candidate," and the senator showed no signs of toning down his criticism.
Credit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Group Can Investigate Clinton's Email Use
article text:
A federal judge will allow a conservative watchdog group to gather evidence in a lawsuit against the State Department about Hillary Clinton's use of a personal email server, creating the possibility that State Department officials could testify in a civil lawsuit over the Democratic presidential candidate's email practices when she was a cabinet official.
U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan on Tuesday granted Judicial Watch's request to allow depositions and discovery into how and why the State Department permitted Mrs. Clinton to use a personal email server for government business while she was secretary of state. He also authorized questioning about why the server wasn't searched as part of requests for Mrs. Clinton's public records.
In its request to the District of Columbia federal court, Judicial Watch proposed interviews under oath with top Clinton aides and confidantes, including Huma Abedin, Cheryl Mills and information technology staffer Bryan Pagliano.
Other proposed depositions included top State Department officials such as Undersecretary for Management Patrick Kennedy and John Hackett, the official responsible for Freedom of Information issues at the agency.
"This is one of several lawsuits filed by the same right-wing group, which will stop at nothing in pursuing the Clintons, just as they have done since the 1990s" said Clinton campaign spokesman Nick Merrill.
"The department is aware of the order and we are reviewing it," a State Department official said.
The process of gathering testimony is likely to play out over several months as the presidential campaign continues. Final details of the discovery proposal still need to be submitted and approved by Judge Sullivan, a Bill Clinton appointee, who said he wants briefings on the discovery plan to wrap up by April 12.
Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton said in an interview that he expects to start the discovery process within days after that deadline.
The request for discovery doesn't include a mention of Mrs. Clinton as a potential witness. Mr. Fitton said a deposition of her could be a possibility if the group decides to pursue one.
Transcripts of depositions of State Department witnesses or written responses by the State Department to Judicial Watch questions could be made public before the November election, according to University of Arizona law professor David Marcus, an expert on federal civil procedure.
But factors could also slow discovery down, said Mr. Marcus. Those could include scheduling disagreements and complications involving witnesses, the amount of time the government seeks to review transcripts or recordings, or appeals of discovery orders, he said. The State Department also could seek to seal discovery documents on a number of grounds, including that they contain vital national security secrets.
The decision to allow Judicial Watch to proceed with its lawsuit, which doesn't name Mrs. Clinton as a defendant, opens up another front in the controversy over her use of a private email server while at the State Department. That arrangement was discouraged but not forbidden by department rules.
Under federal law, Mrs. Clinton's records are eligible for release under the Freedom of Information Act. She has said repeatedly that she wants them made public.
Credit: By Byron Tau and Jacob Gershman

article name: Ted Cruz, Donald Trump Split Republican Contests; The Texas senator emerged victorious in Kansas and Maine, while Mr. Trump won Kentucky and Louisiana; Democratic candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders was the victor in Kansas and Nebraska, but front-runner Hillary Clinton took Louisiana's primary
article text:
Republican candidate for president Sen. Ted Cruz greets supporters after speaking at a rally on the campus of Boise State University in Boise, Idaho. The Texas senator won contests in Kansas and Maine.
Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton speaks at a reception for the Michigan Democratic Party at the MGM Grand Hotel in Detroit. The former secretary of state won the Louisiana Democratic primary but lost the Kansas and Nebraska caucuses to Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont.
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump walks to the podium at a press event at the Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla. The celebrity businessman won the Louisiana GOP primary but lost the Kansas and Maine contests to Mr. Cruz.
Mr. Sanders speaks at a campaign event in Warren, Mich., ahead of Tuesday's Michigan Democratic primary. The senator from Vermont came out victorious in the Kansas and Nebraska Democratic caucuses.

article name: Presidential Candidates and Antiterrorism; Even the worst of the four candidates he mentions, Hillary Clinton, would do a better job fighting terror than has Barack Obama.
article text:
The answer to the question Daniel Henninger raises in "Antiterrorism After Obama " (Wonder Land, March 24) is fairly simple. Even the worst of the four candidates he mentions, Hillary Clinton, would do a better job fighting terror than has Barack Obama. The only real question is how much she has been infected by political correctness, which would limit her effectiveness.
Political correctness is really a psychological incapacity to think dynamically. Even if reality demands change, leftists resist any imperative to do so. Their identities are so wrapped up in their ideology that a change of mind would amount to an act of self-negation, therefore they would no longer exist as the people they are. Homeostasis, whether wrapped in the veneer of a revolutionary or "progressive" identity, is their peace of mind no matter how perversely it contradicts facts or logic. Indeed, the hallmark of contemporary liberalism is the evasion of decisiveness--moral or otherwise.
This is precisely why President Obama doesn't deviate from his economic policies no matter how much a change in thinking would help improve the economy. He simply doesn't want to be proved wrong. In a similar fashion, changing course in his terrorism policy would amount to letting the terrorists "win," even if those changes were based on a better self-defense. So the question remains, has Hillary Clinton internalized this cognitive dissonance from her fellow liberals or is she only guided by her congenital difficulties with transparency and the truth?
On that score, the only candidate who isn't plagued by such demons is John Kasich.
Richard Reay
Riverdale, N.Y.

article name: Sanders Steps Up Clinton Attacks
article text:
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa. -- Sen. Bernie Sanders, closing out his campaign in Iowa, took a strategic gamble in hopes of notching a victory over Hillary Clinton in the state's Democratic caucuses Monday night: He went negative.
The Sanders campaign ran a new TV spot that implies Mrs. Clinton is in the pocket of Wall Street. And after refusing to talk about the Democratic front-runner's use of a private email server as secretary of state, Mr. Sanders on Sunday called her email practices a "very serious issue" that could render her unelectable.
Similarly, a Clinton campaign that had once ignored the 74-year-old democratic socialist is now casting him as a pie-in-the-sky dreamer whose ideas are utterly impractical.
"I don't want to over-promise and under-deliver. I'd rather under-promise and over-deliver," she said at a rally here. She added: "I know what it's going to take."
This wasn't the way many thought the Democratic primary would conclude before the balloting began.
When he jumped in the race in May, Mr. Sanders looked to many Democratic officials like a candidate who wanted a forum to talk about income inequality in America and who didn't really believe he could win. But the Vermont senator's success at raising money and attracting young voters has upended the race. The Sanders campaign announced Sunday it had raised $20 million in January alone.
On the eve of the caucuses, Iowa was up for grabs. Given the stakes, both the Clinton and Sanders campaigns are offering some sharp assessments of the opposition.
Assessing the new tone, Matthew Dowd, a former strategist to President George W. Bush, said: "It's been ratcheted up. Hillary understands that if she wins Iowa, she basically begins to end the race. Bernie realizes that the whole premise of his race is contingent on winning Iowa, and he's trying to do whatever he possibly can at this point to get over the hump."
Spotlighting a vulnerability, Mr. Sanders is making the case that Mrs. Clinton is beholden to Wall Street. Speaking to reporters at a Bloomberg Politics breakfast last week, he mentioned that Mrs. Clinton had just attended a fundraising event at a Philadelphia investment firm.
"That's how she has raised money throughout her political career," he said. "Millions of dollars from Wall Street and from other very powerful special interests."
The combative posture poses risks for Mr. Sanders -- something his team acknowledges. He has pledged to usher in a more uplifting style of politics. He has said he would inspire voters and thus expand turnout on Election Day much as Barack Obama did eight years earlier.
Recognizing the potential damage to the Sanders brand, his aides say there are lines he won't cross: He won't air the classic political attack ad complete with ominous music and unflattering pictures of Mrs. Clinton.
"He's not going to go there; it's not in the cards," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist.
So, instead, some of Mr. Sanders's ads leave it to voters to connect the dots. The latest spot features Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and its role in the 2008 financial collapse. No pictures of Mrs. Clinton's face appear in the ad; her name is never mentioned. Yet she is the star.
Mrs. Clinton and her husband have a long history of dealings with Goldman. Together, they have collected nearly $3 million in speaking fees from the company since 2005.
In the spot, a narrator says that "millions in campaign contributions and speaking fees" enabled Wall Street firms to engage in reckless practices.
In an interview with NBC News over the weekend, Mrs. Clinton said her opponent's method is to discredit her through "insinuation and implication."
"That's disappointing," she added, "because he's always prided himself on being a candidate, a politician -- he's been in politics a really long time -- not to go negative."
As the campaign unfolds Mr. Sanders has flashed increasing irritation at some of the criticism lodged by Team Clinton. Clinton allies have said that Mr. Sanders's socialist views would be exploited by Republicans in a general election.
On Sunday, Mr. Sanders tried to turn the tables. Asked by ABC News if he would get "slapped" with the socialist label should he win the party's nomination, he pointed to recent disclosures that top secret information passed through Mrs. Clinton's private email server.
Having memorably told Mrs. Clinton in a debate in October that Americans were "sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails," he said Sunday: "Look at the front pages in terms of what Secretary Clinton is getting slapped with."
Mrs. Clinton dismissed the latest controversy over her email as an "interagency dispute" that pales next to the larger issues on voters' minds.
For all the sparring, both campaigns are also taking pains to put out a positive message. But their core arguments are very different.
Mrs. Clinton says that her strength is persevering in the face of setbacks. A biographical video that plays for crowds ahead of her appearances ends with Mrs. Clinton saying, "I don't quit" -- a theme of her campaign since it launched last April. She says she has the experience and stamina to both accomplish her goals and beat the Republican nominee this fall.
Mr. Sanders is laying out a broader vision of a country that seeks to overturn a political system that favors the richest Americans.
He is calling for a bottom-up "revolution" that will compel Washington officials to act in the interests of a struggling middle class.
A huge rally he held Saturday in the college town of Iowa City captured the campaign's mood.
As he finished his remarks, the rock band Vampire Weekend took the stage and invoked an optimistic spirit of America at its best.
The band played Woody Guthrie's "This Land is Your Land," and were joined by Mr. Sanders and his wife, Jane, who, together with the crowd sang along: "From the redwood forests to the Gulf Stream waters, this land was made for you and me."
---
Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: 'C' Is for Corruption; The Clintons are the Brazilianization of American politics.
article text:
Postcards from yesterday's countries of the future:
Brazil: President Dilma Rousseff of the Workers' Party faces impeachment on charges of cooking government books. Corruption investigations are ongoing in cases involving former President Lula da Silva and the presidents of both houses of Congress. Inflation is in double digits and the economy contracted by 3.8% last year.
In 2009, the Economist magazine praised Brazil for "smart social policy and boosting consumption at home," predicting its economy would overtake Britain's after 2014.
Turkey: Recep Tayyip Erdogan was in Washington last week, where the Turkish president's security detail made diplomatic history by beating up protesters outside his speech at the Brookings Institution. A 2013 corruption scandal, implicating dozens of members of Mr. Erdogan's ruling AKP party, including two of his children, fizzled after the government purged 350 police officers investigating the affair.
In 2009, Hillary Clinton described Turkey as "an emerging global power." Financial Times columnist Philip Stephens (no relation) gushed that Turkey "sets a powerful democratic example to the rest of the Muslim world."
China: A leak of 11.5 million documents from Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca--instantly dubbed "the Panama Papers"--implicate relatives of President Xi Jinping along with other top officials of sheltering fortunes in offshore tax havens. Mr. Xi is supposed to be leading an anticorruption campaign.
In 2009, New York Times columnist Tom Friedman wrote of the "great advantages" of China's "one-party autocracy," which he praised for being led by "a reasonably enlightened group of people."
The Panama Papers have also exposed billions in assets belonging to close friends of Vladimir Putin, which isn't surprising, along with revelations that the first lady of Iceland owned an offshore holding company, which sort of is. Other boldfaced names in this sludgy mix of shell companies include Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, Argentine President Mauricio Macri, the children of Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and even the late father of British Prime Minister David Cameron.
Everyone mentioned here denies wrongdoing, including the Mossack Fonseca firm--founded by the son of a onetime Waffen-SS officer who sought his fortune in Panama after the war. And everyone is entitled to a fair presentation of the facts, if necessary in court.
But nobody can be surprised by any of this. And nobody should look away from the central lesson of the scandal, though they're trying. To wit, the story here isn't about tax evaders and offshore accounts, deplorable as they may be. It's about public policies and incentives that make a career in politics an expedient route to personal enrichment.
The point is illustrated by Brazil, where state-owned oil giant Petrobras sits at the center of the multiplying corruption scandals. The former chairwoman of Petrobras was Ms. Rousseff, whose main qualification for the job--she's also a former Marxist guerrilla--was her reputation as an aggressive party hack. She has not been accused of using her position for personal enrichment, but Lula is under investigation for accepting Petrobras kickbacks in the form of a luxury apartment and other goodies. He denies the charges.
Meanwhile, Petrobras last year estimated its corruption-related losses at $17 billion. At least 57 Brazilians are being investigated for using Mossack Fonseca to open 107 offshore companies. Throughout all this, the ruling party's explicit economic agenda is to build "national champions" like Petrobras through the use of a state-owned "development bank" and other government subsidies.
What's true of Brazil is true of China, and of Russia, and of every other regime where political power or influence dictates the direction and pace of investment. That's why it was hard to take seriously a decade's worth of boosterism about the so-called BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa) as the countries of the future. Kleptocracy is not a form of sustainable development.
***
Which brings us to Hillary Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee and--if Republicans nominate either Donald Trump or Ted Cruz--likely the next president of the United States. Mrs. Clinton's email arrangements are supposed to be the scandal that will fell her, but what ought to frighten Americans is the way the Clintons mix money and power in the black box of their eponymous foundation to award themselves more of each.
This is the Brazilianization of American politics, albeit with more legal finessing. But the stench is the same, and it's why so many Americans, Democrats included, instinctively recoil at the thought of another Clinton presidency.
So far the Panama Papers seem to have netted few Americans, which may say something about the fundamental probity of the U.S. system. Nothing ordains that it should last forever. "C" is also for Clinton.
Write bstephens@wsj.com.
Credit: By Bret Stephens

article name: Clinton, Sanders Collide At Debate
article text:
DURHAM, N.H. -- The Democratic presidential candidates clashed Thursday night over who is the true progressive at their first one-on-one debate, with Hillary Clinton saying Sen. Bernie Sanders has put forward an unrealistic agenda that would ultimately collapse.
Mrs. Clinton spent much of the first hour defending her record, ideologically and in practice, after Mr. Sanders attacked her links to financial firms. "What being part of the establishment is, is in the last quarter, having a super PAC that raised $15 million from Wall Street," he said.
She termed Mr. Sanders's "insinuation" that Wall Street donations would keep her from adequately policing the industry an "artful smear."
A combative tone was set early on when Mrs. Clinton pushed back on Mr. Sanders's claim that she isn't a true "progressive."
"I'm not making promises that I cannot keep," Mrs. Clinton said, drawing a distinction between her self-described ability to get things done and Mr. Sanders's campaign proposals with numbers that she said "just don't add up."
The Vermont senator said Mrs. Clinton, a former senator and secretary of state, has at times described herself as a "moderate" who has a more incremental approach to solving economic problems that require bold action.
The candidates sparred over health care, the financial struggles of middle class families and the influence of Wall Street political donations.
The debate came five days before the primary in New Hampshire, where a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll shows Mr. Sanders maintains a comfortable lead. The fifth Democratic debate didn't include former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who dropped out of the race Monday after a poor showing in the Iowa caucuses.
Mr. Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, wrote in a stream of tweets on Wednesday that a genuine progressive wouldn't take millions of dollars in Wall Street donations, as Mrs. Clinton has done.
In the debate, he noted that in a campaign event last fall in Ohio, Mrs. Clinton said that "I plead guilty" to "being kind of moderate and center."
Mrs. Clinton chided him for "cherry-picking" quotes she had given, noting that more often she says she is a progressive who wants to get things done. She also accused Mr. Sanders of being the "self-proclaimed gatekeeper of progressivism." She said few Democrats would meet the standard he has set, including President Barack Obama who, she noted, also accepted campaign money from Wall Street.
She also said that under Mr. Sanders's definition, Vice President Joe Biden wouldn't be considered a progressive. His support for the Keystone XL pipeline would disqualify him, she indicated -- a statement that appeared at odds with what is known about the vice president's views.
The Obama administration rejected the pipeline last year, and as early as 2013, Mr. Biden reportedly told a supporter he opposed Keystone.
During the debate, a Clinton campaign aide said she misspoke in citing Keystone as the example for Mr. Biden. He would fail the progressive test, her campaign said, because he supports the Asian free-trade agreement and the death penalty.
After weeks in which Mr. Sanders has suggested that Mrs. Clinton is compromised because of Wall Street contributions and speaking fees, Mrs. Clinton hit back hard. "Enough is enough. If you've got something to say, say it directly," she said.
She added that she is proud of the job she's done representing her constituents as a former New York senator. "I think it's time to end a very artful smear that you and your campaign have been carrying out in recent weeks," she said.
Mr. Sanders replied by speaking in general of contributions from pharmaceutical companies and oil companies, saying they get their way in Congress because of their donations. But he didn't cite anything in Mrs. Clinton's record.
"There is a reason why these people are putting huge amounts of money into our political system," he said. "It is undermining American democracy."
Mrs. Clinton countered by noting she's the one who is being attacked by special interests, in the past and during this campaign, and that she's introduced a comprehensive plan to change the way campaigns are financed. "Today you've got hedge fund billionaires aligned with Karl Rove who are running ads against me to try to get Democrats to vote for you," she said.
One of the lingering questions in the race is whether Mrs. Clinton will face legal trouble stemming from an FBI investigation into her use of a private email system when she served as secretary of state.
Asked if she could reassure Democrats that no bombshell revelations were coming, she said yes, dismissing the entire exercise as partisan.
"Before it was emails, it was Benghazi," she says. "I have absolutely no concerns about it whatsoever," noting that the government earlier on Thursday also accused former Secretary of State Colin Powell of receiving classified emails on a personal email account.
She added that she is "100% confident" that nothing would come of the FBI's investigation into her emails.
Mr. Sanders was also asked about Mrs. Clinton's emails, but refused to be drawn into an attack. He said there is a "process under way" and that he "will not politicize it." He added that "not a day goes by" when he's not asked to attack her on the email issue, and said he has declined.
On foreign policy, Mrs. Clinton was comfortable positioning herself to the right of Mr. Sanders. She cast him as naive for suggesting the U.S. should move aggressively toward normalizing relations with Iran.
"If we were to normalize relations right now, we would remove one of the biggest pieces of leverage we have to try to influence and change Iranian behavior," she said. "The president doesn't think we should. I certainly don't think we should."
Mr. Sanders pushed back, saying he doesn't support normalizing relations immediately but would like to work toward that goal. "Please don't suggest that I think we normalize relations with Tehran tomorrow. We don't," he said. "But I would like to see us move forward, and hopefully someday that will happen."
Noting her experience on the world stage, Mrs. Clinton pointed to a statement from a number of national-security experts that raised concerns about her rival's understanding of foreign affairs. "I do think questions have been raised and questions have to be answered because when New Hampshire voters go on Tuesday to cast your vote, you are voting both for a president and a commander in chief," she said.
---
Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas, Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton's Wall Street Dilemma --- Pushed by rival, Democratic front-runner struggles to justify money from the financial industry
article text:
In the battle for the Democratic nomination, Sen. Bernie Sanders is focused on turning Hillary Clinton's support from the financial industry, one of her longtime political assets, into a weapon against her.
Mr. Sanders has targeted Mrs. Clinton's close relationship with Wall Street, saying her history of taking money from big banks and hedge funds shows she isn't a progressive. The charge has helped Mr. Sanders gain traction with a Democratic electorate uneasy with the power of wealthy firms.
Mr. Sanders raised the Wall Street donations as the two traded barbs during a New Hampshire debate Thursday night, prompting Mrs. Clinton to defend herself. "You will not find that I ever changed a view or a vote because of any donation I ever received," she said.
Mrs. Clinton, who has struggled to justify the money she has received from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other Wall Street firms over the years, had said Wednesday during a televised CNN candidate forum in New Hampshire that she accepted fees of more than $200,000 per speech because "that's what they offered."
Other prominent Democrats, including President Barack Obama in 2008, have combined a friendly relationship with the financial world with attacks on big-moneyed interests.
But no Democrat or Republican running for president this year has received as much money from Wall Street executives for their campaigns as Mrs. Clinton has. Wall Street is the top donor to her 2016 presidential campaign and to a super PAC run by Mrs. Clinton's allies to support her candidacy.
