Only the super PAC supporting Republican Jeb Bush has raised more on Wall Street.
More broadly, since Mrs. Clinton and former President Bill Clinton entered national politics in the early 1990s, Wall Street has contributed more than $100 million to their political campaigns, charitable foundation and personal finances, according to a review by The Wall Street Journal.
Financial-services firms accounted for about 12% of the total amount raised by the Clintons during their more than two decades in politics.
Some Wall Street money has helped the couple's personal finances. Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. and other Wall Street firms have paid the Clintons more than $20 million in speaking fees over the years.
Many on Wall Street say they favor Mrs. Clinton because they agree with her on a range of topics -- and because they believe she will take their views into account if she pursues stepped-up regulations on financial services firms, according to interviews with more than two dozen executives.
Concerns over the nomination of either Texas Sen. Ted Cruz or New York businessman Donald Trump have prompted some Republicans on Wall Street to consider Mrs. Clinton as the better alternative. Many, however, say they are leaning toward Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, who appeals to business-oriented Republicans.
Clinton aides dismiss talk that Mrs. Clinton is too cozy with the financial industry. "She went to Wall Street before the crash and warned them that what they were doing could hurt the economy and called them out on it," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told reporters Thursday. "She has introduced the strongest plan in this race . . . It actually deals with the swaps and derivatives that led to this crash."
Mrs. Clinton's plan seeks to build on the 2010 Dodd-Frank law to strengthen oversight of the banking sector and unregulated "shadow banking" activities that played a significant role in the 2008 financial crisis. She has also proposed a tax on certain types of high-frequency trading -- automated stock trading by computers that has been profitable but can cause excessive volatility -- and has pitched a so-called risk fee on the biggest financial firms.
Still, there is a general feeling that "she's not going to come after Wall Street," said a Clinton super PAC donor who has spoken to dozens of potential supporters.
The widespread view on Wall Street, say executives, is that Mrs. Clinton, driven by pragmatic considerations, doesn't see financial firms as inherently bad and is willing to work on solutions.
Mrs. Clinton's supporters say she is able to push for higher middle-class incomes without demonizing the wealthy.
"Even for a lot of people on Wall Street, the concept of equality resonates," said David Lichtenstein, a real estate investor who hosted a fundraiser last month for Mrs. Clinton.
Mrs. Clinton's supporters say her campaign talk about reining in banks, curbing excessive risk-taking and punishing individuals for financial wrongdoing reflects a negative voter mood.
"She moved to the left because she needed some political cover in her fight against Sanders," said Greg Valliere, chief global strategist at asset manager Horizon Investments. "Her plan may be aggressive, but her ties to Wall Street make it unlikely that this proposal of hers will be a top priority . . . it's the cynical view."
Clinton advisers said she would closely police Wall Street as president.
"People on Wall Street have been supporting her not because they think she's going to roll over on Wall Street, but because they agree with her on other issues outside of Wall Street," said Thomas Nides, a former deputy secretary of State under Mrs. Clinton and now vice chairman of Morgan Stanley.
While her husband's administration was stocked with Wall Street veterans, the Clintons' connections with the finance community grew in 1999, when they bought a home in Chappaqua, an affluent suburb of New York City.
At the time, Mrs. Clinton and her husband were linked with a centrist, pro-business wing of the Democratic Party that didn't seek to alienate Wall Street. Supporters described them as a celebrity couple, charming New York's financial community and blending into summers in the Hamptons, the Long Island community of beach towns where many rich New Yorkers keep homes.
"He was the former president and she was the former first lady," Mr. Nides said. "She was already a well-known commodity, and people wanted to be with her."
As the couple expanded their Wall Street network, hedge-fund managers, bankers and wealthy investors wrote checks to the Clinton Foundation philanthropy and agreed to host fundraisers in their homes for Mrs. Clinton's budding political career. Many were pleasantly surprised to receive handwritten thank-you notes, flowers or phone calls from the couple.
Now, engaged in a presidential primary, Mrs. Clinton is finding these relationships, so helpful in the past, a point of vulnerability.
In the run-up to Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, Mr. Sanders has sharpened his attacks on Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street. At campaign stops around the state, he paints her as an establishment figure incapable of overhauling the political system to benefit everyday American families.
Campaign finance reports made public this week show Mrs. Clinton leads all others in financial support from Wall Street. Through the end of 2015, Wall Street had donated $2.9 million to Mrs. Clinton's election campaign and $55,226 to the campaign of Mr. Sanders.
Among Republicans, Wall Street donors have contributed a total of about $2 million to Messrs. Cruz, Rubio and Trump.
A super PAC run by Mrs. Clinton's supporters has collected an additional $14.3 million from Wall Street, a total surpassed only by the super PAC set up to back Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor. Mr. Sanders doesn't have a major super PAC supporting his campaign; a super PAC run by a nurses union has spent nearly $1 million on his behalf.
Overall, Wall Street accounted for about a third of the funds the Clinton super PAC raised last year. Billionaire investor George Soros gave the pro-Clinton super PAC Priorities USA Action, $6 million in December, bringing his total donations to the group to $7 million.
The newly released campaign finance filings show Mrs. Clinton raised the most money among the presidential candidates from just about every industry tracked by the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics.
In all, donations from the financial-services sector make up a large and growing share of the amount of money raised in U.S. elections. Through the end of 2015, money from financial services firms made up roughly 40% of the $1 billion donated so far into the 2016 election, compared with less than 20% of the total in 2012 and 5% in 2008.
---
Rebecca Ballhaus, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.
Credit: By Anupreeta Das and Brody Mullins

article name: Election 2016: Clinton, Sanders Sharpen Their Rhetoric --- Democrats spar over who is 'progressive' and the senator's edge in a neighboring state
article text:
DERRY, N.H. -- Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders stepped up their attacks before they meet for a one-on-one debate Thursday, campaigning aggressively in a state that her campaign says she may not be able to win.
Trailing by double digits in New Hampshire polls, Mrs. Clinton on Wednesday rejected suggestions that she look past the state and focus instead on friendlier territory, as both campaigns sharpened their tones and sparred from afar.
Mr. Sanders jabbed first on Tuesday when he said the former senator and secretary of state is a progressive on some days. "Except when she announces she's a moderate," he added. "Then she's not a progressive."
Mrs. Clinton responded at a get-out-the-vote event, calling her opponent's comments a "low blow" and saying she has delivered results for progressives. She said the race should focus on issues, but added that "if it's about our records, hey, I'm going to win by a landslide."
The squabble over which candidate is more progressive ramped up online with a series of tweets from Mr. Sanders's account, including a long list of more moderate policy positions that Mrs. Clinton has taken in the past.
The two Democrats continued to parse the definition of progressive during a town hall event Wednesday night. Mr. Sanders noted that the former secretary of state has described herself as a moderate in the past.
"You can't be a moderate and a progressive -- they are different," Mr. Sanders said.
When Mrs. Clinton took the stage, she said she was amused that her rival had cast himself as a gatekeeper determining who is a progressive. "I don't think it helps for the senator to be making those kinds of comparisons," she said.
Earlier, Mrs. Clinton's campaign suggested that Mr. Sanders has built-in advantages in New Hampshire because he represents neighboring Vermont. Mr. Sanders parried, saying New Hampshire voters are serious about their role in the nominating process and that "to repeatedly suggest otherwise is an insult" to them.
Mr. Sanders said on CNN that the Clinton campaign is financed by Wall Street and big-money interests. Mrs. Clinton countered by critiquing her rival's health-care plan.
This intensifying tit-for-tat is playing out in a state where Mrs. Clinton is a decided long-shot. A Real Clear Politics average of polls shows Mr. Sanders with an 18-percentage-point advantage in Tuesday's primary, and some have suggested Mrs. Clinton should focus her resources on the states that will vote shortly after New Hampshire.
"Not on your life," Mrs. Clinton told supporters Wednesday. "I would never quit on New Hampshire."
The Clinton campaign has tried to lower expectations in recent days, saying that Mrs. Clinton's 2008 come-from-behind win in New Hampshire is unlikely to be replicated. Jennifer Palmieri, Mrs. Clinton's communications director, said Mr. Sanders has a substantial lead but that the former secretary of state would stay in New Hampshire through the primary, trying to build support.
"We don't know that we can win, but she is going to be here every day," Ms. Palmieri said.
The Sanders campaign pushed back against the Clinton team's attempts to play down her prospects. "They're overplaying their hand on this 'He's a neighbor' stuff,' " said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist. "Our view is we're up against the whole establishment again."
The battle for New Hampshire and the tonal shift in the Democratic campaign come on the heels of a hard-fought contest in Iowa that saw Mrs. Clinton eke out a razor-thin win.
Some Democratic strategists said Mrs. Clinton remains in a stronger position for the long term. With the race soon moving to states with higher percentages of minority voters, Mrs. Clinton stands to do better, they said. Steve McMahon, a longtime Democratic consultant, said the Iowa result "helped Bernie, but it wasn't enough of a 'Voila!' moment to change the dynamic in South Carolina and Nevada."
Mr. Sanders is telling supporters that the political establishment is growing nervous about his staying power. Winning the nomination won't be easy, the senator said, but he noted that in Iowa he took on the "most powerful political organization in the country."
For her part, Mrs. Clinton is positioning herself as a fighter, not a front-runner, and is quick to remind voters that she is running against a "neighbor." She urges, "New Hampshire, come with me."
---
Jennifer Levitz contributed to this article.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Takes Campaign Detour to Meet Flint Voters
article text:
Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton left New Hampshire Sunday to travel to the besieged city of Flint, Mich., promising to help the community work through a water crisis however she can -- and perhaps boost her campaign with a critical set of voters.
"I will fight for you no matter how long it takes," Mrs. Clinton said to a cheering congregation at the House of Prayer Missionary Baptist Church just minutes after they took communion. "This is for me a personal commitment. I will stand with you every step of the way."
Her address combined prayer -- she opened with a verse from Psalms -- with policy and a call to action, as she addressed a predominantly African-American audience struggling in the aftermath of a crisis that left the city's water supply poisoned with lead.
She also said she is pushing Congress to approve $200 million in federal aid for the city. Senate Republicans balked last week at the additional funds.
The trip meant she missed most of Sunday in New Hampshire, two days before its first-in-the-nation primary.
Two surveys this weekend put Sen. Bernie Sanders's lead over Mrs. Clinton at about 10 percentage points, but others have it much higher. She appeared at a Dunkin' Donuts and on Sunday talk shows before departing New Hampshire. Mr. Sanders, too, left the state Saturday to appear on NBC's "Saturday Night Live" in New York.
The Clinton campaign concluded that the time away from the Granite State was well worth it.
Even if Sanders wins in New Hampshire on Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton holds a strong advantage with African-American and Hispanic voters who are important in states to come, and her trip to Flint was meant to reinforce her argument that she is a doer who finds ways to solve problems.
Over the last few weeks, Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly drawn attention to the situation in Flint, sending a top aide there and pushing for a coming debate with Mr. Sanders to be staged there.
To save money, the city of Flint began using the Flint River as its water source in April 2014, but the corrosive waters ate away at pipes and leached lead into Flint's water supply.
State officials initially dismissed complaints by residents and outside researchers who said tainted water was causing elevated blood lead levels in children.
Mrs. Clinton followed her public address with a closed-door meeting with 21 community leaders, including the mayor, Karen Weaver, who credited Mrs. Clinton's attention to the issue with helping to get the city the help it needs.
"The heat was on, but you turned the heat up," Ms. Weaver told the former secretary of state at the top of the meeting. "She came when no one else would."
Residents at the event said her visit was good for them and, potentially, for her.
"I think she has genuine compassion," said Carol Gardner, 60 years old, who tidied up pews after the event and pointed out the likely power of the Flint water issue at the ballot box. "If she didn't campaign on it, that wouldn't be good politics," she added.
At Hutchinson Food & Drug, just down the road from the church, Cynthia Howell packed her sport-utility vehicle with groceries for a Super Bowl party and said it was fine with her if Mrs. Clinton scored some political points.
"If you're going to use us, we're going to use you," said the 59-year-old community advocate, who was born and raised in Flint. "Everybody has an agenda."
Credit: Ben Kesling, Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016 -- Analysis: Clinton, Sanders Pitches: Doer or Dreamer
article text:
Thursday night's Democratic debate in New Hampshire was the clearest illustration yet of how the party's presidential race is now defined: It is a battle between a doer and a dreamer.
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton portrays herself as the doer. She stressed her experience, her desire to set achievable goals and her ability to work the system successfully to achieve them. There are limits to what can be done, she seemed to be saying, and it is better to work all the way to those limits rather than play Don Quixote, tilting at windmills, and ultimately fail.
"Let's go down a path where we can actually tell people what we will do," she said. "A progressive is someone who makes progress. That's what I intend to do."
Sen. Bernie Sanders plays the role of the dreamer. If the system sets limits, he argued, don't accept the limits, but instead smash the system.
Wage a political "revolution" -- a word he uses without reservation, and repeatedly -- for government-guaranteed health care for all, for free college education, for a giant leap in the minimum wage.
And he has a simple unifying theory of why this all hasn't happened already: a "corrupt" campaign-finance system that allows corporate interests who would lose in a changed world to stand in the way. Change campaign finance and all becomes possible.
"What we need to do is to stand up to the big money interests, and the campaign contributors," he said. "When we do that, we can, in fact, transform America."
The sheer simplicity of the Sanders message is what gives it its greatest appeal to frustrated older voters and idealistic younger ones. Yet it also was clear Thursday night that the simplicity of it also is what exasperates Mrs. Clinton.
She described herself more as a battle-scarred veteran who has learned the hard way that it is best to do the work without, as she said, "making promises that I cannot keep."
So her goal is to make college more affordable, not to promise that it can be free. She wants to expand and improve the health-care law known as Obamacare, not toss it aside in pursuit of some dubious goal of Medicare for all.
At one point she argued that she has the ability to work together with Republicans and independents to achieve such things: "We'll get things done together."
Mr. Sanders said his approach wouldn't be to negotiate compromise with, say, Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell but rather to bring an army of citizens to his doorstep to make him accept their demands.
"No, you just can't negotiate with Mitch McConnell," he said. "Mitch is going to have to look out the window and see a whole lot of people saying, 'Mitch, stop representing the billionaire class. Start listening to working families.' "
The Sanders approach seemed to put Mrs. Clinton on the defensive during the first part of the debate. But the tables turned later, when the discussion turned to national security, as she painted his approach as not idealistic but rather dangerously naive.
That area is where she, as the nation's former top foreign-policy cabinet official, is the more nimble candidate.
She argued that it is a mistake to suppose, as Mr. Sanders has suggested, that it would be acceptable to invite Iranian troops into Syria to help police put an end to the civil war there, or to fully normalize relations with Iran more broadly.
"If we were to normalize relations right now, we would remove one of the biggest pieces of leverage we have to try to influence and change Iranian behavior," she said. Better to "take this step by step to try to rein in Iranian aggression, their support for terrorism and the other bad behavior that can come back and haunt us."
On that front, she got Mr. Sanders to argue that he, too, could be realistic, and that he was talking of normalizing relations eventually, not immediately.
Overall, though, Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire and beyond have two quite different approaches to choose between: a candidate who stresses achievement and one who prefers aspirations.
Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Verizon's Political Strike; Sanders and Clinton join picket lines on behalf of the rotary-phone era.
article text:
As Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders chase each other further to the left, it was only a matter of time before somebody decided to capitalize on their competition. The Democrats have now helped inspire the largest domestic strike in years--and it's pure political performance art.
On Wednesday, more than 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast walked off the job after their unions rejected the telecom's latest contract offer in a 10-month negotiation. The Communication Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers wanted a public spectacle, and did they ever get one.
Mr. Sanders joined a picket line in Brooklyn and began, "Brothers and sisters, thank you for your courage and standing up for justice against corporate greed." He went on to accuse Verizon of "trying to destroy the lives of working Americans," and that was the subtle part. Mrs. Clinton demanded that the company "do the right thing" and tender "a fair offer to their workers."
The Democrats are not exactly Bobby Kennedy communing with Cesar Chavez and destitute grape pickers. How's this for "fair"? The walk-offs enjoy an average annual pay and benefits package of $130,000. Management is offering a 6.5% cash wage increase, the same health coverage as its other domestic employees and an industry-competitive 401(k) match.
Yet Verizon and the unions have largely agreed about compensation. The unions preferred to make a political statement about expanding the ranks of the Americans lucky enough to have decent-paying jobs, which apparently means showing solidarity with an increasingly obsolete business model.
Some 99% of the strikers work for Verizon's legacy "wireline" business, or its traditional fixed phone service plus its fiber optic Internet service. This unit generates only 7% of Verizon operating income, down from 60% in 2000--wireless is more profitable--and as more customers ditch land lines, it is only natural that these old-fashioned networks will require fewer workers to operate and maintain.
But Verizon isn't even looking to shed jobs. It is merely seeking more flexibility to manage its workforce, such as consolidating under-used call centers and the ability to hire more outside contractors. "Nostalgia for the rotary-phone era won't save American jobs," Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam wrote in a LinkedIn post.
Mr. McAdam also called Mr. Sanders's rhetoric "contemptible," publishing a detailed rebuttal. Credit is due to the rare executive willing to defend economic reality and stand up to political intimidation.

article name: Clinton's False Email Equivalence
article text:
A week ago Hillary Clinton's allies accused the State Department Inspector General's office of belonging to the vast right-wing conspiracy. So you have to admire her chutzpah this week in trying to spin a memo from that same office to exonerate her use of a renegade private email server. All the more so because the new memo strengthens the case that she mishandled national secrets.
In Thursday's Democratic debate, Mrs. Clinton hailed a new document from State IG Steve Linick that summarizes his view of the email practices of five prior Secretaries of State. The memo says he found a few instances of "sensitive material" sent to the private email accounts of Republicans Colin Powell and staffers to Condoleezza Rice.
"Now you have these people in the government who are doing the same thing [to Powell and Rice's aides] they've been doing to me," claimed Mrs. Clinton -- that is, "retroactively classifying" documents. "I agree with Secretary Powell, who said today this is an absurdity."
Ah, yes, the old everybody-does-it defense. Mrs. Clinton wants Americans to believe it was common practice for top diplomats to use private email, and that they are all now subject to overzealous interagency squabbling over classification. By Friday Democrats were spinning that Mrs. Clinton is a political victim for having been singled out. Her media phalanx is buying this line, though the Powell and Rice details prove the opposite -- and how reckless Mrs. Clinton was by comparison.
Start with the fact that neither Mr. Powell nor Ms. Rice set up a private email server to conduct government business. Mr. Powell did have a personal email account, but he purposely used a State-maintained classified computer system on his desk for classified communications. This may not have been "convenient" for him, to borrow an earlier Clinton explanation for her private server, but Mr. Powell understood the rules. And he understood them even prior to 2005 when State instituted clear rules warning against private email for official business. Mrs. Rice's aides say she never used any email while at State.
While a few sensitive details may have leeched into a Powell or Rice-aide email account, these would have been accidental. By contrast, Mrs. Clinton intentionally created a private email account, on her own private server, precisely so she could keep those emails away from government public-disclosure rules.
Mr. Linik's review turned up two messages sent to Mr. Powell's account that State now deems sensitive (though Mr. Powell disputes that they should be classified). Mr. Linik found 10 that were sent to Ms. Rice's State Department entourage over her entire tenure. By contrast, State has now deemed that more than 1,600 emails on Mrs. Clinton's server are confidential -- and there is another batch still to be released.
The federal government maintains several levels of classification, ranging from the lowest designations of "sensitive but unclassified" and "confidential" to code-word classifications for the most important secrets. While all such information must be safeguarded, lower-level "sensitive but unclassified" and "confidential" information is sometimes circulated on unclassified government systems. Mr. Powell points out that the two emails sent to him were first circulated on unclassified State Department systems and forwarded to his account by an assistant.
Many of Mrs. Clinton's 1,600 classified emails also fall into these "sensitive" and "confidential" categories. But at least 22 emails have been identified as highly classified from their creation. This means that their information would have resided at all times on classified government systems until they were sent to Mrs. Clinton and her unclassified, unguarded private server. There is no evidence that anything remotely like that happened under Secretaries Powell or Rice.
This transfer question gets to the heart of Mrs. Clinton's email negligence. Sen. Dianne Feinstein is defending Mrs. Clinton by claiming there is no evidence that any of these top secrets emails originated with Secretary Clinton. "It has never made sense to me that Secretary Clinton can be held responsible for email exchanges that originated with someone else," the California Democrat says.
But Mrs. Clinton is responsible because she is the one who created the classification problem by doing official business on her private server. This would never have become an issue if she had followed the rules and used State Department email. That she set up her private email out of a self-serving desire to shield her communications from public disclosure makes her disregard for security a willful act that opens her to criminal liability.
Readers of a certain age will recall that another Clinton tried the everybody-does-it defense when he was found to have broken the law. Are Democrats really going to lash themselves one more time to the Clinton standard of ethics?

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Plans for Tough Caucuses
article text:
MANCHESTER, N.H. -- Hillary Clinton's campaign strategists look at the primary calendar and see possible losses ahead -- not just on Tuesday in New Hampshire, where they are bracing for a double-digit defeat, but in caucus states that typically favor the candidate who draws support from liberal activists.
The key, they say, is not to lose too badly.
Clinton officials say their campaign has been quietly organizing in the coming caucus states such as Minnesota and Colorado, and Mrs. Clinton plans to travel to both later this week. Their goal is to prevent rival Bernie Sanders, the Vermont senator, from running up an advantage in delegates as Barack Obama did in 2008.
The campaign also is making thousands of calls each night into these states, and has loaded them up with staff, believing field organizers are particularly effective in states that require motivating a relatively small number of people to attend what is essentially a Democratic Party meeting.
One of the Clinton campaign's goals is to force Mr. Sanders to spend time in the caucus states that he may think he has in hand, a Clinton aide said, and perhaps have less time in states where Mrs. Clinton has the advantage.
Robby Mook, Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager, also worked on her 2008 campaign, and recalls that Mrs. Clinton won a hard-fought battle in Ohio by 10 percentage points, but because it was a primary state she netted only seven additional delegates over Mr. Obama, then a senator. But in the much smaller Idaho caucuses, Mrs. Clinton barely competed and Mr. Obama won 15 delegates to her 3.
"That can't happen again," Mr. Mook said. "We're building to win these contests but even if we don't win, we need to set it up so we're winning enough delegates to keep our overall delegate lead where it needs to be."
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Clinton's U.N. Candidate?
article text:
Hillary Clinton has made gender a major part of her pitch for the White House, and the idea is catching on. A leading candidate to become the next Secretary-General of the United Nations is a Bulgarian woman with a Communist past and a record unfriendly to U.S. interests who is being promoted by Chelsea Clinton's mother-in-law.
The Bulgarian is 63-year-old Irina Bokova, who since 2009 has run Unesco, the U.N. cultural and social welfare agency. By tradition the top job at the U.N., Secretary-General, rotates by region and it will be Eastern Europe's turn when Ban Ki-moon's term expires at the end of this year. The Bulgarian government may nominate her for the post, which given her U.N. experience would make her the favorite unless significant opposition develops.
Ms. Bokova deserves more scrutiny, not least because of her record at Unesco. Long-time Journal readers will recall that the U.S. withdrew from Unesco in 1984 after years of anti-American agitation. The U.S. rejoined in 2003 saying the agency had reformed.
But in 2011 under Ms. Bokova, Unesco tried to make an end run around the Middle East peace process by admitting the Palestinian Authority as a member state despite U.S. objections. Mrs. Clinton's State Department was then forced by U.S. law to cut off the roughly $80 million in annual U.S. funding for Unesco.
That law reflects Congress's view that U.N. recognition of a Palestinian state before there is a peace deal with Israel encourages the Palestinians to avoid direct negotiations. The cutoff probably stopped other U.N. agencies from recognizing a Palestinian state lest they also lose U.S. funds. But President Obama opposes the funding cutoff and in December asked Congress to reconsider. It declined.
We can't find a record of Mrs. Clinton's views on Unesco funding, but she's no doubt aware of Ms. Bokova, who has participated in Clinton Global Initiative events. Ms. Bokova is also friendly with women's-rights activist Marjorie Margolies, a former Democratic Member of Congress who is a senior fellow at the University of Pennsylvania's Fels Institute of Government -- and Chelsea's mother-in-law. On Tuesday after Ms. Bokova delivers a lecture at the Fels Institute, she and Ms. Margolies will share a stage for a "conversation" and "Q&A" with the audience.
The following day former Ambassador Esther Coopersmith will host a dinner for Ms. Bokova in Washington "to learn more about her candidacy for Secretary General of the United Nations," as the invitation puts it. Washingtonian magazine reported in December 2013 that Ms. Coopersmith "is close to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton."
The Economist reports that Ms. Bokova is also "Russia's preferred candidate." Last year she attended Vladimir Putin's Moscow Victory Day Parade, the biggest military display in Russian history. Most Western leaders refused to attend Mr. Putin's extravaganza in protest over his depredations in Ukraine. But Ms. Bokova was on hand with the likes of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Cuba's Raul Castro.
Ms. Bokova was an active member of the Bulgarian Communist Party in the Cold War era, and her father edited the Party's house organ. She graduated from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations in 1976 when talented students were dispatched to the institute to become good Communist diplomats. And she remained a member of the Communist Party until it changed its name to the Bulgarian Socialist Party.
It's true that the Cold War ended long ago, and many former Communists in the former Warsaw Pact have become democrats in good standing. But authoritarians are again on the march in the world, Mr. Putin chief among them. As U.N. Secretary-General, Ms. Bokova would have global influence and could create trouble for the U.S. All the more so in a Hillary Clinton Administration that would want U.N. approval and consensus for its diplomatic undertakings.
If the next Secretary-General must be a woman from Eastern Europe, there is a better alternative. Kristalina Georgieva is currently a vice president at the European Commission and has worked at the World Bank. Though she isn't our ideal candidate -- her fans include George Soros -- she lacks Ms. Bokova's political baggage. The current center-right government in Sofia might nominate Ms. Georgieva if there's global opposition to Ms. Bokova.
The U.S. role is crucial here. No Secretary-General is likely to be approved if America is actively opposed. Mr. Obama is leaving town in 11 months, and the next President will need a U.N. leader who isn't hostile to American interests. We'd like to know where Mrs. Clinton stands on Ms. Bokova's candidacy, and the House and Senate may want to examine her record in Bulgaria and at Unesco.

article name: Election 2016: Results Point to Clinton's Weaknesses
article text:
Democrats in the first two presidential nominating contests have delivered a clear message to Hillary Clinton about her weaknesses as a candidate. She isn't considered trustworthy, and her message of competence and experience isn't sufficiently compelling.
About a quarter of Iowa's Democratic caucus-goers last week said the quality they most wanted in a nominee was honesty and trustworthiness. Among that group, voter surveys showed, Mrs. Clinton won a mere 10%.
The verdict was more severe in New Hampshire on Tuesday. One-third of voters said they most wanted honesty in a nominee, and Mrs. Clinton carried 5% of those voters.
The results in part reflect the months of controversy Mrs. Clinton generated by using a private email system during her time as secretary of state, questions about her family's charitable foundation, as well as speaking fees she earned from Wall Street firms that are a favorite target of liberal Democrats.
Mrs. Clinton left the Obama administration in early 2013 with a positive image, Wall Street Journal/NBC News polling shows. But by last month, some 40% of registered voters viewed her unfavorably while a larger share -- 49% -- saw her in a negative light.
The results from Iowa and New Hampshire also signaled that Mrs. Clinton has yet to fashion an argument for her candidacy as powerful as the liberal vision laid out by Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont. A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders promises to end a "corrupt" campaign-finance system that he says allows the wealthy and Wall Street buy influence and rig the economy in their favor.
Mrs. Clinton also has laid out liberal goals, but her candidacy also rests on her long experience in public life and the argument that she would make the stronger general election candidate. In New Hampshire, however, Democratic primary voters said they most wanted a nominee who was "honest" and "cares about people like me."
Some 60% of voters chose one of those two qualities, exit polls showed, and Mr. Sanders carried both groups by lopsided margins.
By contrast, 38% said experience or the ability to win in November was the most important quality in a nominee. Mrs. Clinton won those groups by large margins, exit polls showed.
Mr. Sanders's message is exciting his core supporters more than Mrs. Clinton is energizing her base. She carried her strongest voting group, women age 45 and older, by seven percentage points in New Hampshire, 53% to 46%, exit polls showed.
Mr. Sanders, by contrast, posted prohibitively large margins among the groups that most responded to his message. Some three-quarters of Democratic primary voters under age 45 backed him in New Hampshire, including 83% of voters under 30.
Young women, who many presumed would be part of the Clinton coalition, are instead turning to Mr. Sanders. He carried women under age 45 by 40 percentage points in New Hampshire, 69% to 29%.
While Iowa and New Hampshire proved to be unexpectedly difficult tests for Mrs. Clinton, the race now moves to states that could prove to be friendlier terrain. The first contests took place in two of the most liberal and least racially diverse states in the nation. Next come states with larger shares of minority and centrist voters, who in opinion surveys have favored Mrs. Clinton.
Credit: By Aaron Zitner

article name: Trump, Sanders Roll in N.H. --- Clinton Defeat Prompts Retooling
article text:
MANCHESTER, N.H. -- Bernie Sanders soundly defeated Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, propelled by independents and young voters wary about the economy and skeptical that the next generation of Americans will live a better life.
Once considered a fringe candidate who stood little chance against Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont senator pulled off a sweeping victory. With more than half of New Hampshire's precincts reporting, Mr. Sanders had 60% of the vote compared with 39% for Mrs. Clinton. The Associated Press called the race for Mr. Sanders at 8 p.m. ET.
Mr. Sanders defeated Mrs. Clinton among women and swept all age categories except voters over 65, surveys of voters as they exited polling precincts showed. The result underscored the appeal of Mr. Sanders's argument that billionaire families and powerful companies are rigging the economy against the American middle class.
At the same time, Mrs. Clinton's defeat suggested that her central message isn't resonating and that she can't count on voters to choose her because of her years of experience as a first lady, senator and secretary of state. Only 27% of Democratic voters said it was important that candidates have the "right experience," exit surveys showed.
Mr. Sanders, in his victory speech, told supporters they had sent a message that would echo from Wall Street to Washington. "The government of our great country belongs to all of the people, and not just wealthy campaign contributors and their super PACs," he said.
Mr. Sanders, whose win Tuesday was powered by high turnout, predicted that result would be repeated across the nation.
Mrs. Clinton, who won the New Hampshire primary in 2008, declared that, "I still love New Hampshire and I always will." And seeking to use the defeat to show she is a fighter, she promised to take the battle to other states and said, "It is not whether you get knocked down that matters, it is whether you get back up."
Even before the primary, Mrs. Clinton began retooling her message and said she would reexamine her campaign strategy in hopes of blunting Mr. Sanders's momentum.
Mr. Sanders made deep inroads with voters outside the mainstream of Democratic politics. About 40% of those taking part in the Democratic primary were independents, and Mr. Sanders prevailed among those by a commanding 72% to 27%, the exit polls showed. The two candidates split self-identified Democrats evenly, according to the polls.
Voters were clearly receptive to Mr. Sanders's populist message. Only 27% described themselves as politically moderate, while 69% called themselves liberal -- a dynamic that could change as the race moves to states with more centrist Democratic voters.
Asked if the economic system in America favors the wealthy, 90% of Democratic voters said yes, the exit polls showed. And by a margin of nearly 4 to 1, voters said they trusted Mr. Sanders more than Mrs. Clinton to deal with income inequality.
Lisa Colavito, a nurse from Concord, said she voted for Mr. Sanders "because we need to get the money out of politics." She added, "He's a grassroots candidate, he stands by his word, and he's been consistent."
Ms. Colavito said she wasn't persuaded by the prospect that Mrs. Clinton could be the first female president. "I just want a person that's good for the job," she said.
Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had expected her to be in a stronger position at this point in the race, people familiar with their thinking said.
One person familiar with internal discussions said that inside the Clinton campaign, there is debate over two points. The first is how hard Mrs. Clinton herself should attack Mr. Sanders. Among those advocating a sharper tone is her husband, who himself went after Mr. Sanders in sharp terms last weekend.
The second question is whether she should reshape the way she describes her vision, away from the policy-heavy speeches she is most comfortable with, where she projects herself as an effective pragmatist, and toward a more lofty, visionary message.
Mrs. Clinton's aides, at her election-night gathering, said that in coming weeks she would emphasize social-justice issues, going beyond what they see as Mr. Sanders's narrower focus on economic justice.
Next up for the Democrats are caucuses in Nevada, a state with more minority voters than Iowa or New Hampshire. That would give Mrs. Clinton, who has wide support in minority communities, a chance to rebound and demonstrate that she has more broad-based national support than the senator from Vermont.
First, though, she needs to come up with a more compelling rationale for her candidacy, many Clinton allies say. While Mrs. Clinton has put forward a mix of policy proposals, her supporters say he has yet to lay out a succinct explanation of why she wants to be president.
By contrast, Mr. Sanders has steadily gained ground with a message that is apparently resonating with young voters in particular: Billionaires and powerful corporations are corrupting the political system and making it harder for middle-class Americans to get ahead.
Now, campaign aides say, Mrs. Clinton is beginning to give voice to a message that is more positive, personal and even spiritual, talking about concepts like gratitude and the need to move forward in life.
"The problem is that she needs an overarching message other than 'I'm almost as far left as Bernie but not quite,' " said Douglas Schoen, a former adviser to Mr. Clinton. "She has to answer the basic question of why she wants to be president. So far she hasn't done that."
In the run-up to Tuesday's New Hampshire balloting, both Mrs. Clinton and her husband have suggested they are open to a course correction.
The ex-president is frustrated by his wife's slow start and unhappy she isn't polling better with female voters, people familiar with his thinking said. In an interview with MSNBC on the eve of the primary, Mrs. Clinton said: "Of course it would be malpractice not to say, 'OK, what worked? What can we do better? What do we have to do new and different that we have to pull out?' "
But Mrs. Clinton's experience makes it challenging for her to present a sweeping vision for change, something for which voters have shown an appetite.
Mrs. Clinton had what her aides saw as a revealing and helpful moment at a CNN forum last week, where she was asked by a rabbi how she balances the need to make a difference in the world and the need for humility.
She replied with a nuanced, spiritual and personal explanation of the need to practice what she called "the discipline of gratitude."
"So regardless of how hard the days are, how difficult the decisions are, be grateful," she said. "Be grateful for being a human being, being part of the universe. Be grateful for your limitations. Know that you have to reach out to have more people be with you, to support you, to advise you. Listen to your critics, answer the questions."
Her aides are keen to find ways to incorporate those types of thoughts into her speeches, and over the course of the past several days, in fits and starts, a new message emerged.
Still, with Mrs. Clinton having been on the national stage for a quarter century, it isn't clear that voters who have been cool to her will give her a second look.
Mike Perry, a resident of Laconia, N.H., said Tuesday he planned to cast his vote for Mr. Sanders. "I like what he's offering," he said. "He wants to make changes, and that's what I want to hear."
Mr. Perry said he didn't want to elaborate about his feelings about Mrs. Clinton, but that he strongly believed she wasn't the right candidate for the job. "I don't like her," he said. "I just don't."
---
Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Seeks to Maximize Her Support Among Blacks
article text:
DENMARK, S.C. -- Hillary Clinton is running to end "the cruelest kind of indifference" to those left behind in America, she said during a visit to a poor rural community here, which also is home to one of rival Bernie Sanders's best-known black supporters in this critical primary state.
At a town-hall meeting at Denmark-Olar Elementary School, Mrs. Clinton sought to draw attention to underfunded schools that are emblematic of a system that refuses to see the "left behind and left out."
It is "fundamentally wrong" that the state had still not resolved a funding lawsuit filed 20 years ago by some of the local school districts, where building walls are crumbling, rooms are molding, roofs are collapsing, Mrs. Clinton said.
"If the schools had been falling apart in rich suburbs of Columbia or Charleston, we wouldn't still be talking about it," she said. "I'm running for president to break down all the barriers that stand in the way of people achieving their dreams."
Denmark, in rural Bamberg County, is normally not a hotspot for presidential visits; it has a population of 3,300 and shrinking, is more than 85% black and has a household median income less than half the national average.
Mrs. Clinton's visit to Denmark is part of an effort to maximize her historic strength among black voters when pitted against Mr. Sanders in the Feb. 27 Democratic primary.
Black voters are expected to make up more than half of the primary electorate here, and Mrs. Clinton is relying on a victory here to regain momentum after her narrow win in the Iowa caucuses and big loss in New Hampshire.
Mrs. Clinton was once thought to have a lock on the primary here. But in the past few weeks, some prominent black preachers and legislators here have come out in support of Mr. Sanders, including local Bamberg Rep. Justin Bamberg, who formerly endorsed Mrs. Clinton but switched to Mr. Sanders because of his focus on criminal-justice issues.
Mr. Bamberg, a 28-year-old first-term legislator, said he was trying not to take the visit personally. He said that he hoped Mrs. Clinton's visit to the school drew attention to the recent closing of two area hospitals, as well as to a lack of jobs.
Bakari Sellers, a 31-year-old CNN political commentator who formerly held Mr. Bamberg's legislative seat, introduced Mrs. Clinton at the rally. In an interview, he said her visit had nothing to do with Mr. Bamberg.
Mr. Sellers said that Mrs. Clinton has been working on behalf of the people of Bamberg before either he or Mr. Bamberg was born. Mrs. Clinton came to Bamberg County once before -- as a lawyer in the 1970s working with incarcerated teenagers for the Children's Defense Fund.
Her work on issues related to the poor and minorities is a primary reason the Congressional Black Caucus in Washington endorsed Mrs. Clinton this week. But some Sanders backers bristle at the expectation that black voters should get in lock-step.
Joe Neal, a Columbia pastor and former head of the Legislative Black Caucus, said that he is campaigning for Mr. Sanders because of his stance on mass incarceration, the minimum wage and income inequality.
Credit: By Valerie Bauerlein

article name: Clinton's Negative Majority; She's getting more unpopular the longer the campaign goes on.
article text:
Hillary Clinton won New York's primary Tuesday, which means that barring an act of God or FBI director Jim Comey--they aren't the same--she will be the Democratic nominee for President. So Democrats should be alarmed by the former first lady's rising unpopularity.
The latest evidence comes in the new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll taken April 10-14. A regular feature of this survey asks voters about their "feelings toward" certain individuals or institutions--whether they are very positive, somewhat positive, neutral, somewhat negative or very negative. In April the poll found Mrs. Clinton hitting a dubious new record of 56% who have somewhat or very negative feelings toward her. Only 32% have a positive view.
As striking is the negative trend over the last three years. In Jan. 2013, not long after she left President Obama's cabinet, her net negative was 25%. As the nearby chart shows, her unpopularity has since climbed with only occasional exceptions. She broke through negative 40% in the middle of last year, and she hit negative 50% in February. In April a remarkable 42% had a very negative view of the woman Democrats are counting on to hold the White House.
Some of this is explainable by the pounding any candidate takes during a campaign. Bernie Sanders has been portraying Mrs. Clinton as a tool of the big banks, even if he's ducked her serious ethical problems. But what should worry Democrats is that Bill Clinton's wife has been a national political figure since 1992, and her political identity is well known and will be hard to change.
All of which means Republicans should be poised to retake the White House in November if they nominate someone remotely tolerable. Yet they may not. Donald Trump reinforced his GOP front-runner status Tuesday with a blowout victory in his home state of New York, but his negative rating in the WSJ/NBC survey is an astounding 65%. Ted Cruz is disliked by 49%, though he's less well known, with 21% having a neutral view. The Texan finished a distant third in New York to John Kasich.
Hard to believe, but Messrs. Trump and Cruz may be the only two Republicans who could lose to Hillary Clinton.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Courts African-American Voters --- Former senator offers plans for schools, jobs and a criminal-justice overhaul proposal
article text:
Hillary Clinton, relying heavily on black voters in her battle for the Democratic presidential nomination, vowed Tuesday to address racial disparities in the nation's economy, criminal-justice system, health and schools.
In a speech delivered in New York City's Harlem neighborhood, a historic center of black culture, the former New York senator delivered a few barbs at rival Bernie Sanders, saying the U.S. isn't a "single-issue country" and that breaking up the big banks, as he proposes, isn't enough to address joblessness, problems some blacks have in obtaining mortgages or the epidemic of gun violence.
"These are not only problems of economic inequality, these are problems of racial inequality," she said. "We have to say that loudly and clearly."
Tuesday's address was the latest effort by Mrs. Clinton to explicitly court black voters. She has touted endorsements by high-profile black leaders and campaigned alongside Rep. John Lewis, a hero of the civil-rights movement. She has lamented troubling statistics about minorities via her Twitter feed and has repeatedly talked about, and traveled to, the majority black city of Flint, Mich., where a cost-savings move wound up poisoning the water supply with lead.
"Despite our best efforts and our highest hopes, America's long struggle with race is far from finished," she told the largely African-American audience at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.
She offered a new proposal aimed at ending the "school-to-prison pipeline" by overhauling school discipline procedures and touted a string of other ideas. They include a criminal-justice overhaul, universal preschool, making it easier for ex-prisoners to re-enter society upon release and $125 billion to revitalize underserved communities, including money for youth jobs and to aid small businesses.
Earlier in the day, Mrs. Clinton met with the Rev. Al Sharpton and the heads of major civil-rights organizations. Mr. Sharpton, who met last week with Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton's Democratic challenger, wouldn't say whom he might endorse, saying the only one who knows is Mrs. Clinton. "My lips are sealed!" she said with a smile.
Given her failure to decisively win the Iowa caucuses and her loss to Mr. Sanders in New Hampshire, combined with the excitement her opponent is generating among many voters, Mrs. Clinton's ability to keep African-Americans in the fold may determine whether she is able to win the nomination.
Black voters make up a majority of the electorate in South Carolina, which votes Feb. 27, and in a string of Southern states that follow.
In her speech Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton suggested Mr. Sanders was a latecomer to the cause.
"You know, you can't just show up at election time and say the right things and think that's enough. We can't start building relationships a few weeks before a vote," she said.
She pointed to her own work as a young lawyer on behalf of poor children and asked African-American voters to hold her accountable "not just when the cameras are on. . .but every single day."
Her proposal for schools is aimed at dissuading them from suspending students and referring them to law enforcement, which can set them up for future problems. She proposed $2 billion to hire guidance counselors, social workers and others at schools with particularly high rates of suspensions and in-school arrests. The teams would be charged with working with at-risk students and training teachers to resolve conflicts internally.
Mr. Sanders is hardly conceding black voters. On Monday, he met with families from Flint and spoke at a large rally about his anger and sadness at the stories he heard. On Thursday, he plans to meet with civil-rights leaders in Washington.
On Tuesday, the Sanders campaign released a two-minute TV ad featuring Erica Garner, daughter of Eric Garner, a New York man who died after being choked by New York police officers. He also campaigned in South Carolina, attending a prayer breakfast at Allen University in Columbia, a historically black college.
Mr. Sanders recounted his participation in the March on Washington as a student and a recent visit to Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church, site of the 1963 bombing that killed four young black girls. He said blacks were disproportionately affected by income inequality, an overzealous criminal-justice system, lack of health care and curbs on voting.
---
Valerie Bauerlein and Mara Gay contributed to this article.
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Bill Clinton Pitches Wife's Record To Voters Ahead of South Carolina
article text:
GREENVILLE, S.C. -- A subdued Bill Clinton pitched his wife's record to black voters she needs to keep and millennials she would like to win back during a 40-minute speech Tuesday, marking one of his first appearances in the state since he was criticized for comments about then-Sen. Barack Obama in 2008.
Mr. Clinton said he understood that many young voters were attracted to Sen. Bernie Sanders, without mentioning him by name, for his promises of free college. He said there was a "bumper sticker campaign" that said big banks were the problem, acknowledging a frequent attack on Hillary Clinton that she is too cozy with Wall Street.
"A lot of these millennials are supporting the opponent, and I think they're making a mistake, because he's supporting free college," he said, adding that many people hadn't felt the economic recovery yet. "You've got working people saying, what about me? You got millennials and college students saying, what about me?"
He argued that Mrs. Clinton had shown the ability to make progress on issues like health care and education, distinguishing her from Mr. Sanders because she could negotiate with Republicans and had served as secretary of state.
He hailed the removal of the Confederate flag after a mass shooting in Charleston last summer, praised Rep. Jim Clyburn, the state's only black member of Congress, lauded Mr. Obama and called for changes to the country's police force and prison system.
Mrs. Clinton has faced a strong challenge from Mr. Sanders, who is working to pull away black supporters in South Carolina while also making inroads at colleges.
Back in 2008, Mr. Clinton drew criticism for calling Mr. Obama's campaign a "fairy tale" and comparing his run to that of Jesse Jackson, who won South Carolina in 1984 and 1988 but fell short of the Democratic nomination. Mr. Obama won the state's 2008 primary by nearly 20 points.
Credit: By Josh Dawsey

article name: Election 2016: Democrats Vie for Nevada's Minorities --- Clinton and Sanders seek to mobilize nonwhite voters as caucuses near
article text:
LAS VEGAS -- Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders will face his biggest test so far in his run for the White House this week, when voters in one of the most ethnically and racially diverse states will make their choice in the Democratic presidential conteston Saturday.
Nevada -- a sprawling Western state with important blocs of Latino, black and Asian-American voters -- is the next stop for Mr. Sanders and Hillary Clinton. For Mr. Sanders, a win in the Silver State would be an opportunity to show he has appeal among the nonwhite voters who make up a significant part of the Democratic electorate. He has long trailed Mrs. Clinton in the polls among black and Hispanic voters. For Mrs. Clinton, a win here would be an important show of force and bolster her argument that she can put together a winning coalition against a Republican nominee.
"We're going to get a good sense of what Latinos, African-Americans, and Asians are thinking. Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are working tirelessly to reach out to these communities," said Ruben Kihuen, a Nevada state senator running for U.S. Congress and a supporter of Mrs. Clinton.
The state is more than a quarter Latino and has a sizable black population. It also has a large Asian-American community, the fastest-growing minority group in the country. Non-Hispanic whites now represent less than half of the population of Las Vegas.
The state's diversity and the increasingly close battle between the two Democratic candidates have set off a fierce fight to persuade and mobilize nonwhite voters. Two Nevada polls this month show the contest in a dead heat, though the state is traditionally difficult to survey effectively.
Mrs. Clinton's campaign brought in Rep. John Lewis, a civil-rights icon and a longtime Democratic member of Congress from Georgia to help boost turnout among the black community. He made his case for Mrs. Clinton at several campaign stops this week, including at a historically black church and a community center in a low-income neighborhood. "I'm going to continue to travel as long as there's a campaign," said Mr. Lewis, calling Mrs. Clinton the best-prepared candidate to be president.
The campaign also has brought in Dolores Huerta, a civil-rights leader and labor activist who co-founded the National Farm Workers Association with Cesar Chavez in the 1960s. The campaign is on television in Spanish and has hosted events in Spanish aimed at familiarizing Latino voters with the caucus process.
Mr. Sanders's campaign has been equally aggressive, particularly in the Latino community. The campaign brought Mr. Chavez's nephew, Federico Chavez as a surrogate. The campaign is dispatching a group of illegal immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children to knock on doors across the state. The campaign is on television with an endorsement from Lucy Flores, a former state legislator running for U.S. Congress.
Both candidates attended church services Sunday at a large historically black church in Las Vegas and addressed the congregation.
"I am not a single-issue candidate and this is not a single-issue country," Mrs. Clinton said, referring to Mr. Sanders's sharp focus on Wall Street and campaign-finance issues. "Because if we were going to achieve everything about banks and money and politics, would that end racism?"
Sanders campaign state director Joan Kato said they are ceding no ground. "We're doing outreach in all those communities," she said.
Mrs. Clinton's campaign strategy relies on maintaining her well of support with nonwhite voters after her narrow win in Iowa and big loss in New Hampshire. Both of those states are whiter and more rural than the country at large.
Still, her campaign began lowering expectations ahead of the caucuses here. "There's an important Hispanic element to the Democratic caucus in Nevada. But it's still a state that is 80% white voters," campaign spokesman Brian Fallon said on MSNBC after New Hampshire.
The comment drew a rebuke from Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid. Mr. Reid told reporters on Tuesday that he had complained to the Clinton campaign about the comment. Mrs. Clinton later rejected the comment in a television interview.
Steven Horsford, a Democrat who was the first black Congressman from Nevada and former majority leader of the state senate, said the explicit racial appeals may not work among younger nonwhite voters who are looking for a more comprehensive agenda. Mr. Horsford, now a Washington, D.C., marketing consultant, was voted out of office amid a Republican wave in Nevada in 2014.
"Both campaigns have more work to do to speak to a broad constituency and not put everybody in categories -- all African-American voters are not the same," said Mr. Horsford, who hasn't endorsed a candidate.


Enlarge this image.

Credit: By Byron Tau and Alexandra Berzon

article name: Brush Up Your Shakespeare; A global approval rating Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton can only envy.
article text:
Four hundred years after William Shakespeare departed this earth, and notwithstanding efforts by the politically correct to banish him from university curricula, this Dead White Englishman remains a global figure of astonishing vitality.
That's not surprising, given his contributions to an English language that is the dominant tongue in today's world. Millions who have never read "Richard III" or witnessed a performance of "The Merchant of Venice" would be shocked to learn that many phrases they use every day ("give the devil his due," "brave new world," "eaten me out of house and home," "wild goose chase," "bated breath," "a foregone conclusion," etc.) originated with or were popularized by the Bard of Avon.
But more than English speakers have reason to be grateful. If a British Council survey of 18,000 people across 15 countries is to be believed, Shakespeare is more appreciated by those in the developing nations (Brazilians, Chinese, Mexicans, Indians and Turks) than by his fellow British. Across the globe he boasts a favorability rating--76% of those surveyed said they liked him--that Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton can only envy.
Shakespeare has also turned out to be a solid economic asset, directly as a draw for tourism, and indirectly for giving foreigners a positive introduction to Britain. As the British Council report puts it, his popularity continues to be "an important asset for the UK's prosperity and soft power."
Why the enduring, global popularity? The answer is simple. Though Shakespeare was a man who lived in England at a particular time, so well do his plays and poems capture the human condition that they speak to all people at all times. Which makes him as relevant in our world as he was in his own. We'd even go so far as to predict that Shakespeare will survive this era's progressive academic attempts to purge him for the sin of being the wrong race and gender.

article name: Trump, Clinton Power Ahead --- Democrat's Big Night Widens Her Imposing Lead Over Sanders
article text:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton won critical presidential primaries in the industrial Midwest and completed her sweep of the South on Tuesday, as she took full command of a contest that has been far more competitive than expected at the start.
Rival Bernie Sanders was still hoping to win a close contest in Missouri, but that seemed nowhere near enough to change the dynamic of the race. Mrs. Clinton won in Ohio, Illinois, Florida and North Carolina, and blunted Mr. Sanders's momentum from a win last week in Michigan. She widened her already formidable delegate lead and made it improbable he can catch up.
"We are moving close to securing the Democratic Party nomination and winning this election in November," the former secretary of state and New York senator told cheering supporters in Florida, boasting that she has won more votes than any candidate in either party.
She took a swipe at Mr. Sanders, saying he should be more specific about his plans, but she lodged a wholesale indictment of Republican front-runner Donald Trump. "When we hear a candidate for president call for rounding up 12 million immigrants, banning all Muslims from entering the United States, when he embraces torture -- that doesn't make him strong. It makes him wrong," she said.
With 214 pledged delegates at stake, Florida was the night's biggest prize, while Illinois had 156 pledged delegates and Ohio 143 up for grabs. They will be awarded proportionally.
Heading into Tuesday, Mr. Sanders was ramping up his attacks on Mrs. Clinton, and has vowed to fight all the way to the summer convention. But he may now face increasing pressure to back off and revert to his earlier role as a candidate primarily driving a progressive, populist message rather than pursuing a viable path to the nomination.
At his election night rally in Arizona Tuesday night, though, Mr. Sanders showed no signs of backing off. He pointed to Wall Street contributions to the super PAC supporting Mrs. Clinton and repeated his call that she release transcripts of her high-priced speeches to Wall Street firms.
"To my mind, if you're going to give a speech for $225,000 it must be a really great speech," he said. "And if it's such a great speech, all of America should be able to read it."
With nearly all precincts counted, Mrs. Clinton topped Mr. Sanders by 64.5% to 33% in Florida, by 54.5% to 41% in North Carolina and by 56.5% to 42.7% in Ohio.
In Illinois, her margin was much closer, some 50.5% to 48.7% with 94% of precincts reporting.
Mrs. Clinton had been expected to easily win Florida, with the state's demographics and rules barring independents from participating helping her. But Ohio was closely fought, and Mr. Sanders had hoped to parlay a victory last week in Michigan to the neighboring state. Both have seen a drain in manufacturing jobs, and Mr. Sanders put the blame squarely on free-trade agreements that Mrs. Clinton has long supported.
Mrs. Clinton completed a sweep of the South, where strong support from African-Americans pumped up her totals. But her Ohio win was more important, showing she could win in the industrial Midwest.
After Tuesday's vote, Mrs. Clinton was assured of adding at least 253 delegates to her column, bringing her total pledged delegates, who are chosen by the voters, to more than 1,000. Mr. Sanders was sure to add at least 124 delegates, but he was on track to end the night more than 300 delegates behind. Including superdelegates, who can vote for any candidate they like, her total topped 1,400, more than double his.
At roughly the halfway point of the race, Sanders advisers say they now have the advantage. His campaign now looks ahead to contests next week in Arizona, Utah and Idaho, three states where aides have hoped to do well. But the next big delegate hauls aren't awarded until April: first in Wisconsin, and then the giant prize of New York, where Mrs. Clinton lives and which she represented in the Senate for eight years.
In Florida, Mrs. Clinton's advantage was on display Tuesday in Miami, home to large populations of Hispanic and African-American voters who have gravitated to her campaign.
"I like that she's a smart, charismatic woman," said Bridgette Thornton, a 37-year-old African-American attorney, who cast her ballot at a Miami church. "It was a difficult choice for me, but I'm a practical person. Hillary has a better shot at winning the presidential election."
The race was closer in Ohio, where Mr. Sanders hammered his anti-free-trade views in recent days. Mrs. Clinton tried to recast her trade message, but the attempt fell flat with at least some voters.
"The Clinton history with trade policies, that really just killed our area," said Fred Woke, a 57-year-old radio announcer who voted for Mr. Sanders in Niles.
The challenge for both Democrats is that Mr. Trump, should he win the Republican nomination, would be an unconventional opponent who could pick up some of Mr. Sanders's populist arguments.
That has some Clinton backers anxious for Mr. Sanders to ease up. "The message of Sanders campaign has become personal attacks," said Robert Zimmerman, a superdelegate from New York who backs Mrs. Clinton. "It's not only wrong, it's dangerous politically if he keeps up that tone."
Steve Elmendorf, a consultant who backs Mrs. Clinton, agreed there will come a point when Mr. Sanders needs to let up, but he said it isn't for Clinton supporters to say when. "When it becomes clear you cannot win, then you should unite behind the nominee of the party and try to beat the Republicans," Mr. Elmendorf said. "It's for him to decide when he can't win."
In 2008, Mrs. Clinton continued to compete in presidential-primary contests against then-Sen. Barack Obama even though he remained ahead in the delegate race the entire time.
"Even if he doesn't think he will win the nomination, he's trying to amass as many delegates as he can," said Joe Trippi, a Democratic strategist. Delegates would give Mr. Sanders leverage at the party's convention and demonstrate the strength of his movement, Mr. Trippi said, adding, "I don't see him relenting."
Steve Schale, a Democratic consultant in Florida who voted for Mrs. Clinton, said he doesn't worry that the Sanders attacks will damage her, partly because Democrats are sure to unify if Mr. Trump is the nominee. "You want to get Democrats over the Sanders-Clinton thing, give them five seconds to think about Trump being within five feet of the nuclear codes," Mr. Schale said.
---
Arian Campo-Flores and Heather Haddon contributed to this article.
(See related article: "GOP Front-Runner Knocks Out Rubio, but Kasich Hangs Onto Ohio" -- WSJ March 16, 2016)
Credit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Trump, Clinton Power Ahead --- GOP Front-Runner Knocks Out Rubio, but Kasich Hangs Onto Ohio
article text:
Donald Trump scored victories in the Republican presidential primaries Tuesday, winning Florida, the biggest delegate prize of the night, and driving home-state Sen. Marco Rubio out of the race.
Mr. Trump also won in North Carolina and Illinois. But Ohio Gov. John Kasich prevailed in his home state. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz was battling Mr. Trump in a tight race in Missouri, slowing the front-runner's pace toward the GOP nomination.
In his victory speech to supporters in Palm Beach, Fla., Mr. Trump vowed that his candidacy would broaden the reach of the Republican Party.
"We have a great opportunity," he said. "Democrats are coming in. Independents are coming in, and, more important, people who have never voted before."
Still, by defeating Mr. Rubio on his home turf, Mr. Trump dashed the hopes of Republican leaders who saw the young, Cuban-American senator as their best messenger to broaden the party's appeal.
Mr. Kasich, a two-term governor and former congressman, is left as the only representative of a GOP leadership wary of the combative Mr. Cruz and openly hostile toward Mr. Trump.
Tuesday's muddled results will make it harder for Mr. Trump to earn the 1,237 delegates he needs to claim the nomination before the Republican convention in July.
"What we all thought would never happen -- a convention fight -- now has a better-than-even chance of occurring," said Republican pollster Neil Newhouse, who advised a super PAC backing former candidate Jeb Bush. "We haven't seen a presidential election like this before, and we're unlikely to see one like it again."
Mr. Kasich's win in Ohio was his first of the GOP race, and it offers him a tenuous lifeline.
"The campaign goes on," he told supporters in Cleveland, the site of the GOP convention in July. "We're going to go all the way . . . and secure the Republican nomination."
Mr. Rubio emerged shortly after polls closed to announce that he was ending his campaign. He said his campaign was ill-timed for a year dominated by anger and resentment. "While we are on the right side, this year we will not be on the winning side," Mr. Rubio said. "While this may not have been the year for a hopeful and optimistic message about our future, I remain hopeful and optimistic about America."
It was a day of reckoning for the GOP leadership, which had targeted the winner-take-all contests in Ohio and Florida as the best chance to slow the New York businessman's momentum. Anti-Trump groups have plowed more than $35 million into attack ads, with the biggest share, $16 million, airing in Florida, according to Federal Election Commission reports.
Mr. Trump scored an early win on Tuesday in the Republican caucuses on the Northern Mariana Islands and was expected to earn all nine of the territory's delegates. More than half of the total delegates to the Republican convention will have been awarded once votes in Ohio, Florida, Missouri, Illinois and North Carolina are tallied on Tuesday.
Before Tuesday's votes, Mr. Trump had earned 460 delegates, compared with Mr. Cruz's 370. Mr. Rubio was in third place with 163 and Mr. Kasich had 63.
Florida will award Mr. Trump all of its 99 delegates, while Ohio will give Mr. Kasich its 66 delegates.
Mr. Cruz aimed to upset Mr. Trump in Missouri, which has 52 delegates, and was positioned to pick up a share of the 72 delegates in North Carolina and 69 delegates in Illinois. He also campaigned in Ohio and Florida in recent days with the hope of siphoning votes from Mr. Kasich and Mr. Rubio, and landing a coveted one-on-one match-up against the New York businessman in the remaining primaries. Yet Tuesday's results likely mean the best Mr. Trump's rivals can hope for is a contested convention.
In a speech to supporters in his hometown of Houston, Mr. Cruz said Rubio supporters should join his campaign now that their candidate had dropped out. "Starting tomorrow morning there is a clear choice," he said. "We welcome you with open and welcoming arms."
Meanwhile, Mr. Trump, with a Tuesday call to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.), is sending signals he is ready to step into the role of presumptive nominee.
"We had a good conversation," Mr. McConnell said. The senator said he raised the issue of physical violence at Mr. Trump's rallies and said he told Mr. Trump: "It might be a good idea to condemn that . . . no matter what the source."
Mr. Trump's continued rise comes despite harsh condemnations from the last two GOP nominees, former Gov. Mitt Romney and Sen. John McCain. The GOP establishment has appeared powerless in the face of the pro-Trump populist uprising. And a convention nomination fight could provoke a backlash from his supporters and deepen divisions within the Republican Party.
"That could be very self-destructive for Republicans," said Bill Nojay, a New York lawmaker and leading Trump supporter in his own state. "Do we want to waste time fighting among ourselves, or unify behind Mr. Trump and focus on what's important, which is beating Hillary Clinton?""
In a sign that some Republicans are resigned to Mr. Trump being the nominee, a new super PAC was launched Tuesday to try to protect GOP majorities in Congress at a time when Mr. Trump's inflammatory rhetoric is tainting the party's image, according to the group's founders.
As voters went to the polls Tuesday, the Conservative Bridge super PAC began sending fundraising emails to millions of Republicans around the country. Unlike other groups formed in response to Mr. Trump's rise, Conservative Bridge is not trying to intervene in the presidential race. Instead, the group is acting preemptively to try to boost vulnerable Republicans in down-ballot races with an untested candidate like Mr. Trump at the top of the ticket.
"We are operating on the assumption that Donald Trump will be the presidential nominee," said Arizona-based political consultant Bert Coleman, who is among four Republicans at the new group's helm.
"We think the presidential campaign as a whole, in particular Trump's harsh rhetoric, has damaged the Republican brand, and the name of the game is now turning out Republican voters in November."
Earlier on Tuesday, Mr. Kasich said that he plans to offer more detailed critiques of Mr. Trump's policies and conduct in the campaign.
Mr. Kasich told reporters after voting Tuesday morning in his hometown of Westerville that he would be "forced going forward to talk about the way this campaign has been run by some others, by one other in particular."
"But today is not the day to do that," added Mr. Kasich, who has avoided negative attacks.
Mr. Kasich is scheduled to campaign on Wednesday in Pennsylvania, though a Rubio supporter is challenging his spot on the April 26 ballot in court. He is also planning to stump in Utah on Friday ahead of its March 22 caucuses.
The face-off between Mr. Kasich and Mr. Trump in Ohio was a particularly pointed test of whether the 2016 GOP electorate could be persuaded to support an experienced, accomplished politician in spite of widespread disgust with party-establishment leaders.
Mr. Kasich's victory came in spite of the fact that many constituents were attracted to Mr. Trump's anti-establishment siren call.
"I'm sick of the establishment, both Democrats and Republicans, they're screwing the U.S. citizens, shipping our work overseas," said Trump voter Rex Bailey, 64 years old, a Mansfield, Ohio, resident who said he was laid off from his job as a telephone company engineer in January.
"Kasich is OK, but he's still part of the establishment."
---
Reid J. Epstein and Patrick O'Connor contributed to this article.
(See related article: "Democrat's Big Night Widens Her Imposing Lead Over Sanders" -- WSJ March 16, 2016)
Credit: By Beth Reinhard and Janet Hook

article name: Election 2016: Early Voting Likely to Boost Trump, Clinton
article text:
Early voting in the Super Tuesday states is likely to give yet another boost to the candidacies of front runners Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton, according to campaign veterans and political scientists.
That's because of the characteristics of early voters. The most passionately committed supporters tend to cast their ballots early. African-Americans vote early in disproportionate numbers. And many early voters are wasted because candidates drop out after the voters have cast their ballots. So all the voters who cast absentee ballots for former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush -- a fierce critic of Mr. Trump -- aren't available for other candidates to scoop up.
