Apply all these factors to the current race, experts say, and the edge goes to the front-runners.
In the case of Mr. Trump, his supporters tend to be those who make up their mind early. According to entrance polls in New Hampshire and South Carolina, 58% of Mr. Trump's voters said they decided to cast their votes for him over a month before Election Day. In Nevada, 55% of Trump voters decided at least a week before the election.
Early voting gives such voters a way to express their fealty, says University of Florida political scientist Daniel Smith, an early-voting specialist.
"Donald Trump may be banking early votes through absentee ballots and early voting," he said. "That's good for Donald Trump, especially if the anti-Trump forces start to coalesce and bring him down."
In Mrs. Clinton's case, her strength with black voters gives her an early-voting edge. On Friday, she spoke at a rally at Atlanta City Hall. After the event, her volunteers phoned voters to get them to cast their ballots that day, the last day of the early-voting period.
Among the many unknowns, though, is whether the early votes that a candidate banks before Tuesday will add to the contender's totals or simply shift the day on which the candidate receives the votes he or she was already going to get.
Among the Super Tuesday states, Virginia, Alabama and Massachusetts sharply restrict early voting, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. There, supporters can't cast votes early at a polling station and must provide specific reasons why they need to use absentee ballots. In the rest, residents can either show up and vote, starting a week or two weeks before election days or use absentee ballots without restrictions. In some of the states, voters can do either.
The numbers who choose to vote early are large, especially on the Republican side.
In Tennessee, nearly 400,000 ballots were cast in the early-voting period, including about 260,000 Republicans -- or roughly half the number of Republicans who voted in the 2008 and 2012 GOP primaries. In Georgia, about 417,000 people have already voted, topping the 2008 record of 271,000. Of those, about 260,000 were Republicans.
In Texas, 1.1 million votes were cast in early voting, including about 660,000 Republicans. That is 44% of the 1.5 million GOP votes cast in 2012.
Supporters of Texas Sen. Ted Cruz say his large voter-turnout organization can help blunt any advantage
Hope Hicks, a Trump campaign spokeswoman, said she is "confident in our GOTV [get out the vote] efforts in Texas and beyond."
In Florida, which votes March 15, early in-person voting started Monday in some counties. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, like Mr. Cruz in Texas, is hoping his home-state advantage and political organization will help blunt Mr. Trump's momentum. But some, perhaps many, absentee ballots were cast for Mr. Bush, making such voters unavailable to Mr. Rubio.
Rich Beeson, Mr. Rubio's deputy campaign manager, said he didn't think that would be a big problem. "People are holding on to their ballots longer than before," he said.
Credit: By Bob Davis

article name: Election 2016: Final Batch Of Clinton Emails Released
article text:
WASHINGTON -- The State Department completed its release of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's email archive on Monday, making public the final batch of her online correspondence.
All told, 2,115 of Mrs. Clinton's total archive of roughly 30,000 email messages have been deemed classified. Of those, 2,093 emails are now considered "confidential" or "secret," the two lowest levels of classification, and have been released in redacted form. Of the emails released Monday, 238 were deemed to be "confidential" and another 23 are now classified as "secret."
Another 22 emails previously were classified at the higher "top secret" designation and withheld entirely from public release.
None of the emails in Mrs. Clinton's archive had classification markings when they were sent or received by her and her staff.
The release of Mrs. Clinton's emails, distributed in batches over several months,concludes one chapter in the continuing legal saga about records management during her tenure at the State Department between 2009 and 2013 -- an issue that has spawned dozens of lawsuits, an FBI investigation, an internal State Department probe, an intelligence community review and congressional oversight from a number of committees.
Given the policy questions, legal issues and political debates surrounding the emails, the final release is unlikely to quell the controversy over Mrs. Clinton's use of a private email server while serving in government, an arrangement that was discouraged but not forbidden by State Department rules.
Mrs. Clinton is now a Democratic presidential candidate in a competitive race against Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders. Her campaign didn't immediately respond to a request for comment Monday.
The documents released by the State Department on Monday span the full four years of her tenure atop of the State Department, most about the mundane day-to-day business of running the department. A handful show the occasional tug of wars and rivalries that occasionally erupted between the rival national security power centers at the State Department and the White House.
Critics say Mrs. Clinton's use of a private server made public access to her records more difficult and may have put sensitive or classified national security information at risk.
Mrs. Clinton has said she supports the public release of her email archive. She has also said that nothing in her email archive was marked classified at the time it was sent, and her supporters have argued that national security was never jeopardized.
Credit: By Byron Tau

article name: Trump, Clinton Seize Leads --- Weekend wins give both the upper hand in amassing delegates in next state contests
article text:
PAHRUMP, Nev. -- Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton emerged from a weekend of voting as the clear leaders in the fight for their parties' presidential nominations, with smoother potential paths to victory than seemed likely a few weeks ago.
After winning the South Carolina primary, Mr. Trump should continue to benefit from a splintered Republican field that allows him to rack up convention delegates elsewhere in the South. Meanwhile, Mrs. Clinton's win in Nevada's caucuses has helped dispel doubts about her candidacy just as it heads on to favorable turf in the South, where she always figured to be stronger than her competitor Sen. Bernie Sanders.
Both front-runners still face obstacles. Mr. Trump may soon be hit with more direct attacks, and, as the field winnows, a pair of winner-take-all primaries in March could allow a competitor to make up ground quickly. And Mrs. Clinton faces a rival who has a fervent base of support in some states that lie ahead, while she has lower levels of support than her campaign would like in some pockets of the Democratic electorate.
In the short term, though, both will benefit from a primary map that is likely to give them some running room in the delegate hunt.
Mr. Trump is expected to win Nevada's Tuesday caucuses, and the state's 30 delegates, and then 12 states vote on Super Tuesday, March 1. Seven of those states are Southern contests that are key to Sen. Ted Cruz's path to victory. But Mr. Trump's convincing victory in South Carolina has put the Texan's proposition that he will be the choice of the region's social conservatives on shaky ground.
A total of 989 Republican delegates are at stake between March 1 and March 12, to be awarded proportionally, giving Mr. Trump a chance to build a significant advantage before the start of the winner-take-all primaries March 15. A total of 1,237 delegates are needed to secure the GOP nomination.
"If Trump can't be stopped from taking a majority of Super Tuesday delegates it's hard to see how he's not going to be the nominee," said Walker Stapleton, the Colorado state treasurer who was co-chairman of Jeb Bush's campaign in Colorado. The former Florida governor dropped out of the race Saturday after a poor showing in South Carolina.
A string of losses in the Southern states could be debilitating to Mr. Cruz, the Iowa caucus winner who is jockeying with Florida Sen. Marco Rubio to become the primary alternative to Mr. Trump. Mr. Rubio took second place in South Carolina but is under growing pressure to show he can win a state. His home turf, Florida, holds a winner-take-all contest on March 15.
Speaking to reporters here Sunday, Mr. Cruz predicted he would defeat Mr. Trump in a one-on-one matchup should the party choose him as the alternative to the businessman.
"Donald Trump has demonstrated that he has a relatively high floor of support, but he's also got, I think, a ceiling," Mr. Cruz said. "You've got nearly 70% of Republican primary voters that don't believe Donald is the right person to represent our party in the general election against Hillary Clinton."
Lying in wait outside of the South is Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who finished in fifth place in South Carolina with less than 8% support after his surprise second-place showing in New Hampshire. His campaign is working Massachusetts, another March 1 state, and will need a strong showing in the March 8 Michigan primary to justify his candidacy.
Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson took sixth in South Carolina but is remaining in the race.
The longer the non-Trump vote is divided four ways, or even split between two candidates, the more delegates Mr. Trump will collect by winning with a plurality of the primary votes rather than a majority.
Beyond the map, the rhetoric on the campaign trail has leaned Mr. Trump's way, with most rivals avoiding attacking him so as not to draw his fire.
It is a stark difference from 2012, when after Newt Gingrich won South Carolina's primary, the rival Mitt Romney campaign launched a full-scale effort to take down the former House speaker in Florida, the next voting state. Romney surrogates, such as Utah Rep. Jason Chaffetz, trailed Mr. Gingrich at his events and attacked his record to reporters while the campaign and supportive super PAC peppered the airwaves with TV ads hitting Mr. Gingrich.
No campaign has even attempted anything similar to attack Mr. Trump. Mr. Gingrich said Sunday it probably wouldn't work anyway.
"You can't have the Romney effect this year," Mr. Gingrich said. "Nobody can raise enough money, and furthermore, we don't know of any message that works" against Mr. Trump.
Of the roughly $215 million that super PACs have spent so far on advertisements, phone calls and mailers promoting or attacking candidates of both parties, just about $9 million -- or 4% -- has been spent opposing Mr. Trump, who has been leading national polls since July.
The biggest hit was from Our Principles PAC, a group created by a former aide to Mr. Romney's 2012 campaign. The group has spent about $3.8 million attacking Mr. Trump, though $3 million of its fundraising has come from two donors: Marlene Ricketts, the wife of TD Ameritrade founder Joe Ricketts, and Wisconsin shipping executive Richard Uihlein, according to campaign-finance reports.
Mr. Chaffetz, who backs Mr. Rubio, arrived in Nevada on Sunday. But he has no plans to attend Mr. Trump's Las Vegas rally Monday. Instead, the House Oversight Committee chairman drove to Pahrump, a retirement community near the California border, to "provide oversight" for Mr. Cruz outside a sports bar where the Texan appeared for a rally.
Asked why he isn't trying to distract the front-runner, Mr. Chaffetz replied, "I don't even know if that's possible with Mr. Trump . . . .If you're a Trump fan, you're a Trump fan."
Clinton campaign officials, for their part, believe the Nevada victory bodes well for the racially diverse set of states that come up next.
"Nevada posed the first test for both campaigns in a diverse state -- the first test of whether Sen. Sanders could broaden his appeal. . . .And he came up short," Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon said.
Mr. Sanders said on CNN Sunday that his campaign is gaining support among Hispanic voters. "I think our message is resonating," he said.
Delegates are awarded proportionally in the Democratic nomination fight, making it hard for one candidate to clinch the nomination early. But Clinton campaign aides are convinced the former senator and secretary of state is on a path to roll up an insurmountable lead by the end of March.
Mrs. Clinton also already has a big lead among superdelegates, a group of Democratic Party officials who will make up about 30% of the total needed to win.
One of Mr. Sanders's strengths had appeared to be states that hold caucuses, which typically inspire candidacies that fire up party activists, rather than primaries. Yet Mrs. Clinton has won the two caucus states.
"When they articulate their path, when they talk about how they're going to compete for the nomination, they talk about caucus states. We're now 2-0 in caucus states," Mr. Fallon said.
---
Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.
Credit: By Reid J. Epstein and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016 --- CAPITAL JOURNAL: Clinton Advances, Trump Redefines Normal for the GOP
article text:
Regular order has begun returning for Democrats. Republicans still aren't sure whether their version of regular order even exists any longer.
The one thing that was settled as voters spoke Saturday in two states -- Democrats in Nevada and Republicans in South Carolina -- is that there now is no doubt about the identity of the front-runners in the 2016 presidential campaign. Hillary Clinton has re-established herself, as she was always supposed to, as the Democratic favorite. And whether party leaders like it or not, Donald Trump now is indisputably the favorite to win the GOP nomination.
Mr. Trump continues to remake both the Republican Party and what a winning coalition within it looks like. As in Iowa and New Hampshire, he enjoyed significant strength among blue-collar, non-college-educated voters in South Carolina. They used to be a GOP afterthought, but increasingly seem to be its core.
Meanwhile, there is little consolidation in the anti-Trump lanes, and still too many of them to suit party establishment figures eager to stop Mr. Trump. This is at least a three-man race going forward, with Mr. Trump joined by Sens. Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida. Technically, for now, it is actually a five-man race, with Ohio Gov. John Kasich and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson hanging around.
Only former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush took South Carolina's results as a signal to quit the race. Mr. Kasich should gird himself, though, for he is about to come under enormous pressure to do the same, to allow the anti-Trump vote to consolidate.
By the end of Saturday night, the reality was simply this: It isn't clear who is the real alternative to Mr. Trump. South Carolina, with its large population of evangelical Christians, was supposed to be the ideal spot for Mr. Cruz, yet he failed to win. Mr. Rubio made a nice comeback from an embarrassing finish in New Hampshire, but he still hasn't shown that he can actually win anywhere.
Big money and big establishment support will be flowing to Mr. Rubio in coming days; the establishment will effectively anoint him the alternative to Mr. Trump. In his post-South Carolina speech, he wrapped himself in the cloak of Ronald Reagan, and hit a generational-change note by declaring that he will lead the "children of Reagan" into a new era of conservative power. But it is far from clear that will be enough.
For the Democrats, the situation is more simple. Mrs. Clinton didn't win Nevada's caucuses impressively, but she didn't have to. She just had to avoid raising new -- and damaging -- questions about her viability before Democrats vote in South Carolina next week.
Mrs. Clinton should win big there, because of a big African-American vote that is the foundation of her candidacy. Her opponent, Sen. Bernie Sanders, nearly conceded that state in his own concession speech.
The problem for Mr. Sanders isn't so much South Carolina next Saturday as it is the road that follows. On March 1, Democrats move on to a series of Southern states that simply don't figure to be friendly territory for him. Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Tennessee and Virginia all vote that day, and in each of them the African-American share of the population tops 15%. Texas also rolls in on March 1. A third of that state's population is Hispanic, and that also figures to be a friendly Clinton audience.
Less obviously, Nevada suggested one other Clinton asset. Until now, being the establishment choice hasn't been a good thing for much of this election cycle. But it proved to be in Nevada; older, more moderate, mainstream Democratic voters were the ones who showed up in force there for her.
Still, Mrs. Clinton continues to face the same problem she has had weighing her down since day one, which is voters' lack of confidence in her honesty and integrity. As Democratic pollster Peter Hart put it to the Journal this past week: "She is running against herself."
Mr. Sanders has an army of energized supporters and a still-healthy bank account, and states he can win on March 1: Vermont, Massachusetts, Minnesota and perhaps even Oklahoma. So things are far from decided. But for the Democrats, unlike for Republicans, a return to something resembling normalcy at least seems possible.
Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Slices Into Clinton's Lead
article text:
Sen. Bernie Sanders has cut Hillary Clinton's once-commanding national lead in the Democratic presidential race by more than half over the past month, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds.
Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, drew support from 53% of people who expect to vote in Democratic primaries, while 42% picked Mr. Sanders. That 11-point spread is much closer than the 25-point advantage Mrs. Clinton enjoyed a month ago, when the poll found her ahead by 59% to 34%.
The new poll found that Mrs. Clinton holds a solid but diminished lead among her core group of supporters: women. She continues to dominate among minorities, a crucial voting bloc in coming contests in Nevada and the South.
"The race is tightening," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who helped conduct the survey with Democrat Fred Yang. At the same time, he said, Mrs. Clinton retains "structural advantages . . . that put her in a competitive position to be the Democratic nominee."
The poll points to a long-term challenge for Mrs. Clinton in the continued rise of negative feelings about her among the broader electorate. Half of the people surveyed said they felt negatively about her, a record high for her. More than half said they would feel uncertain or pessimistic if she won the White House.
Peter D. Hart, a Democratic pollster who helped conduct the survey, said Mrs. Clinton's biggest obstacle isn't Mr. Sanders, but her own difficulty in winning the trust and affection of voters.
"She is running against herself," Mr. Hart said. "When it comes to competence, temperament . . . she laps the field. Voters just need to like her."
The poll, conducted Feb. 14-16, signaled continuing progress for Mr. Sanders in the aftermath of Iowa's caucuses, where Mrs. Clinton barely eked out a victory, and in New Hampshire, where the Vermont senator won decisively.
Mr. Sanders's gains over the past month were due in large part to rising support among younger women. Mrs. Clinton remains ahead among women overall, but Mr. Sanders slashed her lead by 19 percentage points, to 58%-39%. Mr. Sanders leads among women under age 50, while Mrs. Clinton holds a far larger lead among those 50 and older.
A bigger challenge for Mr. Sanders has been his underperformance among minority voters. He made some gains among nonwhite voters in the new poll, but Mrs. Clinton still leads among those voters by 29 percentage points, 62% to 33%. In January, she had led by 42 points.
More Democratic voters express reservations about Mr. Sanders's key weaknesses than about Mrs. Clinton's. About one-quarter said they were concerned about his lack of foreign policy experience, and 23% said his policy proposals were out of the mainstream.
Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street -- a central line of attack by Mr. Sanders -- were a concern to 22% of Democratic voters. Questions about Mrs. Clinton's honesty and judgment related to her use of a private email server while in the government seemed of little consequence within the party:Only 7% of Democratic primary voters said they were concerned about it.
Mr. Sanders is winning over change-oriented young women such as Laurren Nirider, 25, a poll participant in Richland, Wash.
"I'm 100% behind having a woman president. But I'm not going to support someone just because she's a woman," said Ms. Nirider, who backs Mr. Sanders. "Compared to Hillary Clinton, he's going to be able to move the country in a more forward direction. He's rattling the cages a little more."
Nancy D. Pemberton, 65, a college teacher in Tryon, N.C., said she thought Mr. Sanders was too inexperienced and his policies unrealistic. She saw Mrs. Clinton as better equipped for the office. "She can get the job done, and that is the most compelling thing that I am looking at," said Ms. Pemberton, who added, "It couldn't hurt to have a woman in there."
The poll asked voters of both parties to consider hypothetical matchups and found that Mr. Sanders, at least for now, seemed better equipped than Mrs. Clinton to beat a GOP opponent in the fall.
Mr. Sanders outpolled businessman Donald Trump by 16 points -- 53% to 37% -- and Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas by 50% to 40%.
Mrs. Clinton also beat Mr. Trump in a one-on-one matchup, 50% to 40%, but only tied Mr. Cruz, 46% to 46%.
Mr. Hart warned, however, that such polls this early in a campaign are poor predictors of general election matchups when a candidate is as little known as Mr. Sanders.
If the election came to a Clinton-Trump face-off, Mrs. Clinton topped Mr. Trump, 50% to 40%, among registered voters. But only 34% said their vote would be a sign of support for their chosen candidate, while 47% said it would signal they didn't want the other candidate to be elected.
Asked whether they viewed the candidates in a favorable or unfavorable light, voters had sharply negative views of three candidates: Mrs. Clinton and Messrs. Cruz and Trump. Some 59% of voters viewed Mr. Trump negatively.
Views of only two candidates -- Mr. Sanders and Ohio Gov. John Kasich -- were more positive than negative.
None of the candidates in either party inspired great confidence: Asked how they would feel if each were elected president, no candidate prompted more than 21% of voters to say they would feel "optimistic and confident."
Credit: By Janet Hook

article name: Election 2016: Bill Clinton Charges Where Campaign Hesitates
article text:
Before his wife entered the presidential campaign, Bill Clinton said he might no longer be up to the rigors of campaigning. As a new grandfather, he said, he just wasn't "mad" enough anymore.
Now Mr. Clinton is in the thick of the race, trying to help Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton recapture lost ground -- and he occasionally does sound a bit angry about how the contest is unfolding.
"When you're making a revolution, you can't be too careful with the facts," he said in New Hampshire, in a reference to the calls from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders for a "political revolution."
His speeches combine a defense of his economic record, praise for his wife and a critique of the Sanders candidacy that varies in intensity. The 69-year-old Mr. Clinton often sounds wistful, noting that his life is winding down. A favorite phrase is he has more "yesterdays than tomorrows." He says that realization helps one to focus more on "tomorrows."
Clinton campaign aides say he remains a master of "explaining stuff," the title President Barack Obama gave him in the 2012 race. Voters who come to see Mr. Clinton usually walk away impressed.
Yet his speeches have sometimes proved a distraction for his wife's campaign, and some analysts say talk of his age isn't helpful in a race focused on the future.
"Adding him to the mix raises the age differential rather than creating an image of youth and vigor," said Julian Zelizer, a professor of history and public affairs at Princeton University.
Never the most disciplined of surrogates, he wanders into territory Mrs. Clinton avoids in her stump speeches. At an event in New Hampshire, the former president started with an extended discussion of Republican investigations into the attack on the American diplomatic outpost in Benghazi.
Mr. Clinton then segued to the controversy surrounding the private email server his wife used while in office. At her own events, Mrs. Clinton generally focuses on her policy proposals -- not on these politically charged disputes.
Friends of Mr. Clinton said he seems tired on the trail. Since leaving office, he has had multiple surgical procedures to address heart disease.
Mr. Clinton checks in routinely with Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook and campaign chairman John Podesta, who was his final chief of staff at the White House, to offer advice, aides say.
"President Clinton is enormously popular and remains one of the most gifted communicators in public life," said Mr. Podesta. "Any day we are able to have President Clinton out talking directly to voters about Hillary's history of being a change-maker is a tremendous day for our campaign."
Grandfatherhood hasn't entirely mellowed the 42nd president. He has been quick to complain to friends and allies that his wife should be in a stronger position, people familiar with his views said.
He wants the campaign to talk more about Mrs. Clinton's interest in bringing about change -- a message obscured by her focus on her experience and the policies she supports.
"I'm sure he's frustrated," said Ed Rendell, former Democratic governor of Pennsylvania and a longtime ally of the Clintons. "Most of this is a ratification of how well Sen. Sanders has hit a nerve with a lot of the American people, more than the failings of Hillary."
---
Josh Dawsey contributed to this article.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Warns About GOP Rival
article text:
WASHINGTON -- Hillary Clinton warned the leading pro-Israel lobby in the U.S. that Donald Trump's foreign-policy proposals could undercut American leadership on the world stage and jeopardize the Jewish state's security, offering a preview of Democratic attacks on the Republican front-runner.
Mrs. Clinton didn't mention Mr. Trump by name Monday during remarks to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, but she condemned his views on a range of issues, casting the businessman as inconsistent and dangerously unqualified to be president.
"We need steady hands -- not a president who says he's neutral on Monday, pro-Israel on Tuesday, and who knows what on Wednesday, because everything's negotiable," Mrs. Clinton told the group. "Well, my friends, Israel's security is nonnegotiable."
The former secretary of state has ratcheted up her criticism of Mr. Trump in recent weeks. But her address to Aipac, delivered hours before her GOP rival spoke to the same audience, was a broader, more aggressive critique of Mr. Trump's worldview and credentials, opening up a new front ahead of a potential general-election battle.
Mrs. Clinton emphasized her own experience and her "unwavering, unshakable commitment to our alliance and to Israel's future as a secure and democratic homeland for the Jewish people."
Mr. Trump's inflammatory rhetoric about women, immigrants and Muslims spurred protests ahead of his Aipac speech, and his pledge to be neutral in efforts to negotiate a peace deal in the Middle East has drawn criticism. U.S. presidential candidates generally have struck a more pro-Israel posture, emphasizing the two countries' close alliance.
Mrs. Clinton told the group that "America can't ever be neutral when it comes to Israel's security or survival."
"Some things aren't negotiable," she said. "And anyone who doesn't understand that has no business being our president."
Mr. Trump pushed back against some of Mrs. Clinton's charges in a CNN interview Monday, saying, "She doesn't know me. She doesn't know my policy. There is no one who is more pro-Israel than I am."
The GOP front-runner said he would love to remain neutral in Israeli-Palestinian negotiations but noted, "It's probably not possible. There is just so much hatred."
And he disputed Mrs. Clinton's assertion that he would be an unpredictable commander in chief.
"I have the steadiest hands," he said. "Look at those hands -- far steadier than hers."
Mr. Trump addressed Aipac Monday evening, as did the other two challengers for the Republican presidential nomination, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich.
At Aipac, Mr. Trump called the former secretary of state "a total disaster" but focused primarily on detailing his views about the Middle East. He said his administration would "send a clear signal that there is no daylight between America and our most reliable ally, the state of Israel."
Mrs. Clinton's primary opponent, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, the only Jewish candidate, declined an invitation to attend the event. Mr. Sanders delivered a foreign-policy address Monday in Salt Lake City, and he told Aipac officials in a letter that the issues affecting "Israel and the Middle East are of the utmost importance to me, to our country and to the world."
In her address, Mrs. Clinton told the group the GOP contenders would offer a very different view on American leadership in the world.
"You'll get a glimpse of a potential U.S. foreign policy that would insult our allies, not engage them, and embolden our adversaries, not defeat them," she said. "For the security of Israel and the world, we need America to remain a respected global leader . . . the alternative is unthinkable."
Mrs. Clinton also decried Trump rhetoric on the campaign trail, suggesting that he has encouraged violence, played coy with white supremacists and called for turning away refugees based on their religion.
"We've had dark chapters in our history before," she said. "But America should be better than this, and I believe it's our responsibility as citizens to say so."
Mrs. Clinton also offered assurances that she would take the U.S.-Israel alliance "to the next level," pledging to strengthen Israel's military, repudiate anti-Semitism, and hold Tehran accountable for any violation of the Iran nuclear agreement.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton Coalition Takes Aim At Trump
article text:
Pro-Democratic groups are launching an orchestrated bid to weaken GOP presidential front-runner Donald Trump ahead of a potential November showdown with Hillary Clinton, while her campaign readies a strategy of engaging the billionaire businessman on issues without trading insults.
A coalition of 22 liberal groups -- including some that have endorsed Mrs. Clinton and others that back her Democratic rival, Sen. Bernie Sanders -- have united behind a campaign to stop Mr. Trump.
Among their plans: anti-Trump demonstrations, possibly including protests at the Republican National Convention this summer in Cleveland, and marches in major cities.
"So far, Trump has bounced around the country speaking to people in these stadium rallies, and we haven't seen massive marches outside the rallies," said Ben Wikler, Washington director for Moveon.org, which is leading the coalition.
A spokesman for Mr. Trump predicted that such efforts would backfire.
"What you find with Donald Trump is he's a counter-puncher," Corey Lewandowski, the Trump campaign manager, said in an interview on Thursday. "Someone punches him and he punches back, and he punches back much harder. That's what the Republican field has come to realize."
Although Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton haven't clinched their parties' nominations, the two are on a path to face off in November, based on large leads in delegates. The former secretary of state has the clearest route, while Mr. Trump still faces obstacles in amassing enough delegates to clinch the nomination. Should he fall short, he also must confront the prospect of a contested Republican convention in July.
A newcomer to politics, Mr. Trump has shown himself to be a skillful campaigner whose attacks on GOP opponents have helped fuel his rise.
A Clinton aide said her campaign has carefully monitored how Republican rivals have sought to blunt Mr. Trump's momentum, veering from ignoring him to trading personal insults with him, never with much impact.
The Democratic front-runner's aides are planning to keep her out of a war of insults, concluding that independent voters will recoil at Mr. Trump's heated rhetoric and reward her discretion. Their plan is to try to challenge Mr. Trump on substance, the Clinton aide said.
"I think that she has to be above it all," said Alan Patricof, a Clinton fundraiser. "To me, running against a bully, an egotist, a screamer, is a very difficult challenge, because you can't deal with a person like this in a normal fashion."
Mr. Trump's supporters often cite his demeanor as a refreshing change from scripted politics.
Apart from the Clinton campaign itself, liberal activists, labor unions and pro-Clinton super PACS are girding to spend tens of millions of dollars to try to weaken Mr. Trump. After months spent digging into his business dealings and monitoring his speeches, these groups are stepping up plans to try to discredit him in the eyes of voters.
One pro-Clinton super PAC, Priorities USA Action, released a video on Wednesday that sought to cast doubt on Mr. Trump's foreign-policy acumen. The AFL-CIO this week put out ads on Facebook and Twitter that aim to weaken Mr. Trump's appeal to working-class voters, depicting him as a foe of organized labor.
Major women's groups, including NARAL Pro-Choice America and Emily's List, are also plotting anti-Trump campaigns, in addition to pro-Clinton organizing that was in the works no matter who the Republicans nominate.
A senior Democrat who has spoken with Clinton campaign officials and others in the party in recent days said the multi-pronged strategy under review includes enlisting the Muslim, Hispanic and gay communities in an effort to paint Mr. Trump as a divisive force in American politics.
A pair of super PACs loyal to Mrs. Clinton have already accumulated a vast trove of research on Mr. Trump's business dealings. Using financial experts, Correct the Record and American Bridge have dug into his business career and pored over his personal-disclosure forms looking for material to exploit in a general election.
The groups haven't released any of this research as the GOP primaries have unfolded. They didn't want to assist Mr. Trump's GOP rivals, whom they believed would give Mrs. Clinton a tougher challenge in November, according to a person familiar with their work. Now, they will look for an opportune time to try to put Mr. Trump on the defensive.
Separately, Priorities USA has been preparing for a potential candidacy by Mr. Trump or Texas Sen. Ted Cruz since the summer. The group has conducted focus groups and polling on Mr. Trump and other potential opponents.
Having raised $50 million through January, Priorities USA is planning several lines of attack against the Republican front-runner. It will try to draw attention to his temperament, his treatment of women and his suitability as commander in chief, as well as his business dealings, said a person familiar with its plans.
Taking aim at Mr. Trump's statements about women poses risks, as Mrs. Clinton discovered when she faulted his use of a vulgar Yiddish term in December. Referring to his remark that she got "schlonged" by Barack Obama in the 2008 primaries, Mrs. Clinton said Mr. Trump has "a penchant for sexism." Mr. Trump quickly invoked former President Bill Clinton's history with women, including his impeachment for allegedly lying about his affair with a White House intern. That retort ended the back-and-forth.
"He punched back at her 10 times harder, and you don't hear that talk anymore," said Mr. Lewandowski. "She understood that he was not, quote-unquote, a typical politician."
Mrs. Clinton's allies say they see no advantage in Mrs. Clinton taking part in a slugfest with Mr. Trump. Still, they say they are prepared to step into a fray.
"There are things that a campaign won't want to do that need to get done," said David Brock, the founder of both Correct the Record and American Bridge. "They'll need a lot of surrogates to say things you don't want the candidate saying."
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Wins Missouri Primary
article text:
It's official: Hillary Clinton swept all five states that voted on Tuesday.
The Associated Press called Missouri for Mrs. Clinton just after 6 p.m. ET on Thursday, after an extraordinarily close race against Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
With 100% of precincts reporting, the former secretary of state had 49.6% of the vote to Mr. Sanders's 49.4%. Mrs. Clinton beat him by just 1,531 votes out of more than 619,000 votes cast.
On Tuesday night, she was also declared the winner in Florida, Ohio, North Carolina and Illinois, but Missouri was too close to call.
Missouri has 71 delegates up for grabs, the fewest of any state voting on Tuesday. The state awards delegates proportionally. Candidates need 2,383 delegates to win the Democratic presidential nomination.
A win for Mrs. Clinton in Missouri is also a symbolic victory, because the state was one where Mr. Sanders campaigned hard and saw potential for a win.
Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, held campaign events across the state ahead of the primary.
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Allies See Challenges Ahead
article text:
After capturing at least four important states this week, Hillary Clinton has all but locked down the Democratic nomination and, barring a disastrous stumble, will face the Republican nominee in the general election in November.
So what have Democrats learned about their putative nominee after 29 contests thus far? As the battle with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders progressed, the former secretary of state grew stronger as a candidate, but she displayed vulnerabilities that a Republican ticket could potentially exploit.
Her debate performances strengthened, she developed a clearer message, and she revived parts of Barack Obama's voting coalition by fully embracing the president's record and legacy. She said recently she isn't a natural-born politician in the mold of her husband, former President Bill Clinton -- an admission that might help her seem more genuine to voters.
And after getting a scare from Mr. Sanders, her supporters said she showed resilience that will prove helpful once the general-election race begins.
"Bernie has made Hillary a much better candidate," said Patti Solis Doyle, Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager in the 2008 presidential race. "She has been able to fight for her candidacy, been able to stumble and make corrections. She's been able to go at it one-on-one on the debate stage and really hone those skills again."
Clinton allies have also identified some warning signs that could spell trouble in the fall.
It is one thing to win over fellow Democrats. When the general election rolls around, Mrs. Clinton will also need to attract independents -- something she has struggled to do thus far.
In Michigan, for example, Mr. Sanders scored the biggest upset of the race by winning 71% of independent voters, compared with 28% for Mrs. Clinton. The pattern was similar in Missouri, one of the five states that votedon Tuesday and the toughest fight of the night for Mrs. Clinton. The Associated Press deemed the race too close to call as ofWednesday.
Had she done better among independents in the state, she likely would have notched a clear win. Independents accounted for about a quarter of the vote in Missouri, and Mrs. Clinton won just one-third of them, exit polls showed.
A bright spot for Mrs. Clinton has been the loyalty of African-American voters. She swept the South with overwhelming support among blacks. One question is whether these voters will feel motivated to cast ballots in November, when big turnouts in Florida, Virginia and Ohio will be key to swing-state victories.
Wall Street Journal-NBC News surveys show that as of last month, 58% of African-Americans described themselves as very excited about the election. By contrast, at the same point in the 2008 election, when Mr. Obama was a candidate, more than 80% of African-Americans were very excited about the contest.
Another question is why Democratic turnout is down. Republicans seem riveted by the emergence of Donald Trump as a political force in their party -- and they are showing up in greater numbers than in 2012. On the Democratic side, participation isn't as strong. A Journal-NBC analysis shows that as of early this month, turnout was down 42% compared with 2008, when Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama vied for the nomination. On the Republican side, turnout is up by 40% on 2012.
Ohio is a bellwether state, coveted as a general-election prize. Mrs. Clinton won easily there on Tuesday, while on the GOP side the state's governor, John Kasich, beat back a challenge from Mr. Trump. Turnout in Ohio was down 46% on the Democratic side compared with 2008 -- and up 69% among Republicans compared with 2012, according to data compiled by Public Opinion Strategies, a GOP polling firm.
But the numbers may not tell the whole story. Democratic enthusiasm could surge in the event of a Clinton-Trump showdown.
"Despite whatever lukewarm sentiment Democrats may have for Hillary Clinton, all of the presidential polling to date indicates those same voters have very negative impressions of Donald Trump," said Neil Newhouse, a co-founder of Public Opinion Strategies."That negative sentiment could help Secretary Clinton rally Democratic support and energize her party's turnout."
Hanging over Mrs. Clinton's White House run is her use of a private email account and server during her time at the State Department. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into the transmission of classified material from her network.
Over the course of the campaign Mrs. Clinton has at times sounded defensive in describing her actions, and she has yet to establish a consistent answer to the continuing questions about them.
Last September, she apologized and said she had made a mistake.
Four months later, at a town-hall event, she was less contrite. "I'm not willing to say it was an error in judgment because nothing I did was wrong," Mrs. Clinton said.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: RNC Sues to Obtain Clinton's Messages
article text:
WASHINGTON -- The Republican National Committee on Wednesday filed two lawsuits seeking access to Hillary Clinton's records, potentially opening a new chapter in the continuing legal saga over her decision to use a personal email server while secretary of state.
The RNC lawsuits, which seek access to a wide variety of records related to Mrs. Clinton's time in office, are the most direct legal challenge brought by Republican Party officials seeking access to Mrs. Clinton's records from her time in government.
The litigation could give Republican Party operatives access to a stockpile of government records generated by Mrs. Clinton and her aides going into a hotly contested general election campaign.
The first lawsuit seeks access to all text and BlackBerry messages sent and received by Mrs. Clinton during her time at the State Department. Republicans also are seeking all emails sent and received by several top aides to Mrs. Clinton, including her former Chief of Staff Cheryl Mills, top policy staffer Jake Sullivan, and technology consultant Bryan Pagliano.
A second case asks for any communications between State Department officials and Mrs. Clinton's presidential campaign after she left office in 2013. Mrs. Clinton is the leading Democratic candidate for president. Both lawsuits cite the Freedom of Information Act, or FOIA.
Any emails, text messages or other records generated by Mrs. Clinton or her aides related to official business are considered public records and are eligible for release under public records laws. Those records were requested by the RNC under FOIA directly with the State Department last year, but it didn't produce any records within the period of time allowed by law -- opening the door to the lawsuits.
The State Department's handling of Mrs. Clinton's records has generated dozens of other lawsuits, most of which are still in continuing litigation. Mrs. Clinton's email archive has already been made public, after a lawsuit by a Vice News reporter. Her email policy also has prompted an FBI investigation and independent reviews from the inspectors general of the State Department and the intelligence community.
A State Department official declined to comment about the RNC lawsuits, citing a policy against commenting on continuing legal disputes.
"This frivolous lawsuit is just another attempt by Republicans and right-wing groups to try to hurt Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign because she is the candidate they fear the most in a general election. It is not going to work," said Brian Fallon, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's campaign.
The lawsuits come as several judges on the D.C. District Court have shown a willingness to allow litigation challenging how and why the State Department permitted Mrs. Clinton to run her own email server and control access to her own records.
In response to a separate lawsuit from the conservative activist group Judicial Watch, U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan took the rare step of permitting discovery in a FOIA case -- opening the possibility that Mrs. Clinton or her top aides could be forced to testify under oath.
In another case, a different judge ordered the State Department to speed releases of her emails so Democratic voters would have access to it before casting ballots or caucusing for president.
Credit: By Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Clinton, Sanders Spar Over Immigration --- Democratic rivals debate long-ago votes and the intricacies of each other's record
article text:
MIAMI -- Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders faced off Wednesday, a day after he scored a crucial win in the Michigan presidential primary, sparring over immigration and making direct appeals to Latino voters ahead of next week's contest in Florida.
The Democratic candidates delved into the details of immigration law, invoking long-ago votes and critiquing the intricacies of each other's record. Mr. Sanders reflected on his immigrant heritage, and both candidatescited spots in the other's record that are out of step with Latino voters and immigration-rights activists.
Mrs. Clinton was questioned about the right way to handle the influx of Central American children at the border. Mr. Sanders was under fire for his opposition to the 2007 bill that would have legalized people in the U.S. illegally.
Under aggressive questioning from Univision anchor Jorge Ramos, Mrs. Clinton promised not to deport children already living in the U.S., and to target for deportation criminals and those posing a risk. Mr. Sanders also pledged not to send children away.
But the former secretary of state stuck to her position that children newly entering the country illegally should be sent back if they don't meet qualifications for asylum or other programs that would allow them to stay legally.
The eighth Democratic debate yielded few revelations, often covering well-trodden ground. Although the candidates disagreed sharply on several issues, their tone was less combative than in Sunday's matchup in Michigan.
Mrs. Clinton was pressed to explain why many voters still have doubts about whether they can trust her. In Michigan, about 60% of Democratic voters said they viewed her as honest and trustworthy, compared with 80% who said the same of Mr. Sanders, according to ABC exit polls.
"Obviously, it's painful for me to hear that, and I do take responsibility," Mrs. Clinton said. "When you're in public life, even if you believe that it's not an opinion that you think is fair or founded, you do have to take responsibility."
She said that she would work to demonstrate that people could count on her, adding that she isn't a natural politician like her husband or President Barack Obama.
For his part, Mr. Sanders tried to clarify the difference between an "establishment politician," which he has dubbed Mrs. Clinton, and a "career politician" like himself. He said the difference is what he has focused his career on, citing his independence from Wall Street and the drug and fossil-fuel industries.
During the immigration discussion, the candidates were asked a question by a woman who identified herself as a Guatemalan immigrant whose husband had been deported. She asked the candidates what they would do to keep families together. Mrs. Clinton praised the woman for having the "courage" to ask the question and called for more Americans to hear such stories.
Mrs. Clinton also took several opportunities to refocus the discussion on Mr. Sanders's 2007 vote against the immigration bill.
"Our best chance was in 2007 when [the late Sen.] Ted Kennedy led the charge," she said. "I voted for that bill. Sen. Sanders voted against it."
Mr. Sanders has said during this campaign that he opposed the bill because a guest-worker program included was akin to slavery. But the debate moderators showed a video of him from the time, where he cites concerns that the new workers would drive down wages.
Mr. Sanders replied that he worked to improve the program and was able to support the 2013 version of the bill.
Mrs. Clinton shot back with a list of immigrant advocates who backed the 2007 version, saying they never would have supported "modern slavery." "That was one of the many excuses used not to vote for the 2007 bill," she said.
Both candidates declined to label GOP front-runner Donald Trump a "racist" in response to a direct question about his references to Mexican immigrants as rapists and drug dealers. Still, they hurled several other criticisms Mr. Trump's way. Mrs. Clinton attacked his "trafficking in prejudice and paranoia."
Mr. Sanders recalled Mr. Trump's efforts in the so-called birther movement to "delegitimize the president."
He noted that his own father was born in Poland, yet "nobody has ever asked me for my birth certificate," and that was probably because of the "color of my skin."
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Laura Meckler and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Clinton's Email Jeopardy
article text:
Hillary Clinton's Super Tuesday victory gives her a clear path to the Democratic presidential nomination, but Bernie Sanders has never been her biggest obstacle to the White House. Her real liability is an email scandal that has put her in legal jeopardy.
Camp Clinton is arguing that the State Department's Monday release of the final batch of emails ends the controversy over her private server. Yet that release is merely the end of one judicially mandated exercise overseen by a bureaucracy friendly to the former Secretary of State. The real action is in the courts, the FBI and Justice Department.
But even the friendly State Department review has been damaging. Of 30,000 emails Mrs. Clinton turned over to State, we now know that 2,093 were classified as "confidential" or "secret." Another 22 were classified "top secret" -- and State withheld their contents from public release. Mrs. Clinton keeps claiming these were "retroactively" classified, but that's been vigorously disputed by intelligence community members, who note that at least some of the top-secret emails refer to intelligence projects classified from the beginning.
The latest release provides fresh evidence that Mrs. Clinton knew her server held national secrets. In one email from April 2012, aide Jake Sullivan forwarded Mrs. Clinton a blog post from a jihadist group. Mrs. Clinton replied: "If not classified or otherwise inappropriate, can you send to the NY Times reporters who interviewed me today?"
The fact that Mrs. Clinton had to ask if this one was classified suggests she knew that people were sending sensitive information to her unsecure server. The new email dump also shows then-Sen. John Kerry sending Mrs. Clinton intelligence he'd obtained from top Pakistani generals.
There's more to come. Federal judges have spent the past year doing what the State Department wouldn't -- that is, upholding the Freedom of Information Act. Judge Emmet Sullivan recently granted Judicial Watch discovery into whether State and Mrs. Clinton deliberately thwarted FOIA laws.
Judge Sullivan said from the bench: "Here you have Mrs. Clinton and [Clinton aide Huma] Abedin and their private counsel deciding, after neither Mrs. Clinton nor Ms. Abedin were government employees, what emails are federal records, and what emails are not. It just boggles the mind that the State Department allowed this circumstance to arise in the first place." Yes it does.
Discovery could lead to depositions, interrogatories and new documents that show who approved Mrs. Clinton's unsecure email arrangement, and who tried to conceal it. Judge Sullivan said he may also issue a subpoena requiring Mrs. Clinton and Ms. Abedin to turn over the entire email system they used.
Many other lawsuits are also proceeding and could provide answers to the many questions that Mrs. Clinton has dodged. Did she turn over all her work email? How many did she edit before giving them to State? Who had access to the server containing confidential information? Was her email hacked by foreign governments or criminals?
All of this is presumably also part of the FBI's investigation into Mrs. Clinton's mishandling of classified information. Attorney General Loretta Lynch last week largely dodged Congressional questions about the Clinton probe, though she did divulge that "career" attorneys are working with the FBI. The Washington Post reported Wednesday that Justice has granted immunity to Bryan Pagliano, the former State Department employee who set up the private server at Mrs. Clinton's New York home in 2009. This suggests that a grand jury may be empaneled if it isn't underway.
Now that Mrs. Clinton is the odds-on Democratic nominee, the political stakes of all this are enormous. One excuse we are likely to hear is that Mrs. Clinton shouldn't be held responsible for others who sent her classified information, as California Senator Dianne Feinstein recently said. In other words, let Mrs. Clinton's aides take the fall.
But those aides -- and the country -- wouldn't be in this mess if Mrs. Clinton hadn't set up an off-grid account to evade disclosure laws and protect her messages from public scrutiny when she ran for President. Her employees can hardly be blamed for using a system she designed, and Mrs. Clinton was responsible as the senior official for knowing the classification rules.
With Donald Trump emerging as the probable GOP nominee, the political and media temptation in Washington will be to protect Mrs. Clinton and legally excuse her behavior. But the law applies equally to everyone if it means anything. These investigations need to follow their honest course and hold Mrs. Clinton accountable for her actions. The country can handle the political fallout.
(See related letter: "Letters to the Editor: A Presidential Pardon Could Fix Clinton's Email Problem" -- WSJ Mar. 16, 2016)

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Happy to Get Support of Party Brass
article text:
MINNEAPOLIS -- Being too cozy with the establishment wing of the party has been anathema to many Republican presidential candidates this year. Not so on the Democratic side, where Hillary Clinton has leaned on the party however she can.
An army of surrogates, from senators to local and state officials, have rallied to Mrs. Clinton's cause in recent weeks, providing high-profile firepower to help the former secretary of state fend off Sen. Bernie Sanders's insurgent campaign.Democratic officeholders and party stalwarts have done everything from knocking on doors to appearing in Mrs. Clinton's stead.
Key Democrats helped Mrs. Clinton romp to victory in South Carolina. And with 11 states holding primaries and caucuseson Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton's team of surrogates worked to ensure that her message resonated across the country.
The Democratic establishment's impact on the Clinton-Sanders race stands in sharp contrast to the Republican presidential campaign, which has already felled a number of candidates closely aligned with the party brass amid the rise of Donald Trump, the embodiment of the antiestablishment wave.
Jim Manley, a Democratic strategist, said the dynamic highlights a disconnect between how voters view their own parties.
"Republicans in particular have had it with elected officials," he said. "Among Democrats, there's anger, but very little of it is directed toward elected officials."
The difference between the two parties came into sharp relief in South Carolina, where Republican former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush called upon a "who's who" of the Republican establishment, including his brother, former President George W. Bush, and his mother, former first lady Barbara Bush.
The result: Mr. Bush finished a distant fourth, with less than 8% of the vote. He ended his campaign as soon as the results were tallied.
Mrs. Clinton, meanwhile, was buoyed in the state by an assist from leading Democrats and by some well-timed endorsements. Rep. James Clyburn, the unofficial dean of the South Carolina Democratic Party, had pledged to remain neutral in the Democratic contest, but just days before his state's primary, he threw his support behind the former secretary of state. The political arm of the Congressional Black Caucus endorsed her as well, as did a long list of state legislators.
The strong show of support before the South Carolina primary, particularly from African-American leaders, helped Mrs. Clinton solidify support from black voters, who made up more than half of the electorate inSaturday'scontest. The former secretary of state cruised to victory, winning by 48 percentage points.
Jaime Harrison, chairman of the South Carolina Democratic Party, attributed the divergent fates to Mrs. Clinton's deep connections to Democrats in the state and growing antipathy among rank-and-file Republicans toward party leaders.
"I hear from Republicans that they feel as if the establishment has betrayed them; the establishment isn't fighting for what they believe in," he said. "That's part of the antiestablishment tenor on the Republican side, and I don't think that's the feeling on the Democratic side."
David Winston, a Republican strategist, said that the dynamic on the Republican side has devolved into a contest of who can make the most outrageous statement, and that has overshadowed endorsements, undercutting the influence of leading Republicans.
"The whole focus of the discourse has been trying to get attention," he said. "The most outrageous statement gets the attention."
Mr. Winston noted one exception, though, pointing to South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley's decision to back Sen. Marco Rubio, a last-minute endorsement that helped the Florida senator to a second-place finish.
More of the Republican establishment has begun to coalesce around Mr. Rubio in recent days in an effort to derail Mr. Trump, so far with little success. The former reality-TV star maintains a commanding lead in the polls.
---
Byron Tau contributed to this article.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Trump, Clinton Pile Up Victories --- GOP front-runner wins Super Tuesday contests, but Cruz takes two states, Rubio one, guaranteeing bruising race will continue
article text:
New York businessman Donald Trump won Republican primaries Tuesday from the Deep South to New England, but Texas Sen. Ted Cruz took his home state and Oklahoma, ensuring that the race for the GOP nomination will stretch into the spring.
The Republican front-runner won contests in at least seven states -- Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Vermont and Virginia -- bolstering his claim on the nomination. Still, the pockets of resistance in others gave a glimmer of hope to detractors desperate for another candidate to take on likely Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, who also rolled to a series of victories on Super Tuesday.
The problem for Mr. Trump's rivals -- as it has been since the voting began -- is that there are too many of them for voters to coalesce behind a single alternative to the New York billionaire. In the past week, opponents have dramatically intensified their attacks on Mr. Trump after he steamrolled rivals in New Hampshire, South Carolina and Nevada.
Tuesday's results, however, reinforced Mr. Trump's argument that he is building a durable coalition of GOP primary voters fed up with politics as usual that may bolt the party if he isn't the nominee. "We have expanded the Republican Party," Mr. Trump declared Tuesday night at a rally at his resort Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla. "I am a unifier."
He promised that he would work with some of the same GOP leaders in Congress, such as House Speaker Paul Ryan, who have been skittish about his rise. "I'm sure I'm going to get along with him, and if I don't, he's going to pay a big price," Mr. Trump said of the Wisconsin lawmaker.
Mr. Trump's victories Tuesday are all the more impressive because, for the first time in the race, he faced concerted attacks from his chief Republican rivals. He continues to defy the laws of presidential politics, courting controversies that few other politicians could survive.
Republicans who appreciate his candor continue to give Mr. Trump the benefit of the doubt even when he lands in hot water, as he did over the weekend when he seemed reluctant to reject the support of a former Ku Klux Klan leader
"I know Donald's going to make some mistakes when he gets to Washington, but who hasn't?" said Ducky Wall, 77, a retired golf pro from Georgia who voted for Mr. Trump. "I think he can shake things up."
But a handful of close contests Tuesday exposed some fissures in that support, as rivals, elected officials and some of the party's most prominent donors ganged up on the Republican who has spent much of the race insulting influential figures in the party. An anti-Trump group hosted a fundraising call Tuesday that drew some of the party's biggest donors, including hedge-fund titan Paul Singer, a supporter of Florida Sen. Marco Rubio.
Tuesday's results give Mr. Cruz new grounds to argue he is the leading alternative to Mr. Trump, beating the front-runner in Oklahoma and the Lone Star State, a month after his victory in the first-in-the-nation Iowa caucuses. The wins reinforced Mr. Cruz's argument that he is the only Republican who can topple Mr. Trump. But Mr. Rubio did win one state, topping Messrs. Cruz and Trump in the Minnesota caucuses.
"After tonight we have seen that our campaign is the only campaign that has beaten, that can beat and that will beat Donald Trump," Mr. Cruz said at his victory party.
Mr. Cruz benefited from voters skeptical about Mr. Trump. "I'll weep, if he is the nominee," said Cruz supporter Julie Earl, of McKinney, Texas, referring to Mr. Trump. Added Terry Sauls of McKinney, "He's a Democrat in Republican boots."
Tuesday marked the first chance for the remaining GOP contenders to test their strength across different segments of the electorate. Roughly 60% of Republican voters in Virginia graduated from college and support legal status for immigrants in the country illegally. In Alabama, 54% of GOP primary voters said undocumented immigrants should be deported.
The rules of the GOP nominating contests could muddy the results because most of Tuesday's states divide delegates proportionality. The rules differ in each, but candidates that clear certain thresholds will qualify for delegates. And no candidate had yet to clear the 50% threshold in statewide balloting to claim the bulk of any one state's delegates. The complex delegate math made it too tough to determine the exact total each candidate won Tuesday.
The race now turns to a pair of swing states that are home to two of Mr. Trump's remaining rivals-Mr. Rubio in Florida and Ohio Gov. John Kasich. Mr. Trump may be able to knock either from the race by beating them on their home turf.
Questions arose late Tuesday about the viability of Messrs. Kasich and Rubio's campaigns. On Tuesday, Mr. Rubio's campaign manager told donors in Washington, D.C., that they were committed to going all the way to the Republican convention in Cleveland in July.
For the first time in this race, Messrs. Cruz and Rubio over the past week took on the front-runner at the same time. The two senators, along with Mr. Kasich, are trying to outlast each other to set up a head-to-head match up with Mr. Trump. Time is dwindling for a candidate other than the former reality TV star to collect enough delegates to win.
Mr. Trump's February winning streak triggered a backlash from his rivals and other elected GOP officials petrified by the prospect of the brash billionaire topping the ticket. His detractors are desperately trying to hatch strategies to deny him the nomination, including a bruising convention fight that could alienate his supporters.
No Republican has been more vocal than Mr. Rubio. After spending much of the past year trying to avoid direct confrontations with his rivals for the nomination, Mr. Rubio has resorted to calling Mr. Trump a "con artist," questioning his wealth and even suggesting the front-runner urinated on himself during the most recent candidates' debate last Thursday night.
Mr. Trump has responded to the broadsides by referring to Mr. Rubio as "Little Marco" and dismissing his digs as a feeble attempt to claw his way back into the race. In an interview with Fox News Tuesday, Mr. Trump called on Mr. Rubio to exit the race. "I think he has to get out," he said.
Mr. Trump found himself embroiled in a potentially more serious controversy over the weekend when he hesitated to disavow the support of David Duke, a former Grand Wizard in the Ku Klux Klan. Mr. Trump eventually rejected Mr. Duke's support and blamed his initial response on a bad earpiece during his CNN interview.
But the episode underscored Republicans' fear that Mr. Trump may imperil GOP candidates at every level of the ballot, if primary voters make him the nominee.
On Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton used the David Duke episode to tell a Minneapolis crowd she was "very disappointed" Mr. Trump didn't immediately disavow the former Klan leader's support. "I'm just speaking out against bigotry and bullying wherever I hear it," she said. "And I hear a lot of it from the Republican candidates."
Mr. Trump's Republican detractors have grown louder and more strident as the front-runner gets closer to clinching the nomination. A pair of retiring GOP congressmen -- Reps. Reid Ribble of Wisconsin and Scott Rigell of Virginia -- joined South Carolina Rep. Mark Sanford and Florida Rep. Carlos Curbelo in vowing not to vote for Mr. Trump, even if he becomes the nominee. They followed former Republican National Committee Chairmen Mel Martinez and Ken Mehlman, among other current and former elected and party officials.
"Trump is a bully, unworthy of our nomination," Mr. Rigell wrote his constituents on Monday night. "To live with a clear conscience, I will not support a nominee so lacking in judgment, temperament and character needed to be our commander-in-chief."
Credit: By Patrick O'Connor and Janet Hook

article name: Blacks Bolster Clinton in South
article text:
Hillary Clinton rode overwhelming African-American support to a landslide victory in South Carolina's Democratic presidential primary over the weekend, and she is hoping black voters can next deliver lopsided wins in a swath of Southern states that vote Tuesday.
It is a remarkable twist given that Mrs. Clinton's last presidential campaign ended with her relationship with black leaders and voters in tatters.
Mrs. Clinton solidified her status as the party's front-runner by trouncing Sen. Bernie Sanders in South Carolina, with 74% support compared with 26% for her rival. Six in 10 of the primary participants were African-American, and she won 86% of their votes, according to exit polls reported by CNN and other media. That means she could have won the state without a single white vote.
The Clinton camp is hoping for big wins on Tuesday in Alabama and Georgia, where black voters made up more than half of the primary electorate in 2008, according to exit polls. Mrs. Clinton on Sunday visited two African-American churches in Memphis, Tenn., and planned stops before Tuesday's vote in Nashville, Arkansas and Virginia.
The minority-rich Southern states where Mrs. Clinton holds the stronger hand will allocate a combined 571 delegates to the convention on Tuesday. While Mr. Sanders could post a strong showing in some states this week, including his home state of Vermont, the states in which he hopes to be competitive will award just 288 delegates.
Just eight years ago, many African-Americans were offended by what they saw as racially tinged remarks by both Mrs. Clinton and her husband during the drawn-out nomination battle with then-Sen. Barack Obama. Her road back to their good wishes began almost as soon as her contest with Mr. Obama ended.
At the Democratic National Convention in the summer of 2008, she threw him her support, and after he was elected, she served as his secretary of state. Later, she nurtured relationships with quiet gestures and personal outreach to African-Americans.
For decades the Clintons both had close black friends and advisers, and author Toni Morrison half-jokingly dubbed Bill Clinton the nation's first black president.
"Bill Clinton is the only person I know, black or white, who knows every verse to the black national anthem," Tavis Smiley, a television and radio host, said in an interview. "He just gets black people."
Mrs. Clinton enjoyed strong African-American support at the outset of the 2008 cycle, but after Mr. Obama gained traction, most black voters swung to him and the historic opportunity to elect the first African-American president.
Ahead of the 2008 South Carolina primary, which Mr. Obama was clearly about to win, Mr. Clinton dismissed his success in the state by comparing him with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who won the state's Democratic presidential primary twice but never secured the nomination.
In that same primary, Mrs. Clinton appeared to diminish the importance of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. by saying it took President Lyndon Johnson to get the Civil Rights Act into law.
"A lot of people were genuinely hurt," said the Rev. Al Sharpton, a civil-rights leader and TV and radio host.
Her first big step toward redemption came when she called upon Democrats to unite and elect Mr. Obama at the convention. Her willingness to serve as secretary of state also went a long way toward healing wounds, said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.).
After Mrs. Clinton left office in early 2013, she went to work solidifying her relationships. "She did a healthy-size portion of reaching out," said Minyon Moore, a longtime friend and former aide. "A lot of African-Americans were on her list."
Mr. Jeffries remembers receiving a handwritten note from the former New York senator during the 2013 holiday season and being struck by how personal the sentiment was. He had been a junior member of the state legislature when they met.
"Who am I? She took time to figure that out, and it's greatly appreciated," he said.
Mr. Sharpton recalls a phone call from Mrs. Clinton on his 60th birthday, in October 2014.
"I said to one of my assistants, 'Aww, maybe she's going to run' " for president, Mr. Sharpton said. The assistant replied there were lots of reasons that she might remember his birthday, he said.
"I said, 'yeah, but I had 59 other birthdays and she's never called me,' " he added.
Once she declared her candidacy, Mrs. Clinton put a strong focus on issues of particular concern to the African-American community. She delivered early speeches about bolstering voting rights and ending the "era of mass incarceration."
When she released her college affordability plan last summer, it included $25 billion for historically black colleges and universities.
She ran into trouble early when, in recounting an anecdote she heard from her mother, she said, "all lives matter," a phrase that some see as disrespectful of the Black Lives Matter movement. But after that, she met with Black Lives Matter members and with mothers of young black people who died in police custody. This month, she gave a speech in Harlem about systemic racism.
And she has wrapped herself tightly to Mr. Obama, casting herself as the true heir to his legacy.
"She has very astutely and very deftly wrapped herself around the first black president," Mr. Smiley said. "Black people see that, they recognize that and they know that."
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Polls Point to Big Gains for Trump, Clinton
article text:
WASHINGTON -- Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton hold leads in key states up for grabs in Super Tuesday's nominating contests, suggesting the front-runners are poised to pull decisively ahead of their rivals.
Mr. Trump is ahead of his nearest rival by 18 percentage points in Tennessee among likely Republican voters, and by seven points in Georgia, according to a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll taken between Feb. 18 and 25.
Mrs. Clinton has commanding leads in Tennessee and Georgia, as well as in Texas, where she has 59% of the vote, compared with 38% for rival Bernie Sanders.
Republican Sen. Ted Cruz is emerging as Mr. Trump's strongest competitor on Tuesday, leading in the poll with support of 39% of likely voters in Texas -- the state with the most delegates at stake on Tuesday -- compared with 26% for Mr. Trump. The Texas senator is hoping that a strong win in his home state will bolster his argument that he is the only Republican with the support necessary to take on Mr. Trump.
The polls of three Super Tuesday states point to contests that are entering a critical new phase, in which Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump have the potential to cement early gains. Given those stakes, both are drawing a battery of attacks from rivals determined to stop them from winning all of the 11 states awarding delegates on Tuesday.
Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, who has picked up the support of much of the Republican establishment since former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush left the race, is neck and neck with Mr. Cruz in both Georgia and Tennessee. Mr. Rubio had the support of the 23% of the vote in Georgia, matching Mr. Cruz, the poll found. The Florida senator had the support of 19% of likely voters in Tennessee, compared with 22% for Mr. Cruz.
But the polls, which have a margin of error of between 3.8 and 5 percentage points, found that Mr. Trump was easily ahead of both men, with the support of 30% of voters in Georgia and 40% in Tennessee.
Two other GOP candidates -- retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson and Ohio Gov. John Kasich -- each have support in the single digits in the three states.
In the Democratic contest, Mrs. Clinton is dominating the field, based in large part on commanding margins among African-American voters. She leads Mr. Sanders by 34 points in Georgia, where black voters make up a majority of the likely Democratic voting pool, and by 26 points in Tennessee, where African-Americans make up almost a third of the Democratic electorate.
The strengths Mr. Sanders has carried in prior nominating contests are apparent in the new poll. He wins among independent voters who say they'll participate in Democratic primaries in the three states, and carries voters under age 45 in Tennessee and Texas. Those groups helped propel him to a big win in New Hampshire and what essentially was a tie in Iowa.
The Texas poll also shows that Mr. Sanders has made some inroads in the Latino community, with support among 47% of likely Latino voters compared with 52% for Mrs. Clinton.
The polls were conducted before Mr. Trump was endorsed by New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and before Thursday's GOP debate, in which Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz challenged Mr. Trump's business ethics, conservative credentials, and policy positions.
Credit: By Byron Tau and Siobhan Hughes

article name: The Clinton Coronation Resumes
article text:
So much for the Bernie Sanders revolution. Hillary Clinton's blowout victory in South Carolina on Saturday, combined with her huge polling leads in most Super Tuesday states, shows that the Democratic Party coronation has resumed.
Mr. Sanders could muster a mere 26% of South Carolina Democrats. The exit polls say Mrs. Clinton won an almost unbelievable 86% of the black vote, suggesting that she will also sweep the other southern states with heavy African-American populations on Tuesday. Mr. Sanders will presumably win in Vermont, and maybe another state or two, but that won't be nearly enough to stop Mrs. Clinton from cruising to the nomination.
The Democratic contest thus returns to the normalcy of recent decades, which is that a progressive insurgency invariably fails against the establishment favorite. Gary Hart, Bill Bradley, Howard Dean and Mr. Sanders were all favorites of the white gentry left. They lost because they couldn't defeat the government unions or persuade enough African-Americans. Barack Obama was the exception because he could compete for the black vote.
Mrs. Clinton continued to underperform among younger voters, and underlying economic anxiety should concern Democrats going into November. Some 84% of Democrats in South Carolina said they are either very or somewhat worried about the U.S. economy. But the Clinton juggernaut shows that, unlike the GOP, there really is a Democratic establishment composed of powerful interest groups that determine the nominee. Those forces are rallying to defeat Mr. Sanders, whom they view as unelectable.
Barring some new revelation, it looks like only the FBI probe into Hillary's emails and her mishandling of classified information can derail her now. But Republicans shouldn't count on anything coming from President Obama's Justice Department. Mr. Obama has made clear he views a Clinton victory as crucial to his legacy, and only a brave government employee would recommend a criminal charge against a major-party nominee so close to an election.
A Clinton nomination without an indictment or plea bargain also means that Michael Bloomberg is unlikely to make a third-party run. The former New York mayor wouldn't want to be responsible for splitting the center-left vote and electing Donald Trump.
This also means that on present trend the Democratic Party is going to be reasonably unified going into the fall campaign. There's still a question of whether Mrs. Clinton can motivate enough of Mr. Obama's 2012 coalition to come out to vote.
