But Mr. Obama and her husband will be campaigning for her, making the case that she is the only barrier in the way of Republican control of both Congress and the White House.
Republicans keep telling themselves that Mrs. Clinton is a lousy candidate, and so she is by any conventional measure. Even half of all Democrats find her untrustworthy, and she is as natural on the stump as Velveeta. But an election always come down to a choice, and the GOP is likely to have the harder time uniting behind its eventual nominee, especially if it is Mr. Trump. Then again, if Mrs. Clinton does become our next President, perhaps she can make Chris Christie her Attorney General.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Looks to Set a Southern Tone
article text:
ORANGEBURG, S.C. -- Hillary Clinton's Southern firewall appears poised to pass its first test Saturday in South Carolina, where a strong showing could hint at more struggles ahead for Democratic rival Bernie Sanders in many of the Super Tuesday contests.
Mrs. Clinton heads into Saturday's primary with a double-digit lead in the polls and an eye on the Southern states that will vote on Tuesday, including Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Texas, Arkansas and Virginia.
Her strength in the region, particularly among its many African-American Democratic voters, has been magnified by the Sanders campaign's decision not to try to match her investment here and elsewhere. Officials in some Super Tuesday states say they still are looking for indications that he is competing in the so-called SEC primary.
A march outside a downtown Nashville coffee shop on Saturday will feature a half-dozen, life-size Bernie Sanders cutouts, but otherwise, there has been little sign of Mr. Sanders himself in Tennessee, Democrats said.
"You kind of get the feel that he doesn't think it's worthwhile coming," said Randall Rice, head of the Tennessee Democratic County Chairs Association, who is neutral in the race. "The Bernie group has come in and set up offices, but he's not been here as far as I know. Hillary has been here a few times."
Mrs. Clinton will be back in Tennessee on Sunday.
Mr. Sanders held two events in South Carolina late Friday, including a rally with rapper Killer Mike at historically black Claflin University here in Orangeburg. But Mr. Sanders is headed to Minnesota and Texas on Saturday to trumpet his free-college-tuition plan, and he won't be in South Carolina when the election results are announced.
Justin Bamberg, one of a handful of black legislators who endorsed Mr. Sanders in South Carolina, said he wishes the Vermont senator could stay for a victory party, but, "realistically speaking, how can you get everywhere? You can't."
Tharon Johnson, a Democratic strategist who served as the Southern regional director for President Barack Obama's 2012 campaign, said the reason Mr. Sanders isn't spending as much time in South Carolina as Mrs. Clinton "is because he now knows you have to develop a broad coalition of support in these Southern states, particularly where there's a high minority voting-age population."
Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said the senator's best hope of winning South Carolina hinged on nabbing victories in Iowa, New Hampshire and Nevada, the first three contests.
Mr. Sanders won the New Hampshire primary, came close in Iowa and lost Nevada. Absent an early trifecta of wins, Mr. Devine said the Sanders campaign now needs to focus on playing the long game and looking ahead to later contests.
"We still believe we have the best message, and while we had the advantage of having Iowa and New Hampshire the first and second states, she has the advantage of having so many states from the South so early in the process," Mr. Devine said. "She'll gain from that. Once that's over, the ball comes back to our court and we start to move into a number of states" where they expected to do well.
But between then and now, Mrs. Clinton is likely to secure lopsided victories that illustrate her ability to attract the diverse coalition necessary for a Democratic candidate to win the general election. She also will rack up a slew of delegates in the process.
Alabama state Sen. Linda Coleman-Madison said Mrs. Clinton has a strong following among African-American voters there. The former senator and secretary of state has visited multiple times, and she and former President Bill Clinton will be back in the state on Saturday.
African-American voters in Alabama generally have only a vague senseof Mr. Sanders, she said, so the senator's absence in the state ahead of Super Tuesday doesn't help. Some of Mr. Sanders's field organizers visited her office a while back, and she said she told them, "Quite frankly, I don't really know who he is."
Mr. Sanders's wife, Jane, disputed suggestions that she and her husband haven't spent time in the South or have written off South Carolina or the region, attributing that narrative to what she called Clinton campaign "spin." Mr. Sanders appeared at campaign events in the state on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday, she noted.
"They spend a lot of time spinning, and so that's not accurate," she said. We've gone to Alabama -- we were down there for the 50th anniversary of Selma."
This week, though, Mr. Sanders spent most of his time outside of the South, venturing to Massachusetts, Missouri, Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Oklahoma.
Clinton campaign officials also asserted that Mr. Sanders had expended significant resources in South Carolina, hiring a large staff and making major ad buys.
"A win in South Carolina for us would be quite meaningful because despite the fact that in recent days Sen. Sanders has focused his travel on Super Tuesday states, it's clear he contested South Carolina very fiercely for a very long time," said Brian Fallon, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary. "One could make a judgment that they treated South Carolina as a testing ground for whether they could broaden his appeal and expand his support into a more diverse electorate."
Mr. Fallon said he is confident Mrs. Clinton would emerge from Tuesday's contests with an advantage in pledged delegates. Mr. Sanders has focused the bulk of his recent efforts on five states -- Vermont, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Colorado and Oklahoma -- that represent only about one-third of the delegates that will be awarded on Super Tuesday.
"If he is not going to contest states that have a greater percentage of African-Americans and Latinos in them, then the math just won't work for him," Mr. Fallon said.
---
Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Valerie Bauerlein and Peter Nicholas

article name: Justice and Clinton's Email Probe
article text:
Attorney General Loretta Lynch this week tried to assure House Republicans about the impartiality of her department's investigation into Hillary Clinton's State Department emails by noting that it would be handled by career government officials. This claim could stand a little parsing.
The probe into her possible mishandling of classified information "is being handled by career independent law enforcement agents -- FBI agents -- as well as the career independent attorneys in the Department of Justice," Ms. Lynch said Wednesday. "They follow the evidence, they look at the law and they'll make a recommendation to me when the time is appropriate," adding that the probe is being "conducted as every other case."
That's what they always say, and it is nice to think so. But there's reason to doubt given the example of Justice's investigation into the IRS targeting of conservative groups before the 2012 election. To lead that probe, then Attorney General Eric Holder appointed Barbara Bosserman, a trial attorney in the department's Civil Rights Division.
Ms. Bosserman's appointment was curious given that her area of expertise is civil rights, not tax law. She had also donated $6,100 to President Obama's campaigns and the Obama Victory Fund in 2008 and 2012. That's no small donation on a career employee's salary and suggests some serious political loyalty.
Ms. Bosserman's conflict of interest came to light only after Justice stonewalled congressional requests for information about the status of the IRS probe. The House Oversight Committee then began investigating Justice's investigation. In September 2014 we wrote about the involvement of former department spokesman Brian Fallon, now a press secretary for the Clinton presidential campaign.
The House also discovered that Justice had assigned former IRS tax attorney Andrew Strelka to the case brought against the agency by Z Street, a pro-Israel group that claimed its tax-exempt status had been delayed because of its political leanings. Mr. Strelka had previously served as a presidential management fellow working in the IRS tax-exempt office managed by Lois Lerner, who by the way was also a career government official with clear anti-Republican political leanings. Mr. Strelka was removed from the case before being deposed as a witness.
Justice closed its investigation of the IRS last October with no criminal charges.
We'll hope for the best from Ms. Lynch's career prosecutors, and especially from the FBI. But whoever handles the case, at either the State or Justice Department, will presumably create a paper trail of evidence and legal analysis. If a Republican wins the presidential election, his appointees will be able to look at the files and judge the evidence independently.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton's Focus Stays On South Carolina
article text:
KINGSTREE, S.C. -- Hillary Clinton has been crisscrossing South Carolina, with as many as four events a day, showing diligence in the state and loyalty to its African-American voters who could bolster her chances in Saturday's Democratic primary.
In contrast, her rival, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, is spending much of his time this week courting college-age voters in Ohio and Oklahoma, an itinerary that could amount to ceding the South and its powerful black voting blocs to Mrs. Clinton. African-American voters will likely make up more than half of the electorate in South Carolina's Democratic primary.
Mrs. Clinton's focus has mostly been on criminal justice reform and income inequality. "We've got work to do to help more people be able to knock down those barriers that stand in their way," she said. "And that includes taking on systemic racism which is still a problem in America."
The Sanders campaign is running an energetic ground game in South Carolina, with hundreds of volunteers knocking on doors, piling into the campaign's half-dozen offices and spending hours a week calling voters.
Volunteer Judy Milburn Lake likes to say that "to see Bernie is to love him," and she is disappointed that many South Carolinians haven't had the chance to eyeball Mr. Sanders, who has spent comparatively little time here.
The senator remains relatively unknown to a lot of voters in this state. And with just a day remaining before the primary, many said they were backing Mrs. Clinton by default.
Polls show a decided advantage for the former secretary of state. In a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll last week, Mrs. Clinton held a 28-percentage-point lead over Mr. Sanders among likely Democratic voters in South Carolina.
Mr. Sanders hasn't abandoned the state. He was in Greenville on Sunday and then Columbia on Tuesday for a CNN event. He held a news conference on poverty with two prominent black legislators Wednesday before setting off to Kansas City, Mo.
Todd Shaw, associate professor of political science and African-American studies at the University of South Carolina, said Mr. Sanders faces a strategic dilemma this week in dividing his time between South Carolina and the states that will hold the next contests. Although a win appears out of reach in South Carolina, ignoring the state "might look as if you're writing off the black vote," he said.
Mr. Sanders is expected to come back to South Carolina Friday.
On Thursday, Mrs. Clinton had the Palmetto State to herself. And, while Mr. Sanders hopscotched from Ohio to Illinois to Michigan, the entire Clinton family deployed across South Carolina. Mrs. Clinton and former President Bill Clinton each had a full day's worth of campaign rallies planned, and daughter Chelsea Clinton appeared at her own event.
Mr. Sanders is trying to use surrogates to reach voters. But Sanders supporters privately acknowledge feeling burned when Mr. Sanders said in his Feb. 20 concession speech in Nevada, "On to SuperTuesday," ignoring the primary here.
Credit: By Valerie Bauerlein and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Will Justices Criminalize the Clinton Foundation? Plus, the IRS conducts warrantless email searches.
article text:
Today the Supreme Court will consider whether attending and arranging meetings for generous benefactors amounts to criminal political corruption . The case involves former Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell, who took $170,000 in gifts from a Richmond businessman. A Journal editorial notes , "The legal problem is that Mr. McDonnell never provided much of any quo for the quid." The editorial board adds , "If arranging a meeting for a benefactor qualifies as corruption, prosecutors will be able to target any politician in the country. Such as Hillary Clinton."
Morning Editorial Report
Click here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.
Now here's something that really should be criminal. A separate editorial notes that because of a loophole in a 1986 law, the IRS and other agencies have been able to examine Americans' email without search warrants . The editorial board writes that under the law "any federal bureaucrat using a mere administrative subpoena" can read email "that has been opened or is older than 180 days." In 2010 a federal appeals court sought to limit this abuse but the IRS has largely ignored it.
"The bids to buy Yahoo's operating business, rumored to be between $4 billion and $8 billion, are in--and my guess is that they are all high," writes Andy Kessler . "In the tech world, if you're not growing, you're dying."
"As expected, Volkswagen's scandal over emissions cheating is spreading to other car makers," writes our columnist Holman Jenkins . "Porsche, Audi, Mercedes and GM's Opel division in Germany are recalling cars for failing emissions tests . In France, Renault and Peugeot have been raided by police . Japan's Mitsubishi admitted on Tuesday that it had been fudging mileage data for 25 years, putting the company's survival in doubt." Mr. Jenkins adds , "In an honest world the scandal would now spread to the agencies and politicians that conspire to set implausible rules and then help create ways around them for industries that employ millions of their voters and whose products are of vital daily purpose to virtually everyone in their societies ."
Also today, Jayson Lusk debunks the "romantic traditionalism" behind opposition to genetically-modified foods. "The truth is that what we eat today differs radically from the food eaten even a few hundred years ago . Carrots used to be purple. Random mutations and selective breeding led to their signature color during the 16th century in the Netherlands, where it later was claimed the new varieties honored the King William of Orange. Broccoli, kale, cauliflower and Brussels sprouts all emerged from the same wild plant. Potatoes and tomatoes originated in the Americas and were never eaten in Europe and Asia until after the New World was discovered. Today we eat more and better than ever, precisely because we did not accept only what nature provided," writes Mr. Lusk .
After Donald Trump's big wins on Tuesday, a Journal editorial notes that his advisers "are promising a new, more disciplined Donald Trump, and on Tuesday night he tried to stay mostly positive and stressed the need for economic revival. His gambling voters had better hope it lasts ."
"After long months of rage-mongering, the politics of gloom and the images of a broken America conjured by both Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump, Mrs. Clinton looks, by comparison, like a model of hope and shining optimism," writes Dorothy Rabinowitz .
Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Politics Is Not a Crime; If Bob McDonnell is guilty of corruption, then so is Hillary Clinton.
article text:
Americans think most politicians are corrupt these days, but sometimes the law needs to protect the normal business of politics against prosecutors who invent law-breaking when it doesn't exist. That's the Supreme Court's task on Wednesday when it hears the appeal of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell's corruption conviction.
A jury convicted Mr. McDonnell in 2014 for taking more than $170,000 in gifts from a Richmond businessman who was also a family friend. The gifts included a $50,000 loan, $15,000 to finance their daughter's wedding, fancy dresses, a Rolex watch and vacations. Let us stipulate that this is reckless and sleazy, and that the businessman hoped the Governor would take actions to promote his diet-supplement business.
The legal problem is that Mr. McDonnell never provided much of any quo for the quid. Virginia law lets politicians accept gifts, and prosecutors never charged him with violating state law. They charged him under federal law with performing "official acts" to benefit the business, but none of those acts influenced policy or changed a government decision.
Mr. McDonnell was convicted for attending a lunch at the executive mansion where the businessman's company gave out grants to universities, for attending a reception with the businessman, for asking an aide about research pertaining to the company, and for arranging a meeting with his staff and the man.
This stretches the bribery statutes to criminalize the normal transactions of politics. Public officials routinely act as boosters for local businesses. They also frequently meet donors and introduce them to others. Citizens also have the First Amendment right to petition their elected officials. If arranging a meeting for a benefactor qualifies as corruption, prosecutors will be able to target any politician in the country.
Such as Hillary Clinton. As Secretary of State Mrs. Clinton lobbied governments on issues affecting companies that donated to the Clinton Foundation. Then there are the speaking fees for Bill Clinton paid by companies that had interests before the State Department.
In 2010 the Supreme Court grappled with a similar corruption issue in Skilling v U.S., a case about former Enron CEO Jeffrey Skilling. The case was decided unanimously and a 6-3 majority defined corruption under the Honest Services Fraud statute as bribes and kickbacks. In a concurrence written by the late Justice Antonin Scalia, three Justices would have struck down the honest-services law.
"A criminal statute must clearly define the conduct it proscribes," Justice Scalia wrote. The Honest Services Fraud statute that prohibits "a scheme or artifice to deprive another of the intangible right of honest services" is "vague, and therefore violates the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment."
The McDonnell conviction also raises federalism concerns because its elastic definition of bribery could unleash federal prosecutors on state politicians who may be political opponents of the Administration running the Justice Department. For this and other reasons, dozens of former federal and state officials, including more than 80 former state attorneys general, signed amicus briefs on behalf of Mr. McDonnell's appeal.
Justice Scalia's absence will be felt at the Court, but we hope the eight remaining Justices remember the courage of their convictions in Skilling. Bribery requires evidence of a clear exchange of an official action for something of value. Mr. McDonnell's bad judgment was an embarrassing spectacle and he deserves political exile. His conviction deserves skepticism from the Court.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Outlines Counterterror Response --- Former secretary of state rebukes GOP rivals' proposals in speech at Stanford
article text:
STANFORD, Calif. -- Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton delivered a broad rebuke of her Republican rivals in a counterterrorism speech Wednesday that sought to validate voter fears while advocating targeted use of American power to defeat Islamic State.
She said demonizing Muslims makes it harder to fight terrorism and that condoning torture undermines American values. She condemned calls to withdraw American support for NATO and to "carpet bomb" populated areas in hopes of killing terrorists. And she said there is no way to build a wall high enough to block the Internet, where jihadists are recruited.
"Slogans aren't a strategy. Loose cannons tend to misfire," she said, presenting herself as the adult in a room full of bluster and irresponsible rhetoric. "What America needs is strong, smart, steady leadership to wage and win this struggle."
The speech at Stanford University came a day after a terrorist attack in Brussels where suicide bombers at the airport and subway detonated explosions that killed 31, wounded 270 others and refocused the presidential campaign on the terrorist threat.
The Democratic front-runner laid out a slate of ideas for battling terrorists at home and abroad, few of them new, while delivering a takedown of the leading Republican presidential candidates. She called for an "intelligence surge" and said governments should reconsider protocols in airports and areas outside security zones.
She lambasted Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's call for more aggressively policing of Muslim neighborhoods, saying Muslim-Americans are vital to detecting and reporting evolving plots. She said Muslim nations are critical allies in the fight against terror that don't appreciate "offensive, inflammatory rhetoric that demonizes all Muslims."
She also offered a vigorous and lengthy defense of American alliances including NATO, which she called the most successful in history, and said GOP front-runner Donald Trump's call to scale back American support for the European-based security organization would only enable Russian President Vladimir Putin to extend his power. "Putin already hopes to divide Europe. If Mr. Trump gets his way it will be like Christmas in the Kremlin," she said.
Mr. Trump responded to Mrs. Clinton's speech in a Twitter post. "Just watched Hillary deliver a prepackaged speech on terror. She's been in office fighting terror for 20 years -- and look where we are," he wrote.
A representative for Mr. Cruz didn't reply to requests for comment.
Mrs. Clinton ignored her Democratic rival for the presidential nomination, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, entirely. He has painted her as overly hawkish and repeatedly reminded audiences that she voted to authorize the 2003 invasion of Iraq. With a commanding lead in delegates, Mrs. Clinton has increasingly trained her focus on her prospective Republican rivals.
Mrs. Clinton sprinkled her speech with recollections from her four years as President Barack Obama's secretary of state. That service has given her experience and an understanding of global complexities, but may be a burden if voters blame Mr. Obama -- and by extension, Mrs. Clinton -- for world problems, including the growth of Islamic State, which claimed responsibility for the Brussels attacks.
Responding to the speech, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee connected Mrs. Clinton to Mr. Obama and said they both had failed to take the terrorist threat seriously enough. "Hillary Clinton and President Obama have been wrong about ISIS at every turn, which has resulted in more attacks and a more dangerous world," said a statement from RNC Chairman Reince Priebus.
At the top of her remarks, she acknowledged American anxiety, but said those fears could be countered with measured, specific ideas. Among them: stepped-up U.S. air power in Iraq and Syria to counter Islamic State, though no ground troops, and enlisting technology companies to track terrorist social media networks.
She said that European nations still aren't alerting one another when they turn away suspected terrorists at their borders, despite pledges to better share information made after the attacks last year in Paris. "It's actually easier for the United States to get flight manifests from EU nations than it is for EU nations to get them from their own neighbors," she said.
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Continues Momentum by Securing Big Prize
article text:
Hillary Clinton won the biggest prize in Tuesday's Democratic presidential contests, securing a victory in Arizona's primary and pulling further ahead of Sen. Bernie Sanders in the chase for delegates.
Mr. Sanders was expected to fare better in Idaho and Utah, which held caucuses Tuesday. But Mrs. Clinton's victory in Arizona, which awards more delegates than the other two states combined, further dimmed Mr. Sanders's hopes of regaining momentum in the race for the Democratic nomination.
Mrs. Clinton celebrated her victory at a rally in Seattle, where she was campaigning ahead of Saturday's Washington state caucuses. She looked past Mr. Sanders entirely and sharply criticized Republicans, particularly presidential front-runner Donald Trump, and said voters understand that the race under way isn't just a choice between candidates.
"This is a contest between fundamentally different views of our country, our values and our future," she said.
With the primary season half over, Mr. Sanders entered Tuesday's three nominating contests in urgent need of lopsided wins and a strategy for broadening his coalition beyond the young and largely white group of voters who have boosted him so far. He had devoted significant time and resources to Arizona, holding events there almost every day during the last week, traveling to the Mexican border and investing in television ads.
Mrs. Clinton was helped by Arizona rules that limited participation in the primary to Democratic Party members, excluding independent voters, who have tended to back Mr. Sanders. The state's large share of older voters, who strongly backed Mrs. Clinton in prior primaries, also made the state friendly territory for her. The state awards 75 delegates on a proportional basis.
Mr. Sanders continued to project confidence late Tuesday night, saying that his bid for the White House is generating energy and excitement.
"When we began this campaign, we were considered a fringe candidacy," the Vermont senator said after Mrs. Clinton was projected by the Associated Press to win Arizona. "Well, 10 months later, we have now won 10 primaries and caucuses and, unless I'm very mistaken, we're going to win a couple more tonight."
Mr. Sanders's campaign has argued that the second half of the primary season, starting with Tuesday's contests and heavy on Western states, would take the race to more favorable terrain. He not only needs to win states but to carry them by large margins in order to maximize his share of delegates.
Mrs. Clinton had swept through the South, then won all five states that held primaries last week. A look at the calendar reveals limited opportunities for the Vermont senator to eat into Mrs. Clinton's delegate lead.
Mr. Sanders could score several victories in Western states and beyond. But narrowing Mrs. Clinton's delegate lead will require him to notch landslides that produce big shares of available delegates.
An examination ofthe 28 contests stretching from now until mid-Juneshows opportunities for Mrs. Clinton to hold her lead or even build on it. As a presidential candidate in 2008, she faced then-Sen. Barack Obama in each of those states. She won 12 contests; Mr. Obama won 16.
But her 12 victories came in states and one territory, Puerto Rico, that in the 2016 primaries account for more than 1,400 delegates. By contrast, the 16 contests she lost in her last campaign offer only about 600 delegates this year.
To assess how the next phase of the race suits Mrs. Clinton, consider California. The state's June primary will allocate the biggest prize of the entire race, 475 delegates. In 2008, Mrs. Clinton won California easily, defeating Mr. Obama by eight points.
David Wasserman, a delegate analyst for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, wrote recently that Mr. Sanders could string together several victories in the West and then stall in the more diverse Northeastern states. "If there is bad news for Clinton, it's that the next month of primaries could give the false impression that Sanders is on track for a big comeback," Mr. Wasserman wrote.
Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook has described the former secretary of state's delegate lead as "nearly insurmountable."
---
Laura Meckler and Byron Tau contributed to this article.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: With Security Back in Focus, Trump, Clinton Win Arizona
article text:
The deadly terror attacks in Brussels abruptly refocused the agenda of the presidential race Tuesday, jolting the dwindling group of candidates into a renewed debate over who was best-equipped to protect America.
Republican front-runner Donald Trump, who won Tuesday's Arizona primary, suggested the attacks, for which Islamic State claimed responsibility, vindicated his aggressive rhetoric about Muslims and others. He also called for new laws that would allow torture when interrogating terror suspects. Leading Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton, who won her party's primary in Arizona, reiterated her experience as secretary of state and adopted her own tough tone by suggesting Europeans need to do more to control their borders.
It was Republican Sen. Ted Cruz who offered the starkest new plan, suggesting police in the U.S. should more aggressively police Muslim communities. "We need to empower law enforcement to patrol and secure Muslim neighborhoods before they become radicalized," Mr. Cruz said.
Under Mr. Cruz's plan, which Mr. Trump said he supports, the selection of which neighborhoods would receive increased patrols would depend on input from law enforcement, a person familiar with the proposal said.
Some of Mr. Cruz's backers had questions about the plan. "Generally every neighborhood is patrolled -- that's what local law enforcement does," said Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R., Kan.), who has endorsed Mr. Cruz. "I'm not quite sure what he has in mind, but without a doubt there's been no greater defender, no constitutional scholar greater than Ted Cruz in this race."
The attacks came as Utah was also holding its nominating contest Tuesday, while Democrats in Idaho held their caucuses.
This isn't the first time terrorist attacks have reshaped the contours of the presidential campaign. Deadly assaults last year in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., appeared to play to the strengths of Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton in their respective primary races.
Recently, the focus had returned to subjects like trade and the economy, but the explosions in Brussels made each of the campaigns immediately pivot. Mr. Cruz, in second place to Mr. Trump by GOP convention delegates, held two news conferences. Mrs. Clinton made unscheduled television appearances and hastily scheduled a Wednesday speech at Stanford University on counterterrorism.
Ohio Gov. John Kasich, a Republican, called on President Barack Obama to cut short his historic trip to Cuba to address the issue.
The attacks have the potential to further boost Mr. Trump, whose tough talk and far-reaching proposals aided him following previous terrorist attacks. Mr. Trump said Tuesday that investigators should use harsh interrogation techniques to pry information from Salah Abdeslam, who was arrested in Brussels last week and is accused of taking part in last year's Paris attacks.
"He may be talking, but he'll talk a lot faster with the torture," Mr. Trump said on CNN.
Mrs. Clinton, for her part, said the U.S. needs "to toughen our surveillance, our interception of communication" in order to prevent new attacks.
In calling for law enforcement to secure Muslim neighborhoods, Mr. Cruz waded into a policing tactic that some warned could further alienate religious minorities and violate people's rights.
Lorenzo Vidino, director of the program on extremism at George Washington University, said it was wrong to portray entire neighborhoods as overrun by terrorist networks. "This seems well beyond the scope, and can you imagine what kind of message it sends?" Mr. Vidino said.
The Cruz campaign rejected such criticism, saying law enforcement needed to act more aggressively and ignore "political correctness."
Mr. Cruz added, "If you have a neighborhood that is plagued by gang activity, it is standard and good law enforcement to stop the gang members and take them off the street."
The violent emergence of Islamic State in 2014, and its ability to inspire or direct massacres on five continents, has consumed law enforcement, intelligence, and military networks around the world. The next president will inherit these threats.
In the days after the December terror attack in California, Mr. Trump galvanized support by proposing to temporarily stop the immigration of Muslims into the U.S. The proposal spooked many GOP leaders but appeared to resonate with many primary voters.
The idea complemented other parts of Mr. Trump's foreign-policy platform, which would tighten U.S. borders and diminish engagement in the Middle East. On Monday, Mr. Trump took another step, suggesting the U.S. should contribute less to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and saying more of the NATO burden should be borne by European allies.
Messrs. Cruz and Kasich pounced on that recommendation following the attacks in Brussels.
"We must strengthen our alliances as our way of life," Mr. Kasich said in a statement.
For Mrs. Clinton, the Brussels attacks force a direct confrontation with a thorny question -- how to balance the need for government antiterrorism surveillance with the privacy rights of Americans.
Facing a liberal challenge from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primaries, Mrs. Clinton has long stressed the importance of civil liberties and the need for government restraint. In December, she gave a speech in Minnesota calling on the government and technology companies to "start working together to keep us safe from terrorists."
But with Mrs. Clinton zeroing in on the Democratic nomination after several big primary wins over Mr. Sanders, she sounded more hard-line on Tuesday. "I give quarter to nobody in being as focused as I can be," she said on CNN.
Speaking in Everett, Wash., Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton took aim at Mr. Trump, alluding to the role of the Internet in terrorist recruitment. "Some of my opponents want to build walls and shut the world off," she said. "Well, you tell me, how high does the wall have to be to keep the Internet out?"
She also sought to contrast her attitude toward American Muslims with that of the Republicans, saying Muslims could alert authorities to suspicious doings.
---
Josh Dawsey, Kristina Peterson and Laura Meckler contributed to this article.
Credit: By Damian Paletta

article name: An Empty Obama-Clinton-Sanders Plan on Drug Costs
article text:
President Obama's latest budget includes proposals -- echoed or one-upped on the presidential-campaign trail by Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton -- that would require pharmaceutical companies to release data on the cost of research and development (R&D) and the extent of discounts offered to insurers for each drug brought to market. Yet the key numbers already are disclosed freely -- and we know how to get better value from medicines and improve their affordability to patients.
The company I lead, Lilly, discloses its annual R&D spending in audited financial statements every year, like other public companies. Lilly's number for 2015 was $4.8 billion -- part of the $50 billion invested in R&D each year by the members of our industry association alone. That's more than 20% of all R&D spending by all U.S. businesses. Seen against that staggering total, the proposal to mandate the nearly impossible task of assembling drug-by-drug R&D-spending figures misses the whole point.
Pharmaceutical companies' R&D feeds innovation from the earliest identification of leads through to clinical trials, real-world data collection and the refinement of existing treatments. It includes the cost of myriad failures -- part of every scientific enterprise -- along with further research on approved medicines, right up to their patent expirations. Money made on the sale of today's new medicines feeds all of the indispensable streams in this complex ecosystem.
Averages are easy enough to come by -- a new academic study in the Journal of Health Economics says it takes about $2.6 billion in R&D investment per new medicine launched. Calculating a precise number for an individual product is quite another matter. Consider Lilly's investment of billions of dollars in R&D related to Alzheimer's disease over the last quarter century. Since there are several candidates in our pipeline that emerged from past work, to which future product and in what proportion should these costs be allocated? And to what end?
The key insight is beyond dispute. Developing medicines is risky, expensive and time-consuming, and everyone would be better off if it were less so. Rather than meaningless disclosure mandates, policy efforts instead should encourage whatever can be done, without compromising patient safety, to shave precious weeks off development and regulatory-approval timelines.
There are effective ways to do that. For example, pooling access to potential new molecules and sharing "pre-competitive" research on promising treatment paths could avoid costly duplication. Industry and the FDA could ramp up the use of "adaptive clinical trials" that refocus themselves based on real-time findings rather than starting over. And large-scale efforts to capture the real-world outcomes of treatments in genetically profiled patients -- and feed these insights back to R&D labs -- would accelerate progress significantly.
Mandating further disclosure of discounts negotiated by drug companies also is a route to nowhere. Lest anyone doubt that the discounts are substantial, allow me to report freely that the average net prices paid last year by Lilly's customers in the U.S. ranged from a high of 67% of list prices paid by commercial health plans to a low of 19% paid by government purchasers including Medicaid. That's right: The average discount off list price was more than 80% for government payers.
I'm not cherry-picking these figures -- they cover Lilly's entire portfolio of established products. But forcing Lilly, or other companies, to disclose product-by-product and payer-by-payer discounts would be an unprecedented affront to free-market competition.
The list prices of medicines that feed media sensationalism are paid by essentially no institutional or government buyer in a hotly competitive marketplace. Yet affordability remains a problem for many patients. That's because insured patients in the U.S. today pay an average of about 20% of their prescription-drug costs out-of-pocket compared with about 5% of their hospital costs. Some patients' cost shares are much worse -- due to complex insurance "tier" systems for drugs and the rise of "combined deductibles," in which drug expenses get lumped together with major-medical costs, and benefits hinge on reaching a high expense threshold.
The insurance bias against medicines needs to be addressed head-on, at the very least so that patients benefit from the savings negotiated by their insurers. Clearing the Food and Drug Administration's huge backlog of generic-drug applications would also be a great help.
Lilly and Anthem, a major insurer, recently asked for changes in federal regulations that make it difficult to set up "outcomes-based contracts." These would link payment for a drug to the presentation of evidence that patients achieved the health benefits expected from the drug, for example.
The realities that determine the cost of medicines to patients don't require mandated disclosures. They are as plain as day. They simply need to be acknowledged and acted upon rather than distorted and ignored.
---
Dr. Lechleiter, a chemist, is chairman, president and CEO of Eli Lilly and Company.
Credit: By John C. Lechleiter

article name: Clinton's Star Email Witness
article text:
The Justice Department is widely reported to have offered criminal immunity to Bryan Pagliano, the techie who set up Hillary Clinton's private email operation. Now that he has that get-out-of-jeopardy-free card, Mr. Pagliano also ought to be able to tell Congress and the public what he knows.
Last year Mr. Pagliano exercised his Fifth Amendment right not to testify about his role in maintaining a private email system for Mrs. Clinton when she was Secretary of State. But as GOP Senators Ron Johnson and Chuck Grassley wrote in a letter to him last week, "there is no longer reasonable cause for you to believe that discussing these matters with the relevant oversight committees could result in your prosecution." They want Mr. Pagliano to appear before the Homeland Security and Judiciary committees. (Attorney General Loretta Lynch on Wednesday refused to say if Justice had offered Mr. Pagliano immunity, but that's her standard operating procedure.)
Mr. Pagliano, who worked on Mrs. Clinton's 2008 campaign and then moved with her to State, could be a star witness. He presumably knows Mrs. Clinton's motive for the system; who at the State Department knew about and approved it; what security measures were in place; whether there were security breaches; and whether he was paid by Bill and Hillary in addition to his State salary.
Given his political ties to the Clintons, he may also know who outside the government also used her server -- in particular whether it was a clearinghouse for State Department and Clinton Foundation business. Mr. Pagliano also has emails from his own pagliano.com address that he has so far refused to turn over and that the Senators want to see.
Messrs. Johnson and Grassley point out that Congress has a unique interest in this testimony. The FBI is presumably not investigating whether Mrs. Clinton or her aides deliberately attempted to evade federal record-keeping or freedom-of-information laws because those statutes don't include criminal enforcement. Yet the country has a right to know if its top officials engaged in an organized effort to evade disclosure laws. Congress has an interest in that kind of oversight.
As a Clinton loyalist, Mr. Pagliano will no doubt resist appearing before Congress, but the Senators have the option of a subpoena. The public deserves to know the kind of government Mrs. Clinton would deliver if she becomes our next President.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Faces Test in Wooing Sanders Fans
article text:
LINCOLN, Neb. -- It is rare for the crowd to boo at a Bernie Sanders rally. When it happens, it is usually at the point he invokes the name of his opponent in the Democratic presidential race, Hillary Clinton.
With Mrs. Clinton holding a substantial lead in the race for convention delegates, many Sanders loyalists are grappling with an uncomfortable question: If he loses, would they back her?
Interviews with a number of Sanders supporters present an unclear picture. Some say they wouldn't vote for the former senator and secretary of state if she wins the party nomination. Others say they would, reluctantly. Still others see strengths in Mrs. Clinton and would unconditionally back her for the White House.
The Democratic primary fight has been nowhere near as divisive as the Republican one. Still, in a campaign stop Monday in Grand Rapids, Mich., Mrs. Clinton made clear she is aware of what might lie ahead as she talked about the hard-fought 2008 race against Barack Obama and her work in helping the nominee pull in her supporters once he wrapped up the nomination that June.
That effort wasn't entirely successful -- one pro-Clinton group held out and defiantly campaigned for Republican nominee John McCain.
"I had a lot of passionate supporters who did not feel like they wanted to support then-Sen. Obama. I worked as hard as I could. I nominated him at the convention. I made the case, because he and I shared a lot of the same views," she said. "I would hope to be able to enlist Bernie in helping me reach out to his supporters if I am so fortunate to be the nominee."
Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator, has given every indication he would endorse Mrs. Clinton if she wins the nomination. He says he likes and respects her and has set limits on how negative he is willing to go.
But it isn't clear how many of his die-hard supporters would fall in line. A February Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed half the Sanders supporters have a positive view of Mrs. Clinton, but 31% have a negative one. About four in 10 Sanders supporters say they worry about Mrs. Clinton's "ties to Wall Street and millions in speaking fees."
At a speech in Lincoln last week, Mr. Sanders elicited boos when he mentioned Wall Street donations collected by a pro-Clinton super PAC.
Kathleen Worcester, a 42-year-old who came to hear Mr. Sanders at a rally last week in Portland, Maine, said she is unsure of what she would do if her candidate doesn't win. Mrs. Clinton "seems like a moderate conservative to me," she said.
Clinton aides say she has long been mindful that, as a nominee, she would need the support of Sanders backers, many of whom see her as the embodiment of the establishment politics they hope the senator would vanquish.
At times, she has been sharply critical of Mr. Sanders -- the two candidates interrupted and talked over each other at a testy debate Sunday night in Flint, Mich. -- but she has also tried to direct her barbs at Republicans in hopes of unifying Democrats behind a common enemy.
"We have differences, but those differences pale in comparison to what we see going on with the Republicans right now," she said in Grand Rapids.
And she has offered overt outreach, particularly to the young voters who overwhelmingly favor Mr. Sanders.
For now, Mr. Sanders is doing nothing to endear the front-runner to his supporters. "There are many people, including my opponent, who want you to think kind of small," he said at a recent campaign stop.
Marcus Johnson, 24, one of about 10,000 people who came to hear Mr. Sanders speak at Michigan State University last week, said he would never vote for Mrs. Clinton and would consider backing the Green Party candidate.
"Honestly, I think she's a Republican," he said.
Others are open to supporting her, though some say unenthusiastically.
"It would be a definite vote against the GOP and not for Hillary," said Harriet Scureman, 71, of Norwalk, Conn.
On the other hand, Katherine Steinfield, 22, a senior at Michigan State who prefers Mr. Sanders, said Mrs. Clinton, as a woman, has had to overcome obstacles that Mr. Sanders never faced. "I think she's impressive, too," she said.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton and Sanders Clash --- Sparks fly over auto bailout and trade at seventh Democratic presidential debate
article text:
FLINT, Mich. -- The Democratic presidential contenders clashed over economic policy in a debate Sunday, with front-runner Hillary Clinton attacking rival Bernie Sanders for his opposition to a federal auto bailout and Mr. Sanders charging that Clinton-backed trade deals had helped destroy American cities like Detroit.
Both issues resonate deeply in Michigan, which holds a primary election Tuesday. The state is home to auto makers that benefited from a 2009 government bailout, but it also has lost jobs to trade as companies moved positions overseas.
It was their seventh debate, and the sharpest clash yet, with the candidates repeatedly interrupting and accusing each other of hypocrisy. Mrs. Clinton holds a commanding lead in delegates, even after weekend caucus wins for Mr. Sanders in Nebraska, Kansas and Maine. Mrs. Clinton won Saturday's Louisiana primary, which had the biggest delegate count.
Asked about a possible future confrontation with Republican front-runner Donald Trump, Mrs. Clinton predicted that his "bigotry, his bullying, his bluster are not going to wear well on the American people."
The Vermont senator stayed on offense. He blasted Mrs. Clinton's record, demanded she release transcripts of her Wall Street speeches and sharply critiqued her husband's record as president in the 1990s.
Mr. Sanders has been attacking Mrs. Clinton over trade, but Mrs. Clinton's hit on the auto bailout was a new and potent counter. Federal assistance for the industry was included in the Troubled Asset Relief Program, a $700 billion measure that was credited with keeping the nation's financial system from collapsing. The Senate vote to release the second half of those funds came in the waning days of the George W. Bush administration.
"The money was there and had to be released in order to save the American auto industry," said Mrs. Clinton, a former New York senator. "I voted to save the auto industry. He voted against the money."
Mr. Sanders defended his vote, saying he objected to the Wall Street bailout money. He said he wasn't willing to give taxpayer money to those companies due to what he called their own recklessness, greed and illegal behavior. "Let the billionaires themselves bail out Wall Street," he said. "I will be damned if it was the working people of this country who had to bail out the crooks on Wall Street."
Within minutes, the Sanders campaign sought to soften and clarify his position. Mr. Sanders supported the auto funds but not the Wall Street rescue, it said. Since they couldn't be separated, he opposed the bill.
Mrs. Clinton said the exchange proved her point that Mr. Sanders is a "one-issue candidate." Mr. Sanders didn't disagree, but said his "one issue is trying to rebuild a disappearing middle class."
Mr. Sanders attacked Mrs. Clinton's support for some free-trade agreements, such as Nafta, which eased trade rules with Mexico and other nations and was signed by former President Bill Clinton and backed by Mrs. Clinton when she was first lady. "You didn't need a Ph.D. in economics to understand that American workers should not be forced to compete against people in Mexico making 25 cents an hour," he said. He also criticized welfare reform and Wall Street deregulation legislation that he signed.
In each case, Mrs. Clinton replied that "if we're going to argue about the 1990s," then she preferred to talk about that era's robust job creation and broadly rising incomes.
Mrs. Clinton went after Mr. Sanders for opposing reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank, which provides financial support to help U.S. companies export their goods. Mr. Sanders called the entire enterprise "corporate welfare."
The debate was staged in Flint, a venue pushed by Mrs. Clinton to bring attention to a crisis that was triggered by a cost-cutting move that elevated the lead level in the city's water supply.
Mr. Sanders repeated his call for Republican Gov. Rick Snyder to resign, and for the first time, Mrs. Clinton agreed and added that if he doesn't resign, he should be recalled.
In a series of tweets sent during the debate, Mr. Snyder defended his record and said he is taking responsibility for the Flint crisis.
The pair also returned to one of their longtime disputes -- Mr. Sanders's backing of a 2005 law that provided gun makers legal immunity. In January, Mr. Sanders voiced support for legislation that would remove gun manufacturers' protections from liability. On Sunday, though, Mr. Sanders offered a more nuanced view, suggesting gun makers shouldn't be held responsible for actions of those who legally purchase firearms.
Credit: By Laura Meckler, Colleen McCain Nelson and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Election 2016: Poll: Clinton Has Lead In Michigan
article text:
Hillary Clinton is leading Sen. Bernie Sanders by a wide margin ahead of Tuesday's Michigan primary, and she would beat the two GOP front-runners in potential general-election matchups, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll showed.
In the contest for the Democratic nomination, Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, is polling at 57% in Michigan, compared with 40% for the Vermont senator, the survey found.
Donald Trump is the preferred pick of 41% of likely GOP primary voters, followed by Texas Sen. Ted Cruz at 22%. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio draws 17% support. John Kasich, the governor of neighboring Ohio, is last at 13%.
The results suggest that a significant challenge remains for GOP leaders who are trying to slow Mr. Trump's momentum after his dominant performance on SuperTuesday,on which he won seven states and opened up a big lead in delegates.On Thursday, Mitt Romney, the party's 2012 nominee and a Michigan native, delivered a full-throated takedown of the Republican front-runner.
But the survey bolsters at least one argument Republicans are making against the New York billionaire: He trails Mrs. Clinton by 16 percentage points in one of the states he predicts he could win in the fall, and he trails Mr. Sanders by 22 points. Mr. Romney lost Michigan -- 44% to 54% -- to President Barack Obama in 2012.
"The GOP's worries about the Trump candidacy seem well-founded in the contest for Michigan's 16 electoral votes," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, which conducted the poll. "Trump trails both Clinton and Sanders by substantially wider margins than Romney lost the state to Obama in 2012."
The decision by retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson to exit from the presidential race has had little impact on the field in his home state of Michigan, the poll finds. Conducted before Mr. Carson announced that he was leaving the campaign trail, the poll found him to be the top pick of 9% of likely GOP primary voters. When his support was distributed to voters' second-choice candidates, it was spread almost evenly among the rest of the field. All four candidates gained modest ground, and Mr. Trump's lead over Mr. Cruz shrank by 2 percentage points.
Mr. Trump's support in Michigan reflects his strengths in the 19 states that have already voted. He performs best among men, Republican primary voters who identify themselves as moderate, those who lack a college degree and voters who make less than $50,000 a year. He registers his highest support from GOP voters who don't actively practice a religion.
Mr. Cruz leads Mr. Trump among a single group -- the 16% of likely GOP primary voters who describe themselves as "very conservative."
In the Democratic primary, Mrs. Clinton holds large leads among African-Americans, drawing 76% to his 21%. Similar leads propelled Mrs. Clinton to victories in South Carolina, Georgia and other states with large shares of African-American voters. The two more or less split white Democratic primary voters in Michigan.
"Michigan is following a familiar story line," Mr. Miringoff said. "The greater the diversity of the Democratic electorate, the greater the Clinton lead."
The former secretary of state also crushes Mr. Sanders among registered Democrats, garnering almost twice as much support. He shows similar strength among independents, but they account for only 22% of likely Democratic primary voters, according to the poll.
Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Assails Business -- Selectively
article text:
Hillary Clinton sees the naughty and the nice in corporate America as she tries to channel populist anger without alienating too many businesses.
The Democratic presidential front-runner routinely condemns what she sees as corporate malfeasance, but she says other companies are job generators and good corporate citizens. She has rolled out tax proposals aimed at rewarding business practices she favors and punishments for what she sees as shortsighted and even unpatriotic moves.
In an address Friday in Detroit, Mrs. Clinton touted a resurgent auto industry and technological breakthroughs by Michigan manufacturers. But she also singled out Nabisco for laying people off in Chicago and moving production to Mexico.
"I'm not interested in condemning whole categories of business, or the entire private sector, of course not. But I do want to send a clear message to every boardroom and executive suite: If you cheat your employees, exploit consumers, you pollute our environment or rip off the taxpayers, we will hold you accountable," she said. "But do the right thing, invest in your workers and your country's future, and we will stand with you."
It is Mrs. Clinton's way of responding to her Democratic rival for the presidential nomination, Bernie Sanders, who issues sweeping, strongly worded condemnations of corporate America. A favorite line: "Corporate greed is destroying our economy."
Nabisco is only Mrs. Clinton's most recent target. Her campaign has aired at least two television ads directed at individual companies. In a spot that began airing Tuesday, she promised to go after Valeant Pharmaceuticals International for its "predatory pricing" after the company dramatically raised the price of a migraine treatment. A company spokeswoman replied that most people use the generic version.
In another ad last month, Mrs. Clinton stood in front of Johnson Controls Inc. in Milwaukee and criticized the company for a planned merger that would reduce its tax bill. "They're gaming the system and moving profits to Ireland so they can avoid paying taxes here at home," she said.
The company said its merger was meant to "drive innovation" and was part of a broader plan to grow in the U.S. and globally.
Mrs. Clinton also has singled out Turing Pharmaceuticals, which increased the price of a lifesaving drug. Her approach has something in common with Republican Donald Trump, who has criticized Ford Motor Co. and a subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., as well as Mondelez International Inc., Nabisco's parent company, for moving U.S. production facilities to Mexico.
On Friday, Mrs. Clinton slammed Nabisco for benefiting from tax breaks from the state of Illinois and then abandoning U.S. workers. She was referring to the situation in Chicago, where the company announced it was laying off 600 workers from its bakery and moving some production lines to Mexico.
"They have no problem taking taxpayer dollars with one hand and giving out pink slips with the other," she said. "If a company like Nabisco outsources and ships jobs overseas, we'll make you give back the tax breaks you receive here in America."
Mondelez spokeswoman Laurie Guzzinati replied that the company was planning to replace nine older production lines with four new ones, which would have reduced its workforce by about 300 people, anyway. She said the company decided to expand its facility in Salinas, Mexico, after concluding it could save $46 million a year.
Credit: By Laura Meckler and Richard Rubin

article name: Election 2016: Sanders, Clinton Spar on Trade in Midwest --- Senator attacks Nafta and Pacific deal, and front-runner promises job-creation policies
article text:
EAST LANSING, Mich. -- Trade and manufacturing took center stage as the Democratic presidential race moved to Michigan on Thursday, with Sen. Bernie Sanders talking up his longtime opposition to free trade agreements and Hillary Clinton's campaign promising policies that would support job creation.
Mr. Sanders, looking for a win in the industrial heartland, repeated his claim that Mrs. Clinton had supported "disastrous" trade agreements and suggested that her opposition to the pending Trans-Pacific Partnership wasn't sincere.
The former secretary of state plans to respond in a speech at an auto supplier in Detroiton Friday. Advisers said that Mrs. Clinton would propose ways to create jobs by boosting manufacturing, and that she was willing to back trade agreements only if they met her standards.
"The answer can't be to shut down all trade," said Jake Sullivan, Mrs. Clinton's senior policy adviser. He said the key is backing "smart and fair trade, where American workers get a level playing field with the rest of the world."
The candidates have been debating these points for months, but the issues are taking on new urgency with the approach of Tuesday's primary in Michigan, a state long reliant on manufacturing that has suffered steep job losses.
The issue is sure to be litigated when Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton debate on Sunday in Flint, Mich.
Mr. Sanders is banking on a win in Michigan for fresh momentum after losing seven of the 11 states that voted on Tuesday and falling well behind in the delegate count. His top aides refer to the Michigan contest as a "showdown" that will influence the course of the race.
On Thursday, Mr. Sanders fired the first salvo. At a news conference here, surrounded by union workers, he said he had consistently opposed trade deals and suggested that Mrs. Clinton can't be trusted to stop them if elected president.
Mr. Sanders said that trade agreements such as Nafta, signed by Mrs. Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, have eliminated jobs in the U.S. as corporations have moved operations to countries that pay lower wages.
He rattled off various trade agreements that Mrs. Clinton backed and that he had opposed. "On the issue of trade, Secretary Clinton's views and mine are very different," Mr. Sanders said.
He also pointed to Mrs. Clinton's original kind words for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation deal that is one of the Obama administration's key priorities. As secretary of state, Mrs. Clinton called it the "gold standard," but she came out against it once it was completed in October, six months into her presidential campaign.
"She was very reluctant to come out in opposition," Mr. Sanders said. "She is running for president. She concluded it was a good idea to oppose the TPP, and she did."
The Sanders campaign also is airing a TV ad in Michigan that says Mr. Sanders has been steadfast in opposing trade deals "while others waffle."
Mrs. Clinton has said she evaluates trade agreements on a case-by-case basis, supporting some but not others. As a senator from New York, Mrs. Clinton opposed a Central American Free Trade Agreement but supported deals with Australia, Singapore and several other nations.
Mr. Sullivan didn't answer directly when asked whether, if elected president, Mrs. Clinton would try to make changes to the Asian deal to get it approved. He said that she believes "we need to have a very serious conversation about the future of trade." He said that should include how to prevent a "race to the bottom" among trading partners, and that Mrs. Clinton wants a "hard think" about what it would take to construct trade agreements that raise working standards.
Clinton aides said that in her Friday speech, she would present a broad vision for bolstering U.S. jobs. Mr. Sullivan said she would lay out a "new bargain for a new economy" that extends to coal country and cities such as Detroit.
She has already laid out several small-scale proposals for bolstering manufacturing, including tax breaks to encourage investment in hard-hit areas and better enforcement of trade agreements.
Mr. Sullivan charged that Mr. Sanders didn't have a manufacturing plan of his own, and said he was wrong to oppose reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank, which provides financing to support some major domestic manufacturers. On that issue, Mr. Sanders aligned with conservatives in opposing what he called "corporate welfare to multinational corporations."
The Clinton campaign also called in backing from Michigan's Sen. Debbie Stabenow. The senator said that Mrs. Clinton "totally gets it" when it comes to manufacturing and jobs. "You don't have an economy, you don't have a middle class, unless somebody makes something," she said.
Credit: By Laura Meckler By Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Front-Runner Keys on Black Vote --- Clinton looks to one of her main voting blocs as she seeks to close out Democratic race
article text:
MILWAUKEE -- Looking to close out the contest against rival Bernie Sanders, Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton is stepping up her outreach to the voters who vaulted her to a dominant position in the race for delegates: African-Americans.
Coming off a trio of lopsided losses last weekend in the West, Mrs. Clinton still enjoys a commanding delegate lead, though the path to the nomination figures to be bumpy. Her advisers concede she will have a tough time in the next big primary, in Wisconsin on April 5,and Mr. Sanders is going all-in for the New York contest two weeks later, hoping for an upset in Mrs. Clinton's home state.
With no sign the Vermont senator will step aside, Mrs. Clinton is signaling she will lean heavily on black voters to capture the delegates needed for the nomination.
She has sought to showcase her ties to African-Americans over the past few days in Wisconsin. Accompanied by local African-American congresswoman Gwen Moore, she led a forum on gun violence Tuesday at a Baptist church in a Milwaukee neighborhood that is more than 90% black.
A panel at the event gave graphic accounts of sons and daughters killed by guns. Sitting by Mrs. Clinton was Annette Nance-Holt, whose high-school son Blair Holt was shot dead on a Chicago bus in 2007.
"I applaud Secretary Clinton for reaching out to us, because that other candidate on the Democratic side did not reach out to us," Ms. Nance-Holt said.
Still, Barry Burden,a political-science professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said the state has too few African-American voters to put Mrs. Clinton over the top.
"Her strength is in the African-American community, but it's smaller in Wisconsin than in the other Midwestern states," he said.
African-Americans make up 6.6% of the Wisconsin population, according to Census data.
Brian Fallon, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary, said a number of factors in Wisconsin, including the state's open primary, which makes it easier for independents to have a say, and its progressive bent, put Mr. Sanders in a good position. But even if the senator "edges out a victory" in Wisconsin, that isn't likely to significantly erode Mrs. Clinton's delegate lead, he said. "Regardless of the outcome in Wisconsin, we expect to compete strongly in the state," Mr. Fallon said.
Delegates are awarded proportionally in Democratic primaries and caucuses.
On Wednesday in New York, where 247 delegates are up for grabs, Mrs. Clinton campaignedat the Apollo Theater in Manhattan, an iconic venue for black performers.
Perhaps more than any other voting group, African-Americans have defined the Democratic race. Mrs. Clinton racked up large delegate leads on March 1 with landslide wins in Georgia, Alabama and other Southern states where blacks account for a hefty share of the Democratic electorate.
In a recent conference call with reporters, Sanders advisers said they chose not to compete in these states, realizing Mrs. Clinton had advantages the senator couldn't overcome. Instead, the campaign looked farther North and West, hoping their victories in Oklahoma, Colorado and Minnesota would prove the senator could go toe-to-toe with the former Secretary of State.
Some Democratic strategists say this was a mistake.
"It is too late for them to figure out a strategy to garner support from the African-American community," said Tharon Johnson, who served as the southern regional director for President Barack Obama's 2012 campaign.
Jaime Harrison, chairman of the South Carolina Democratic Party, said Mrs. Clinton has assembled a coalition that resembles then-Sen. Barack Obama's support base in 2008.
"If she can maintain her strong support with communities of color, she will get to the finish line with the most pledged delegates," he said.
Sanders campaign aides said the senator has made progress with African-Americans, pointing to his upset win in Michigan, where he won 30% of the black vote.
Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said on the conference call that the candidate was largely unknown in the African-American community when the race began. But Mr. Sanders's history of civil-rights activism and his policy agenda should resonate with black voters as they get to know him, he said.
"We have worked very hard and will continue to work hard all the way through to the end in trying to make sure that African-American voters first of all know his story," he said.
But is it too late?
Four states -- New York, New Jersey, California and Pennsylvania -- account for about 60% of the 1,747 remaining delegates. All are racially diverse states that Mrs. Clinton won in her 2008 bid.
Clinton strategist Joel Benenson said recently Mr. Sanders is running out of "real estate" to erase her lead.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Ad In New York Takes Aim At Trump
article text:
Hillary Clinton on Wednesday released her first TV ad aimed at New York voters ahead of the state's primary on April 19, and it has one target: Donald Trump.
Mrs. Clinton's rival for the Democratic nomination remains Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, but with a large delegate lead in the Democratic presidential race, she increasingly has been shifting her focus to her potential opponent in the general election.
The 30-second spot, narrated by Mrs. Clinton, doesn't mention Mr. Trump by name. But it is filled with references to his candidacy and brand.
The ad invokes some of the themes from Mr. Trump's campaign, notably his call for building a wall on America's southern border and his proposal to temporarily bar Muslims from entering the U.S. Mrs. Clinton says, "When some say we can solve America's problems by building walls, banning people based on their religion and turning against each other. . . Well, this is New York. And we know better."
With 247 delegates at stake, New York is the biggest prize left in the Democratic primary race except for California, whose primary is set for June 7. Mrs. Clinton represented the state in the Senate for eight years before signing on as President Barack Obama's secretary of state in 2009.
Earlier this year, Mr. Trump said in an interview with the Hill that he would "expand the map" in a general election and that he would have a "real good shot" at winning New York, a state that typically favors Democratic presidential candidates. "This is my place," the New York businessman said. "I love New York."
Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: U.S. News: Plaintiffs In Clinton Case Get New Boost
article text:
A second federal judge Tuesday granted a conservative group the right to gather evidence in connection with its effort to access some of Hillary Clinton's records from her time at the State Department.
Judge Royce Lamberth of the federal District Court for the District of Columbia ruled that the group, Judicial Watch, was entitled to discovery in its lawsuit seeking access to information about the State Department's handling of the 2012 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya. Mrs. Clinton, now the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, was secretary of state at the time.
The judge wrote Tuesday that the government's "constantly shifting admissions" about its search for records that Judicial Watch requested gave him reason to grant discovery.
"Whether the State Department's actions will ultimately be determined by the Court to not be 'acting in good faith' remains to be seen at this time," Judge Lamberth wrote, "but plaintiff is clearly entitled to discovery and a record before this Court rules on that issue."
In a suit filed in July 2014, Judicial Watch seeks records from Mrs. Clinton and her staff regarding the Benghazi attacks and other records of Susan Rice, who was U.S. ambassador to the United Nations at the time of the attack and is now President Barack Obama's national security adviser. The group didn't name Mrs. Clinton in the suit.
A State Department official said the department is reviewing Judge Lamberth's discovery order and declined to comment further on the case. Representatives for Mrs. Clinton didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.
Judge Lamberth, a Ronald Reagan appointee who has a long history of handling cases involving the Clinton administration, noted in his order that it is "exceedingly rare" to grant limited discovery in Freedom of Information Act cases. But he is already the second federal judge to do so in cases involving Mrs. Clinton's emails.
U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan, a Bill Clinton appointee, in February granted Judicial Watch's request forlimited discovery in a separate lawsuit against the State Department over Mrs. Clinton's email practices while she was secretary of state.
In its discovery request in that case, also filed in the District of Columbia federal court, Judicial Watch seeks to question eight current and former State Department officials.
Judge Sullivan is expected to rule on Judicial Watch's plan in that case afterApril 15. After Judge Sullivan's discovery order is issued, Judicial Watch will have 10 days to file a discovery plan tailored to the Susan Rice suit, Judge Lamberth ruled on Tuesday.
Credit: By Kate O'Keeffe

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Digs In as Trump Moves On
article text:
Jessica Flannery spent the first half of March in Democrat Hillary Clinton's Des Moines campaign office with three dozen other volunteers, calling the front-runner's supporters in Iowa to ensure they showed up at county conventions and were elected delegates to the national party gathering in July.
Republican front-runner Donald Trump's campaign, meanwhile, sent an email to local Republicans just before the statewide county convention inviting them to sign up to be a delegate for him. The campaign followed up a few days later with an apology, telling email recipients they weren't eligible to be delegates unless they'd already enrolled as one at local precincts.
"It did not evidence a robust organization," said Matt Strawn, a former Iowa GOP chairman who received one of the emails. Mr. Trump also has stopped paying his top two Iowa operatives, whose contracts expired last month -- weeks after the state's first-in-the-nation caucuses were held.
As Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump aim to clinch their parties' nominations, the former secretary of state is poised to start the general-election campaign with a far more sophisticated operation in key swing states than the businessman.
"It unequivocally is helpful for a campaign that spent a year-plus working in Iowa to keep some people in play," said David Oman, a former Iowa state GOP co-chairman and senior political adviser to former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, who quit the race last month. "It would be a mistake to let people go. . .and then have to put the team back together again to marshal a general-election campaign."
Mr. Trump has largely eschewed implementing a traditional ground game, instead relying on large rallies and his star power to turn out voters. As a consequence, strategists in Iowa and New Hampshire say there's little left of his already-sparse operations in the states.
Mr. Trump's Iowa state director, Chuck Laudner, is no longer working for the campaign, the longtime Iowa operative confirmed. He was paid $21,000 at the end of February, down from nearly $35,000 for the month before the Iowa caucuses.
Deputy state director Ryan Keller also said his contract with the campaign had ended, and said he hadn't "put that much thought" into whether he would rejoin for the general election. The campaign's primary remaining operative in the state is Tana Goertz, a former contestant on Mr. Trump's reality TV show, "The Apprentice."
The Trump campaign didn't return a request for comment.
After Mr. Trump placed second in Iowa, he criticized his own campaign's operations there. "I think we could have used a better ground game, a term I wasn't even familiar with," he told MSNBC in the days after the Iowa caucuses. "I would've funded a better ground game, but people told me my ground game was fine."
In New Hampshire, where Mr. Trump's campaign manager Corey Lewandowski previously served as state director for a pro-free market group backed by billionaires Charles and David Koch, Mr. Trump ran a similarly thin operation. "Mr. Trump never really had any infrastructure to begin with," said Jamie Burnett, a Republican strategist who worked on Mitt Romney's 2008 campaign. "When he left town, they packed up the three-ring circus and they sent the public-relations campaign to another state."
Mr. Burnett, who supported Mr. Bush before he left the GOP race, said that if Mr. Trump becomes the nominee, he will be "starting from scratch" in New Hampshire. "They're going to have to hope that a big, large-scale PR campaign can beat someone like Clinton, and I just don't think it can," he said.
Mr. Trump's unorthodox operation has proven to be mostly successful. He has won the majority of states and has a lead of nearly 300 delegates over Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. Yet GOP strategists say a general-election terrain -- in which he would face a single opponent -- could offer a tougher test of his campaign strategy.
Mrs. Clinton's operation, which had 26 offices in Iowa in the lead-up to the state's Feb. 1 caucuses, has left one open, where Ms. Flannery, an organizing director for Naral Pro-Choice, manned six phone banks this month.
Clinton spokeswoman Jennifer Palmieri said this month that building a volunteer base in primary states is an "investment for the general election." She pointed to the importance of the databases in states that are battlegrounds in the general election. "Those are useful audiences that you want to reach repeatedly," she said.
---
Laura Meckler contributed to this article.
Credit: By Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Biden-Clinton Friction Hangs Over Campaign
article text:
Democrats worried about Hillary Clinton's electoral weaknesses see Vice President Joe Biden as a potential solution -- as long as the two former cabinet colleagues and sometime rivals can smooth their complicated relationship.
Mrs. Clinton's vulnerabilities were apparent over the weekend when she suffered lopsided losses to rival Sen. Bernie Sanders in Democratic caucuses in Washington, Hawaii and Alaska. The trio of states contain either many white voters or veer to the left wing of the Democratic Party, two constituencies where Mrs. Clinton has struggled.
Mr. Biden, who often talks about his upbringing in Scranton, Pa., in a family that endured financial hardships, has shown an affinity with working-class whites that could help overcome doubts about Mrs. Clinton's candidacy. He appears willing to hit the trail for the potential Democratic ticket.
Looming over the possible collaboration, however, are tensions between two of the nation's most important Democrats: a sitting vice president and a former secretary of state who might wind up with the job he has long coveted.
In one notable instance, Mr. Biden said in a January television interview that Mrs. Clinton was "relatively new" to the issue of income inequality and that no one doubted Mr. Sanders's "authenticity" on that issue.
