In a New York City metro area that is home to some of the richest and the poorest Americans, Mr. Sanders will focus on income inequality, and on Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street, said Tad Devine, his senior strategist.
Thursday'stiff over whether Mrs. Clinton is qualified or not began when the New York Daily News published an interview with Mr. Sanders. Mrs. Clinton was asked three times on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" whether, in light of the interview, she thinks he is qualified to be president.
"I think the interview raised a lot of really serious questions," she said. "I will leave it to voters to decide who of us can do the job that the country needs."
The Washington Post, writing about the interview, included a headline that said she had questioned whether he was qualified. Mr. Sanders seized on that.
"When you have headlines in the Washington Post -- quote 'Clinton questions whether Sanders is qualified to be president,' my response is, well you know, if you want to question my qualifications let me suggest this, then maybe the American people might wonder about your qualifications, Madam Secretary," he said Thursday.
He suggested her past support for trade agreements, her vote to authorize the Iraq war and support from Wall Street interests disqualified her for the job.
Mrs. Clinton needs to drive up her support among women, particularly suburban women, a campaign adviser said. Mr. Sanders's comment could help with that, said George Arzt, a political consultant who is unaffiliated in the race.
"I think there are many people who view Hillary -- whether they like her or not -- as the most experienced and qualified in the field," he said. "There are many women who believe that the 'unqualified' title has been used too often against women looking for better jobs."
Credit: By Laura Meckler and Erica Orden

article name: Donald Trump's Antiterror Plans Rebuked by Leaders of Both Parties; Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton and GOP House Speaker Paul Ryan all rejected Muslim immigration ban
article text:
WASHINGTON--President Barack Obama and presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton denounced Donald Trump on Tuesday, saying his proposed antiterrorism policies would make America less safe--while the highest-ranking elected official in Mr. Trump's own party, House Speaker Paul Ryan, also rejected the presumptive GOP nominee's response to the Orlando shooting .
In response, Mr. Trump countered that the president "prioritizes our enemy" over the American people amid their rapidly escalating fight over how to best stop terrorist attacks.
In remarks in Washington, Mr. Obama took aim at the Mr. Trump's renewed call to bar Muslims from entering the country. He said such an approach toward immigrants would only serve to alienate American Muslims as well and weaken America's defenses.
"Are we going to start treating all Muslim Americans differently?" Mr. Obama asked. "It doesn't reflect our democratic ideals. It won't make us more safe, it will make us less safe," Mr. Obama said.
Groups like Islamic State "want to claim that they are the true leaders of over a billion Muslims around the world who reject their crazy notions," Mr. Obama said. The president warned that "painting all Muslims with a broad brush" only advances terrorists' claims that the West is the enemy.
Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, knocked Mr. Trump on Tuesday in Pittsburgh with a similar message to Mr. Obama's, calling her rival's approach "un-American" and "dangerous."
Mr. Trump fired back, saying: "President Obama claims to know our enemy, and yet he continues to prioritize our enemy over our allies, and for that matter, the American people. When I am president, it will always be America First."
In a tweet to the "LGBT community," Mr. Trump pledged: "I will fight for you while Hillary brings in more people that will threaten your freedoms and beliefs."
The heated debate over terrorism and immigration policy takes place as Mr. Trump is working to unite the Republican Party behind him. While he has the support of the Republican National Committee and many prominent Republicans, his controversial statements and policy stances continue to give some allies pause.
Mr. Ryan, who recently agreed to back Mr. Trump , said on Tuesday that the U.S. should tighten its screening process of refugees entering the country, rather than impose a religious test as Mr. Trump proposes.
"I do not think a Muslim ban is in our country's interest. I do not think it is reflective of our principles--not just as a party, but as a country," Mr. Ryan said.
The fight has been boiling up for several days. Mr. Trump used an appearance in New Hampshire on Monday to attack both Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton, portraying them as weak on foreign policy and national security.
"The bottom line is that the only reason the killer was in America in the first place was because we allowed his family to come here," Mr. Trump said about Omar Mateen, the U.S.-born man police have said was the gunman. His parents emigrated to the U.S. from Afghanistan.
In an earlier television interview, Mr. Trump also suggested that Mr. Obama was sympathetic to Islamic terrorists .
Related Reading
* Donald Trump Goes On Offense, Blaming President

* Trump Suggests Obama Sympathetic to Islamic Terrorists

* Radical Islamic Terrorism? Language Wars Flare Again

* Remembering the Orlando Victims

* Orlando Shooting: Survivor, Responding Doctors Recount 'War Zone'

* Orlando Shooting Plays Into FBI's Homegrown-Terror Worries

* Before Orlando Shooter's Routine Last Days, Hints of Instability

"Look, we're led by a man that either is not tough, not smart, or he's got something else in mind," Mr. Trump said on Fox News on Monday. "And the something else in mind--you know, people can't believe it. People cannot, they cannot believe that President Obama is acting the way he acts and can't even mention the words 'radical Islamic terrorism.' There's something going on. It's inconceivable. There's something going on."
Mr. Obama also leveled his sights at his critics, including Mr. Trump, who have criticized him for failing to use the term "radical Islam" to describe terrorist attacks.
"Calling a threat by a different name does not make it go away," Mr. Obama said. "There is no magic to the phrase 'radical Islam.' It is a political talking point. It is not a strategy."
Mrs. Clinton also said Mr. Trump was fixated on "radical Islam" as a magic word that "once uttered, would stop terrorists."
Usually Mr. Obama's remarks after National Security Council meetings are battlefield assessments, but on Tuesday he revealed his frustrations with the tenor of the campaign cycle with a fiery rebuke.
"There is not been a moment in my seven and a half years as president where we have not been able to pursue a strategy because we didn't use the label 'radical Islam.' Not once has an adviser of mine said, 'Man, if we use that phrase, we are going to turn this whole thing around.' Not once," Mr. Obama said.
Mr. Obama personally worked on the remarks he gave Tuesday. White House press secretary Josh Earnest said. Mr. Earnest said he wasn't aware of any direct coordination with the Clinton campaign on his remarks, but said the similarity wasn't a coincidence.
"President Obama and Secretary Clinton have similar approaches and consider the homeland security of the United States a top priority," Mr. Earnest said. "They agree that these are principles worth fighting for and articulating and that the use of the word 'radical Islam' is a political talking point."
Credit: By Byron Tau and Felicia Schwartz

article name: Analysis: Jobs Downturn Mars Clinton's Narrative
article text:
A slowdown in hiring this year threatens a record-long streak of jobs creation that Democrats see as one of their prime advantages in the fight to retain the White House this November, creating a possible headache for Hillary Clinton.
While one payrolls report in June won't define a long general-election campaign, voters' perceptions of the election-year economy begin to crystallize around this time of year. On the campaign trail, Mrs. Clinton has closely aligned herself with President Barack Obama on a wide range of issues, including the economy.
"If you're Hillary Clinton, you're rooting for stronger jobs reports coming down the stretch here," said David Axelrod, the former senior adviser to Mr. Obama. "A series of disappointing jobs reports would be headwinds for Hillary."
The employment numbers landed days before Tuesday's closely watched California primary, when Mrs. Clinton hopes to wrap up her party's nomination after a hard-fought campaign against Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
The report also followed on the heels of Mr. Obama's defense of his economic stewardship in an Indiana speech, where he declared Americans better off "by almost every economic measure," and called on voters to build on his policies by electing a Democrat.
Economists aren't predicting an imminent recession, but Friday's report showed other signs of softness.
The internals of Friday's report showed that many of last month's labor-force dropouts are middle-aged workers and those with less education, demographics that have been drawn more to Mr. Sanders and presumptive GOP nominee Donald Trump. Monthly data tends to be volatile, but while employment has been down for most age groups since the last recession began in late 2007, younger and middle-aged men have experienced the largest declines.
Republicans were quick to hit on the lousy numbers. Mr. Trump tweeted that the report was "terrible" and a "bombshell" a few minutes after its release. The Republican National Committee called the jobs numbers "devastating."
"The timing is especially unfortunate for Democrats because the president has just declared that this is a great economy," said Douglas Holtz-Eakin, who was economic policy director for John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign.
Mrs. Clinton defended the president's record on the economy, pointing to 75 straight months of job creation and saying that Mr. Obama inherited a terrible situation and pulled the country out of a ditch. Electing Mr. Trump would mean a return to failed Republican policies, she told CNN on Friday.
She added the latest numbers "are disappointing to anybody, because we want to keep jobs growing." She said her plan to invest in infrastructure projects would create jobs.
The White House put the best gloss on the numbers, with economic adviser Jason Furman reminding reporters that the strike by workers at Verizon Communications Inc. shaved 35,000 workers from payrolls last month. He also pointed to wage growth that has perked up this year.
Democrats also pointed out that the jobless rate is around half of what it was seven years ago, stock prices have nearly doubled, and home prices are up around 20%.
But if the May report isn't a one-off, Mr. Holtz-Eakin said, Mrs. Clinton would need to deflect suggestions that her election would amount to a third Obama term. " 'It's great under Barack Obama' isn't going to sound very good if this continues," he said.
Polls have shown that the economy is one area where Mr. Trump has an edge over Mrs. Clinton. A May Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found that 47% of registered voters said Mr. Trump would do a better job dealing with the economy, compared with 36% for Mrs. Clinton.
Moreover, independent voters' views appear to line up more closely with Republicans on the economy. In the same poll, some 52% of Democrats said the 2007-2009 recession still had a significant effect on people, compared to 68% of Republicans and 66% of independents.
The current expansion, now entering its eighth year, is the fourth-longest in the postwar period. Economists at J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. saidFriday the probability the U.S. would enter a recession in the next 12 months had climbed to 36%, the highest for the current expansion cycle.
Other measures show better near-term growth prospects. Housing sales have risen steadily higher this year, as have auto sales. Manufacturing surveys have rebounded after last year's contraction, and the share of workers who said their employer was hiring in May reached the highest level tracked by Gallup since 2008.
Political scientists point to two gauges that rise above the rest in determining whether the incumbent party can hold the White House: the president's approval rating and the economic growth trend in the first half of the election year. Mr. Obama's approval rating in recent weeks has climbed above 50%, returning to levels last seen since his 2012 election, according to Gallup.
But economic growth has been unremarkable. Economists see growth rising above 2% in the second quarter after just 0.8% in the first quarter.
History shows how often elections turn on the economy. In 2008, what began as a referendum on the Iraq war broke for Mr. Obama against Mr. McCain when an economic slowdown turned into a financial crisis. In 2012, Mr. Obama defeated Mitt Romney even though the unemployment rate stood above 8% for most of the campaign, partly because job growth and consumer confidence were firming.
Democrats enter the election at something of a disadvantage because in the postwar period, only once, with George H.W. Bush in 1988, has a nominee succeeded a two-term president of his own party.


Credit: By Nick Timiraos and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Closes Polling Gap With Clinton --- Tight race weighs on the Democratic front- runner as she tries to pivot to November
article text:
Sen. Bernie Sanders has all but eliminated Hillary Clinton's polling lead among Democratic voters nationwide, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll has found, offering signs that she continues to struggle with the primary electorate at a time when she wanted to build strength for the general election.
Mr. Sanders for the first time is close to tying Mrs. Clinton, as 48% of Democratic primary voters picked him as their first choice for president, while 50% picked her. In a poll last month, Mrs. Clinton was ahead by 9 percentage points, a 53%-to-44% edge.
A majority of states have already held their primary contests, and the Vermont senator's surge in support likely comes too late for him to overcome Mrs. Clinton's big lead in delegates to the summer nominating convention in Philadelphia. But the survey suggests that the long and bitter primary campaign has taken a toll on the former senator and secretary of state.
"As she is finishing this primary, she is not gaining strength," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who conducted the survey with Democrat Fred Yang. "The cracks are showing, and she is losing strength."
Mrs. Clinton's saving grace is the weakness of her potential Republican opposition. The survey found that GOP front-runner Donald Trump would have a harder time consolidating his party behind him than she would hers. Some 38% of Republican primary voters said they couldn't see themselves supporting the New York businessman, while 21% of Democrats said they couldn't support Mrs. Clinton.
In a hypothetical general election matchup, Mrs. Clinton outpolls Mr. Trump 50% to 39%, the survey found.
But for most voters, that would be a lesser-of-two-evils choice: 56% of both Trump and Clinton voters said their vote would be cast because they didn't want the other candidate to win.
"For these voters, casting their ballot for president in 2016 is not about an idealistic vision of hope and change or a new day in America," Mr. Yang said, "but, rather, a much more sober and pragmatic feeling as they check the box: It could be worse."
Among Republicans, Mr. Trump has maintained his advantage as the field of candidates dwindled. He is the first choice of 40% of GOP primary voters, compared with 35% for Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and 24% for Ohio Gov. John Kasich.
But the poll could fuel his rivals' argument that Mr. Trump would be the party's weakest candidate against Mrs. Clinton in November: Mr. Cruz trails her by two points, 46% to 44%, in a hypothetical matchup, while Mr. Kasich outpolls her, 51% to 39%.
The two parties' front-runners are making history with the negative feelings they inspire. The share of voters who feel negatively toward Mr. Trump, at 65%, or Mrs. Clinton, at 56%, is unprecedented for a major-party nominee. By comparison, President Barack Obama was viewed in a negative light by 43%, and Republican nominee Mitt Romney by 44%, at the end of the 2012 general-election campaign.
"America is on the path to electing the most unpopular president since 1948," said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who also helped conduct the survey.
Measuring the front-runners' qualities of character, the poll found that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump are worse for the wear over the past six months.
Voters still rate Mrs. Clinton highly for the knowledge and experience she would bring to the office. But over the past six months, she has lost ground on two crucial qualities: Voters, including those in her own party, are less likely to see her as an agent of change and as honest and straightforward.
Just 22% of registered voters give her high marks for being able to bring real change to the country. Even among Democratic primary voters, the share giving her high marks dropped to 41%, down from 57% in October.
On being honest and straightforward, just 19% rate her highly. Among Democratic primary voters, those rating her highly dropped to 40%, from 52% in October.
Mr. Trump has also lost ground on key points. Voters are less likely to give him high marks on his signature claim: that he can get things done. Some 38% rate him highly on that quality, down from 48% in October. Among Republican voters, 64% rate him highly for effectiveness, down from 72%.
While "telling it like it is" is Mr. Trump's calling card, fewer voters now see him as honest and straightforward. The share who rated Mr. Trump highly on being honest and straightforward was 35%, down from 43% in October.
Asked which party is better equipped to handle foreign policy, voters picked the Democrats by a three-point margin. By a narrow margin, voters also saw the Democratic Party as better able to handle immigration.
That could fuel some Republicans' concern that the party's standing would suffer from Mr. Trump's harsh rhetoric about illegal immigration and his support for a reduced role for the U.S. military in world affairs.
But Mr. McInturff, the Republican pollster, said he didn't see signs that Mr. Trump was doing any "damage to the Republican Party that is irreparable."
Mr. Sanders's strong support among primary voters continued a steady narrowing of the gap since January, when Mrs. Clinton led by 25 points, 59% to 34%. In June 2015, a Journal/NBC News poll found Mrs. Clinton leading the Democratic contest by 60 percentage points, 75% to 15%.
Credit: By Janet Hook

article name: Election 2016 --- CAPITAL JOURNAL: The Damage Sanders's Clinton Bashing May Do
article text:
As the big New York primary election arrives, it would be a mistake to say the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination is dragging on with no end in sight. Despite tightening poll numbers, it's dragging on with a likely end still in sight: Hillary Clinton prevailing, both in New York and nationwide, because the delegate math works inexorably in her favor.
So the question increasingly is this: How much damage is she absorbing at the hands of Sen. Bernie Sanders in the meantime?
The answer: The damage is hardly fatal but it is starting to matter, especially in Mrs. Clinton's standing with crucial independent voters. The specific problem isn't merely that Mr. Sanders's tone has turned more harsh in attacking her. The particular problem is that his critique increasingly focuses on declaring she can't be trusted because she takes campaign contributions from big banks and big business. That is a line of attack that seems almost designed to hit Mrs. Clinton in her area of greatest vulnerability, which is voter doubts about her honesty and trustworthiness. The pattern continued Monday when the Sanders campaign accused the Clinton camp of possibly violating campaign-finance laws, prompting Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook to declare that "the Sanders campaign's false attacks have gotten out of hand."
Of course, this is the stage of a tough election race when it's common for partisans in either party -- or this year, in both parties -- to lament that a bruising primary season is hurting their chances for victory in the general election. And frequently those concerns turn out to be overblown. Certainly, Democrats lamented the length and tone of the long Barack Obama-Hillary Clinton fight in 2008, and that fight turned out to be, if anything, helpful in tuning up Mr. Obama for a big November win.
"I think Sanders is hurting Clinton with Republicans -- but they wouldn't have voted for her anyway," says Democratic pollster Mark Mellman. "With Democrats and independents the effect is minimal. So real impact is marginal at best."
Still, there is impact, as suggested by a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll that showed the share of voters who hold a negative view of Mrs. Clinton continues to grow. Perhaps of most concern to Democrats are the signs of souring views among independent voters. In January, the share of independent voters who had positive views of Mrs. Clinton stood at 35%, while 54% had negative views. In the new survey, just 20% of independents had positive views, while 62% had negative views.
There even is evidence of damage among soft Democrats -- that is, people who lean Democratic but aren't core partisans. Among that group, the share holding negative views of Mrs. Clinton grew to 32% this month from 21% in January.
Celinda Lake, a longtime Democratic pollster, thinks the "aggressive" Sanders tone is likely to backfire with Democratic women, who make up 59% of the party's primary voters. But she also worries it is eroding one of the party's key advantages this year.
"Originally, I think Sanders played an important role mobilizing voters and articulating an important economic and change message," she says. "I think voters found refreshing the contrast with the Republicans of two candidates engaged in serious conversation about our country's future and offering a real platform. Now, with ridiculous, overstated attacks like Hillary isn't qualified, it makes us look as bad as the Republicans and turns off voters."
The tone problem was on full display at a big Sanders rally in New York City last week, where one speaker, health-care activist Dr. Paul Song, said liberals' goal of achieving Medicare for all won't happen "if we continue to elect corporate Democratic whores who are beholden to big pharma and the private insurance industry."
He later apologized and said he was referring to Democrats in Congress, not to Mrs. Clinton, and Mr. Sanders said the remarks were "inappropriate." Still, the tone is the sort of thing that could give moderate Republicans who might otherwise never vote for businessman Donald Trump a reason to think about doing exactly that.
It's also rhetoric consistent with Mr. Sanders's broader critique -- she's a captive of special interests who will abandon average folks, on their behalf -- which threatens to exacerbate her biggest problem: In the new Journal/NBC News poll, just 19% gave her good marks for being "honest and straightforward."
Mrs. Clinton appears to have the upper hand in a general-election matchup against either Mr. Trump or Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. But in either case, she'll need Sanders voters to show up. And it appears that in a matchup against Mr. Trump, a fair share of her vote would come from people embracing her as the lesser of two evils.
The problem with the Sanders attacks is he is close to portraying her as representing a kind of evil in the system, which threatens to erode that particular advantage.
Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Pyongyang Pans Both Trump and Clinton on North Korea Proposals; North Korean official says the country has 'no trust' in leading U.S. presidential candidates
article text:
ULAANBAATAR, Mongolia--North Korean government officials say proposals so far from the leading U.S. presidential candidates on the nuclear standoff with Pyongyang don't provide a path for resolving the crisis.
At a recent security conference in the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar, officials from North Korea's Foreign Ministry made presentations to defend what they say is a need to continue a nuclear-weapons program to deter possible U.S. attack. U.S. government representatives didn't attend the conference.
The North Korean officials also reiterated a longstanding demand that Washington sign a peace treaty with Pyongyang before any discussion about ending the North's nuclear program. The U.S. says North Korea must first move forward on denuclearization.
In conversations with The Wall Street Journal on the sidelines of the meeting, the officials expressed skepticism that the next U.S. president would achieve a breakthrough in bilateral relations.
Presumptive Republican Party candidate Donald Trump has made frequent comments about North Korea during campaigning, including a pledge to apply more pressure on China, Pyongyang's economic lifeline, to rein in its volatile neighbor.
On Wednesday, Mr. Trump said he would be willing to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in the U.S. to start a conversation. The two nations have no diplomatic relations.
The North Korean officials declined to discuss whether Mr. Kim would speak to Mr. Trump if the billionaire businessman is elected president. But they expressed skepticism that Mr. Trump would engage in dialogue.
"[President Barack] Obama also said before taking office that he would shake hands with enemy states. This is only for show, for electoral purposes," said one official.
During campaigning, presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton has emphasized continued coordination with U.S. allies such as South Korea and Japan to pressure North Korea diplomatically and economically.
As Secretary of State under Mr. Obama, Mrs. Clinton had a leading role in a 2012 deal with North Korea to provide aid in return for a freeze on its nuclear-weapons program. That agreement quickly collapsed when North Korea announced plans to launch a rocket using banned missile technology.
Mrs. Clinton subsequently used the phrase "strategic patience" to describe a policy of trying to pressure North Korea return to nuclear talks.
"We have no trust, no expectations for Mr. Trump or Hillary Clinton," the North Korean official said. He added that the strategic-patience policy had allowed North Korea to develop its nuclear deterrent.
North Korea held its fourth nuclear bomb test in January, followed by a long-range rocket launch a month later that was condemned by many nations as a test of ballistic missile technology. The United Nations, the U.S. and other countries then introduced new sanctions against North Korea.
A second North Korean official said that comments from the presidential candidates backing pressure on North Korea were misguided.
"My country will never kneel down to whatever strong sanctions may be imposed on us," he said during general discussion at the conference.
North Korean officials will also attend a security conference in Beijing starting Tuesday, according to people familiar with the event. U.S. Special Representative for North Korea policy Sung Kim will join the meeting but has no plans for direct talks with the North Korean delegation, according to the State Department.
Write to Alastair Gale at alastair.gale@wsj.com
Credit: By Alastair Gale

article name: Hillary Clinton's Daughter Chelsea Gives Birth to a Boy; Newborn Aidan Clinton Mezvinsky is presumptive Democratic presidential nominee's second grandchild
article text:
Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton is now a grandmother of two, with her daughter having given birth on Saturday to a boy, Aidan Clinton Mezvinsky.
In a Twitter message, Chelsea Clinton wrote that her husband Marc Mezvinsky "and I are overwhelmed with gratitude and love as we celebrate the birth of our son..."
She had announced she was pregnant with her second child in December.
Aidan is the little brother of Charlotte Clinton Mezvinsky, who will be two years old in September.
Mrs. Clinton often talks about being a grandmother on the campaign trail, mentioning how she sings to Charlotte. Chelsea Clinton, 36, told People Magazine last year that her mother had also baby-sat for Charlotte.
In a statement from former President Bill Clinton's office, he and Mrs. Clinton said: "We are all over the moon as Chelsea and Marc welcome Charlotte's little brother to the world and grateful for our many blessings. Chelsea and Aidan are both doing well and enjoying this very special time together."
There was no word on whether the youngest members of the growing Clinton-Mezvinsky family will be on hand at the Democratic presidential nominating convention next month in Philadelphia.
Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com
Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Donald Trump Says He Would Be Greater Supporter of Gay Community Than Hillary Clinton; Presumptive Republican presidential nominee reiterates he will defend Second Amendment rights
article text:
THE WOODLANDS, Texas--Donald Trump on Friday again asserted that he would be a better advocate for the gay community as president than Hillary Clinton after this week's mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., that killed 49 people.
Mr. Trump called out a supporter holding a "Gays for Trump" sign in the crowd during a rally in this suburb north of Houston, drawing cheers from thousands of people who came to see him. Such comments in rallies and on Twitter have unnerved evangelical supporters who oppose gay marriage.
The presumptive Republican presidential nominee also invoked a common refrain of gun control opponents in asking the crowd what would have happened if people inside the Orlando nightclub--"those wonderful people"--had been armed.
Bullets could have gone "in the opposite direction, right smack between the eyes of this maniac," he said, later calling the shooter a "son of a bitch." Mr. Trump's assurance that he would protect the Second Amendment, which protects Americans' right to keep and bear arms, drew some of the biggest cheers of the night.
Mr. Trump completed his swing through Texas by shrugging off criticism from some within his party over his opposition to free trade and assuring the crowd that he would appoint conservative justices to the Supreme Court.
"The party is actually liking me," he said. "You know, I'm an outsider, and historically, they don't like outsiders."
He celebrated the first anniversary of his candidacy with rallies and fundraisers in San Antonio, Dallas and Houston. Friday afternoon, he met with donors at the home of Tony Buzbee, a trial lawyer who has supported Democratic and Republican candidates, including former Texas Gov. Rick Perry.
While Texas has been a reliably Republican state for two decades, rallies by the party's nominees have been extremely rare as many have eschewed public events here, holding private fundraisers instead.
The New York real-estate magnate also said he was actively courting supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders, who has declined to withdraw from the Democratic race for president after Mrs. Clinton secured the delegates needed to clinch the nomination.
"We agree with Bernie on one thing, trade," Mr. Trump said, even as the crowd booed. "We're trying to get Bernie's people, because a lot of those people hate Hillary."
Write to Bradley Olson at Bradley.Olson@wsj.com
Credit: By Bradley Olson

article name: Trump and Clinton Show Strength in New York Poll
article text:
Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton hold double-digit leads in New York and are poised to regain their footing in their home state's primaries next Tuesday, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll finds.
On the Republican side, Mr. Trump holds a 33-point lead over his closest rival, Ohio Gov. John Kasich, 54% to 21%, while Texas Sen. Ted Cruz trails both, as the top pick of 18% of likely Republican primary voters.
Mrs. Clinton maintains a 14-point lead in the Democratic contest, outpacing Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders 55% to 41% among likely Democratic primary voters. The former secretary of state's lead is built on strength among women, African-Americans and Democrats age 45 and older.
The survey results will be welcome news to the two front-runners, who have both lost ground in recent weeks. Mr. Trump is looking to bounce back from a decisive loss in last week's Wisconsin primary, while Mrs. Clinton has lost eight of the last nine Democratic contests.
"Right now, the front-runners look like they will erase recent setbacks and add significantly to their delegate margins," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, which conducted the survey. "New York is not likely to enhance the hopes of those trying to close the gap in the delegate hunt."
Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump remain the clear leaders in their parties nominating contests. Mrs. Clinton has a particularly strong advantage because of her support from her party's so-called superdelegates, the elected officials and other party leaders who have a say in determining the presidential nominee.
Mr. Trump is in a tougher spot because he is in a race to collect the 1,237 delegates required to clinch the nomination before the party gathers in Cleveland to determine the nominee. He has so far won 743. A big win in New York would help him reset his campaign narrative, after he surrendered delegates to the Cruz camp at a string of recent state party conventions.
On Monday, Mr. Trump, prompted by the result of the Colorado contest in which Mr. Cruz won all 34 delegates, complained that the GOP delegate-selection process, which differs from one state to the next, was established by party bigwigs to prevent political outsiders like him from winning the nomination. "The system is rigged, it's crooked," he said in an interview on Fox News.
At the same time, he acknowledged that two of his children won't be able to vote in the New York primary because they missed the registration deadline. "They feel very, very guilty," he said.
The Republican contest in New York, like the Democratic race, is limited to voters who have registered with the party.
Mr. Trump leads his two remaining rivals by at least a two-to-one margin among just about every demographic group in the New York electorate, among them women, college graduates and those primary voters who practice a religion -- three groups with which he often struggles.
New York will award 95 Republican delegates next Tuesday. A candidate can win all of the delegates from any given congressional district if he eclipses the 50% mark.
Mr. Cruz entered the New York contest riding high, following his convincing win in Wisconsin last week. But he is struggling to get a foothold in the Empire State, a difficulty attributed in part to his attack on what he called Mr. Trump's "New York values" earlier in the primary cycle. The senator defended those remarks last week, telling reporters he was referring to the "values of liberal Democratic politicians."
Mr. Cruz spent Monday on the West coast, attending campaign events in California, the last stop on the primary calendar where the remaining contenders will fight over the state's 172 delegates. Mr. Trump can't wrap up the nomination before California and four other states vote June 7.
"I'm going to say a sentence that hasn't been said for 50 years," Mr. Cruz said. "California is going to decide the Republican nomination."
At the same stop, the Texas senator taunted Mr. Trump for complaining about the delegate-selection process. "When people vote against him, they are stealing the election," Mr. Cruz said.
In the latest poll, New York Republicans were also asked about the biggest question hanging over the GOP contest: What should happen if no candidate enters the convention this summer with a majority of delegates, the threshold for clinching the nomination.
A large majority -- 64% -- thinks Mr. Trump should win the nomination if he has the most delegates, even if he falls short of a majority, the poll found.
If Mr. Trump doesn't win the nomination, most primary voters also said they would oppose any effort to crown someone who didn't run for president this year, throwing cold water on speculation that party leaders should nominate House Speaker Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) or some other Republican who sidestepped the primary. Some 59% said the nominee should be someone who ran in the primaries, while 32% said it would be acceptable to have a nominee who didn't.
The Democratic primary in New York is showing voting patterns familiar from prior contests, with independents, liberals and younger voters lining up behind Mr. Sanders, and Mrs. Clinton dominating among self-described Democrats and other traditional constituencies. Mrs. Clinton, who was twice elected to represent the state in the U.S. Senate, has a big advantage in New York City and the surrounding suburbs, while the race is effectively deadlocked upstate.
In what could be troubling trends for Mrs. Clinton in the general election, Mr. Sanders owns a slight lead among Latino Democrats, and his supporters are far less likely to back Mrs. Clinton in November than her backers are to support him. Some 30% of Sanders supporters said they wouldn't support Mrs. Clinton if their candidate doesn't win the nomination. By contrast, 15% of Clinton supporters said they wouldn't back Mr. Sanders should he become the nominee.
The two Democratic candidates are fighting over 247 delegates in New York.
The Journal/NBC News/Marist survey of New York, conducted April 6-10, included 259 likely Republican primary voters and 557 likely Democratic primary voters. The margin of error is plus or minus 6.1 percentage points among GOP voters and 4.2 points among Democrats.


Enlarge this image.

Credit: By Patrick O'Connor

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Plays Up Endorsements --- Ex-New York senator counters 2016 trend by showcasing support of state's elected officials
article text:
NEW YORK -- Hillary Clinton heads into next week's presidential primary with the heavy backing of New York's Democratic establishment, a collection of support she has dispatched to assist her campaign from Manhattan to the far-reaching corners of the state.
The strategy challenges the notion that showcasing official endorsements wouldn't help much in an election year swept by enthusiasm for outsider candidates. Just as Ted Cruz tapped into Wisconsin's Republican establishment to help defeat Donald Trump in that state's primary April 5, Mrs. Clinton is betting her deep connections to Democratic officials here will help her win by a significant margin.
Mrs. Clinton, who served as a senator from New York for eight years before she was secretary of state, has amassed a list of more than 60 endorsements from Democratic public officials. Those range from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who backed her within hours of the declaration of her candidacy last April, to Long Island town supervisors.
For Mrs. Clinton, who has a big lead in polls ahead of the April 19 primary, even casual campaign stops are accompanied by elected officials. On Monday, U.S. Rep. Joseph Crowley sat with her at a Bangladeshi-Pakistani restaurant in Jackson Heights in Queens, where he recalled her having campaigned for Senate. On Saturday, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries and others joined Mrs. Clinton at famed Junior's Restaurant in Brooklyn.
Bernie Sanders, by contrast, has picked up support from a small handful of mainly state and local officials. The Vermont senator also has enlisted celebrities, including actors Rosario Dawson, Susan Sarandon and Mark Ruffalo and, in recent days, Michael Stipe, formerly of the band R.E.M.
At an Albany rally on Monday, Mr. Sanders was introduced by Bill Perkins, a state senator.
"I appreciate Bill's support because this campaign not too surprisingly is not getting a whole lot of support from elected officials," Mr. Sanders said. "We are taking on the establishment, and every now and then there is a brave man and woman who is elected who is prepared to do the right thing."
Mrs. Clinton's backers have rebuffed those suggestions with praise for the former senator and ever-more-intimate tales of early personal encounters with her.
U.S. Rep. Paul Tonko recounted speaking with Mrs. Clinton during a "listening tour" she undertook when running for Senate. Albany City Council President Carolyn McLaughlin recalled when her mother pushed her out of the way at an Albany County Democratic picnic to shake then-Sen. Clinton's hand.
And former Albany Mayor Jerry Jennings recounted how, when the Clintons came to town for a pair of Bill Clinton campaign events in 1992, he told the then-Democratic candidate: "There's only one person who can beat you: Your wife."
New York political consultant Hank Sheinkopf, a Democrat who is unaffiliated with either campaign, called New York "Clinton country" and predicted she would win. But he questioned whether the institutional support would translate into votes.
"The issue here for Secretary Clinton is that generally more ideological voters turn out in primaries," he added.
And Mrs. Clinton's institutional backing hasn't come without its own complications during the run-up to the vote.
Mr. Sanders's supporters -- and Mr. Sanders himself -- have criticized Mrs. Clinton for appearing with Mr. Cuomo at a rally to support the new law for a $15 minimum wage in parts of the state when Mrs. Clinton doesn't support that wage floor on the federal level.
And last week, when Mrs. Clinton praised Mr. Cuomo during a speech to the New York State United Teachers, a union that has feuded with the governor, those remarks were met with forceful booing.
While Mrs. Clinton's support from New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, with whom she appeared onstage at a black-tie dinner Saturday night in Manhattan, could help the candidate on the left, "de Blasio might alienate moderate Democrats," said Doug Muzzio, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College in Manhattan.
At a Sanders rally in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last week, Nick Rizzo, the Democratic district leader, said he thinks Mr. Sanders has a great ground game in Brooklyn -- but that institutional support would help Mrs. Clinton, "particularly in a close primary."
Mr. Rizzo said he believes many politicians side with Mr. Sanders but can't endorse him in New York. Pointing to New York City Council member Rafael Espinal, who was at the event, he added: "It's not a coincidence that the only other elected official in Brooklyn here supporting Bernie has arm tattoos and a beard."
---
Peter Nicholas and Josh Dawsey contributed to this article.
Credit: By Erica Orden

article name: Election 2016: Trump, Clintons Strictly Business
article text:
One of the provocative questions in the 2016 presidential race is what dealings Donald Trump and the Clintons had over the years. Were they friends, allies or rivals as Mr. Trump built his fortune and Hillary and Bill Clinton pursued their political ambitions?
On Tuesday, the Clinton Presidential Library released about 500 pages of material dating from Mr. Clinton's presidency that offer a few insights into how the Clinton White House saw the business mogul, now the leading Republican presidential candidate.
The documents, released in response to a public-records request, provide little evidence of a personal relationship, showing only that the White House had a passing interest in Mr. Trump's business deals and his earlier flirtation with a White House bid.
The records include logs of White House holiday cards sent to Mr. Trump, an autographed copy of Mr. Trump's book "The Art of the Deal" and news clippings about the businessman's contemplation of a presidential campaign in 1999.
Emails from Betty Currie, Mr. Clinton's personal secretary at the White House, show a brief internal discussion about whether to send birthday greetings to Mr. Trump.
"What are [your] thoughts on sending a birthday letter to Donald Trump -- who turns 50 on June 14," Ms. Currie wrote in a June 1996 email to another White House staffer. "Please forward response to Maureen Lewis who will prepare letter -- if you approve. Thanks."
A few days later, that plan apparently was scrapped. "Cancel letter to Donald Trump," Ms. Currie wrote.
At the White House, Mr. Clinton's aides followed speculation that Mr. Trump might run for president and made sure he was properly briefed on the matter before interviews. The tone of the briefing materials suggests Mr. Trump was seen as less a credible potential candidate than a curiosity.
In a memo to Mr. Clinton before a planned TV interview with Bryant Gumbel, aides included a sample question-and-answer involving the political ambitions of Mr. Trump and a few other celebrities.
"This year we've been treated to news that Donald Trump, Cybil Shepherd, Jesse Ventura and Warren Beatty might run for president," the sample question read. "Is this the result of a demeaning of the office that you've contributed to?"
In a suggested answer, the aides wrote, "I don't think what I've done has anything to do with such political developments. We go through all sorts of cycles in politics, and we're in one now where some people from the entertainment world are talking about running for president . . ." When the interview took place, Mr. Gumbel didn't ask about Mr. Trump.
A White House diary entry in 2000 records that Mr. Clinton posed for a photo with the businessman at Trump Tower in New York. Another file details invitations sent to Mr. Trump for White House events.
The records include an assortment of news articles and memos that make mention of Mr. Trump, a few of his real estate deals and interviews he gave in 1999 about a potential presidential campaign.
Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Black Women Prove Vital For Clinton --- African-American officeholders and voters help propel candidate's campaign
article text:
Hillary Clinton never goes very far without black women sharing the stage, introducing her around or casting ballots for her in outsize numbers -- and they are a prime reason she stands on the cusp of claiming the Democratic presidential nomination.
Black women have long played a big role in Mrs. Clinton's life and career, and now their expanding roles in politics -- as voters, officeholders and activists -- have lifted the Clinton campaign in multiple ways.
Exit polls show turnout by black women in Democratic primaries is significantly higher than turnout by black men, in several cases more than double. And black women have overwhelmingly supported the former senator and secretary of state over rival Bernie Sanders, with 90% or more of them voting for her in some states. In New York, she took 79% of their votes on her way to an easy victory, the exit polls show.
Mr. Sanders, a senator from Vermont, has repeatedly tried to make inroads with black voters, without much success. Mr. Sanders's best showing so far with black women came in Missouri, but Mrs. Clinton still took 70%, according to the exit polls.
Ahead of the New York primary this month, Rep. Yvette Clarke, a black woman who represents Brooklyn, was constantly at her side. In Ohio, she frequently shared the stage with Rep. Marcia Fudge of Cleveland.
"Black women really are the backbone of the Democratic Party," Ms. Fudge said in an interview.
Winning with African-American voters carries outsize importance because of Democratic Party rules that the Clinton campaign grasped early on. Delegates to the national convention are allocated by congressional district, and districts that have historically turned out more Democratic votes get more delegates.
The result: Districts with large black populations have many more delegates than others.
Take Ms. Fudge's northeast Ohio district. Typically, congressional districts each get between four and eight delegates, but hers had 17, more than any other in the nation. Eleven of them went to Mrs. Clinton.
Black women have long registered and voted at higher rates than their male counterparts, but in the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections, they surpassed all other racial and ethnic groups in their turnout rates.
It isn't just an Obama effect, said Maya Harris, who studied the subject at the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank, and who now works for the Clinton campaign. She pointed to the 2013 Virginia gubernatorial race, when high turnout rates among black women helped elect Democrat Terry McAuliffe, who took 38% of white women but a whopping 91% of black women.
At the same time, more black women are being elected to office. There are 20 black women in the House, including two nonvoting members, many of whom have campaigned with Mrs. Clinton. Four black women are big-city mayors. And black women have increased their representation in state legislatures by nearly 50% since 1994, according to a study by the Center for American Women& Politics at Rutgers University.
Black women also are the driving force behind activist groups that hold particular sway in the Democratic Party, such as Black Lives Matter and Mothers of the Movement, made up of women who have lost children to gun violence or in police custody.
"We decided to support Hillary, because she supported us," said Nicole Paultre-Bell, whose fiance, Sean Bell, was killed in a police encounter hours before their wedding.
That support has withstood anger among some African-American activists about her support for the 1994 crime bill, which her husband signed into law. At a fundraiser earlier this year, a black woman unveiled a banner quoting a speech she gave as first lady, when she referred to violent criminals as "superpredators" and said, "we have to bring them to heel." After that, Mrs. Clinton said that that she shouldn't have used that language.
In interviews, many black voters and leaders said they relate to Mrs. Clinton's long, bumpy career, including the public airing of her husband's extramarital affairs. "She has taken a beating for many things publicly, and she's still standing. And we feel the same way," Ms. Fudge said.
"There was no barrier when you first met her," said Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D., Texas). "We see her as a fellow sister."
Mrs. Clinton's chief of staff at the State Department, 2008 campaign manager and her first boss after law school have all been black women. She has counted many well-known black women as friends, such as the late Dorothy Height, a civil rights and women's rights activist.
Still, if she wins the Democratic nomination, the question remains whether she will be able to motivate black women, and men, to go to the polls in November in the same numbers that Mr. Obama did.
Interviews with black women in many of the states that have voted so far suggest she is making the sale. "There's something in her character," said Loreatha Jones of Brooklyn, who is retired. "I feel that she speaks for me. She speaks to me and she speaks about me, which most people can't."
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Trump Wouldn't Pull In Democrats, Says Clinton
article text:
Hillary Clinton flatly dismissed Donald Trump's suggestion that he can win over supporters of rival Bernie Sanders in the fall election, arguing that the Republican's views on a range of issues would repel them.
In an interview Friday with CNN, Mrs. Clinton also said she wouldn't back down from her focus on women's issues, and professed little concern about Mr. Trump's assertion that she wouldn't win 5% of the vote if she weren't a woman.
"If playing the 'women's card' means standing up for the concerns that women have and that they express to me, then deal me in," she said, using what has become a signature phrase for her campaign. "Because that's exactly what I've always done for decades [and] what I will do in this campaign."
She also cited her two successful elections to the U.S. Senate and the many votes she has received in the 2008 and 2016 presidential elections. "So it doesn't really square with reality," she said. His attacks are "kind of silly," she said, saying she is more bothered by his attacks on other groups.
Mr. Trump set off the latest back-and-forth on Tuesday after both he and Mrs. Clinton had strong showings in the East Coast primaries. "Frankly, if Hillary Clinton were a man, I don't think she'd get 5% of the vote. The only thing she's got going is the woman's card," he said. That prompted days of mocking by the Clinton campaign and its supporters.
Mr. Trump stuck with the attack, saying that Mrs. Clinton couldn't run for "city council" without the "woman's card."
Mr. Trump and Mr. Sanders share some views -- such as opposition to free-trade agreements -- and have both challenged their respective political establishments. Mr. Trump has suggested that he could win over some of the Sanders backers if Mr. Sanders loses the Democratic nomination.
Mrs. Clinton dismissed that idea. She cited climate change, the minimum wage and equitable pay for women as issues where Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump are at odds and called the Republican front-runner's foreign policy views "reckless, loose, dangerous."
"I don't think that's very appealing" to Sanders backers, she said. "I'm going to be very aggressive in . . . reaching out to Sen. Sanders's supporters, but we have so much more in common. And we have far more in common than they do with Donald Trump or any Republican."
Asked about insults that Mr. Trump had delivered to her, Mrs. Clinton said in the CNN interview, "I have a lot of experience dealing with men who sometimes get off the reservation in the way they behave and how they speak." An aide said she was referring to past GOP opponents. "I'm not going to deal with their temper tantrums or their bullying or their efforts to try to provoke me," she said.
After his losses on Tuesday in four out of five states, Mr. Sanders, who trails in the race for convention delegates, suggested he was staying in the contest in hopes of influencing the Democratic Party's platform on key issues. Mrs. Clinton suggested to CNN that there may be room for discussion.
"We're gonna talk. We're gonna work together. Because, look, we want the same goals," she said. "We really are going to be unified and have a tremendous progressive agenda to run on in the fall. And I really think that will help us win the election and it will also help us govern."
Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Clinton, Cruz Rake In Campaign Donations
article text:
Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Ted Cruz and their allies have millions of dollars on hand and are in the strongest financial positions in their respective parties as they head into the primary season's final stretch, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, donations to the super PAC backing Gov. John Kasich sagged and his campaign saw just a small fundraising bump following his win last month in his home state of Ohio.
A super PAC backing Mrs. Clinton, Priorities USA Action, raised $11.7 million last month -- more than double its February haul -- and had $44.6 million left to spend at the end of March, according to its FEC filing.
The PAC's haul will supplement strong fundraising by Mrs. Clinton's campaign, which ended March with $29 million in the bank. Mrs. Clinton had been outraised in March by rival Bernie Sanders -- bringing in $29.3 million to the Vermont senator's $46 million -- but spent her funds at a slower rate. Mr. Sanders churned through his cash in March, and ended the month with $17 million in the bank.
Campaigns and super PACs were required to disclose their March fundraising to the FEC by midnight on Wednesday.
Mr. Cruz, a Texas senator, had $8.8 million in the bank at the end of March. He raised $12.5 million during the month.
GOP front-runner Donald Trump loaned his campaign another $11.5 million last month -- bringing his total loans to more than $36 million -- and raised another $2.7 million from outside donors. While his cash-on-hand figure, at $2.1 million, was barely higher than Mr. Kasich's, Mr. Trump has said he is willing to spend uncapped amounts on the campaign.
Mr. Cruz is also backed by a growing network of super PACs that raised at least $10 million last month and had more than $21 million left to spend. The super PAC backing Mr. Trump, which launched a $1 million ad campaign on his behalf last month, had not yet filed with the FEC.
Super PACs can raise money without contribution caps but are barred from coordinating with or donating to campaigns.
Trusted Leadership PAC, a super PAC in the network of pro-Cruz groups, saidWednesdaythat it raised $4.5 million in March. Trusted Leadership PAC's biggest donors last month were Stan Herzog, chief executive of Missouri-based Herzog Contracting Corp., and Richard Uihlein, owner of a Wisconsin-based shipping company. Each gave $1 million.
Credit: By Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Clinton Chugs On With Easy Victory
article text:
Hillary Clinton decisively won her home-state New York primary Tuesday, shutting down one of the few remaining chances for rival Bernie Sanders to slow her march to the Democratic presidential nomination.
Mr. Sanders had pointed to New York, where he was born, as a place where he could take a bite out of Mrs. Clinton's formidable lead in convention delegates. He campaigned hard in what became a sharp-edged fight for the state, delivering his call for a political revolution to thousands of people who crowded a series of outdoor rallies.
But Mrs. Clinton, who represented the state for eight years in the Senate, racked up impressive vote totals in New York City, with its diverse electorate, and in its populous suburban counties. Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator, performed better upstate.
"The race for the Democratic nomination is in the home stretch, and victory is in sight!" Mrs. Clinton told cheering supporters Tuesday in New York City, appearing on stage with her husband, former President Bill Clinton, who campaigned heavily on her behalf.
She focused sharply on the general election ahead, said almost nothing critical of Mr. Sanders and began what may be a long process of unifying the party around her. "To all the people who supported Sen. Sanders, I believe there is much more that unites us than divides us," she said.
Speaking ahead of the results Tuesday evening, Mr. Sanders conceded nothing, telling a crowd at Penn State University that his campaign was challenging the notion that change is not possible and "this is the way it always will be."
Mr. Sanders also took several now-familiar shots at Mrs. Clinton, and earlier in the day, aides said his recent sharp tone wasn't likely to change even with a New York loss. But if Mrs. Clinton backs off him, they said, he may do the same.
The delegate math is steeply against Mr. Sanders. He came into the New York contest having won eight of the past nine contests and drawing tens of thousands of people to his rallies. But his delegate gain from those mostly small-state victories was modest.
Heading into New York's voting, Mrs. Clinton had an advantage of 244 pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters, according to preliminary Associated Press tallies.
Overall, she had 1,289 pledged delegates, and when you include superdelegates -- party leaders who can support anyone -- supporting her, Mrs. Clinton's total jumped to 1,758 to his 1,076. A total of 2,383 delegates is needed to claim the nomination.
Mrs. Clinton has won most of the large, diverse states, and the Vermont senator's recent wins have done little to cut into a yawning delegate deficit. Now just three large states remain on the Democratic calendar -- Pennsylvania next week, and California and New Jersey in June.
The victory was a relief for Mrs. Clinton, who campaigned hard to avoid what would have been an embarrassing loss, even one that may not have prevented her from winning the nomination.
Mr. Sanders faced tough odds from the outset, in part because the state has a large proportion of nonwhite voters, who have generally favored Mrs. Clinton. In addition, New York barred independents, who have been friendly to Mr. Sanders, from voting in party primaries, and it required voters who wanted to switch party affiliation to do so six months ago.
But ahead of the results, top Sanders advisers said the senator had no plans to take the pressure off his Democratic rival as long as she keeps up her critiques of the Vermont senator.
"We have received a lot of innuendo and dismissiveness and demeaning comments from the Clinton campaign -- from the secretary herself and from her surrogates," Jane Sanders, the candidate's wife and a close adviser, said in an interview. "He's not going to sit by and just not respond."
Clinton advisers are hoping the New York victory will allow the former secretary of state to turn her attention to the fall contest. For many weeks, Mrs. Clinton has taken shots at her GOP opponents, but Mr. Sanders's strength has forced her to keep much of her focus on the primary.
"You have to unify the party, and you don't want to prematurely look past someone who has earned a lot of votes and put up a strong fight," one senior adviser said. "The timing is everything."
During the campaign for New York, the Vermont senator ramped up his attacks on his rival. He aired a TV ad contrasting his rival's high-paid Wall Street speeches with her opposition to raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. (Mrs. Clinton supports a $12 federal floor.)
Mr. Sanders also said her positions made her unqualified for the presidency, though he quickly backed away from that assertion.
Mrs. Clinton also was tough, particularly on the issue of gun restrictions, suggesting Mr. Sanders isn't being truthful about his record and accusing him of personally blocking a lawsuit by families of children killed in the 2012 school massacre in Newtown, Conn.
Sanders senior adviser Tad Devine said Mrs. Clinton and her supporters have the power to change the tenor of the race. "If the Clinton campaign stops their attacks, that will go a long way to changing the tone," he said after the race was called.
Clinton communications director Jennifer Palmieri said Tuesday night that in light of Mrs. Clinton's dominant position, Mr. Sanders "has to decide if he's going to stay on this destructive path where he's making personal character attacks. . . Or will he return to running the campaign on issues?"
One Sanders adviser said that even if the senator doesn't win the nomination, he hopes that picking up as many delegates as possible would give him leverage to press his agenda at the convention.
"Does Bernie think he can win? He thinks he can win, yes -- and he [also] is trying to get delegates to push his issues," said Larry Cohen, a longtime labor leader and a Sanders adviser.
---
Erica Orden contributed to this article.
Credit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Berning the Clinton Establishment
article text:
Hail and farewell, Bernie.
The Vermont senator isn't yet mathematically boxed out of the Democratic nomination, but near enough for government work. Hillary Clinton's victory Tuesday in New York has her confident enough of winning the prize that she's now pivoting to the general election. Mr. Sanders felt the need to issue a memo insisting he can still win -- so even he knows that he has a problem. Barring an intervention by God, or the FBI, Hillary wins.
Perhaps rightly, considering voter sentiment and party prospects. Mrs. Clinton has won more states, more votes, and more pledged delegates. And she's likely the better general-election candidate: a tough campaigner, stronger across varied demographics, who has won six of the nine crucial swing states and isn't a self-declared socialist. Mr. Sanders's vow to go all the way to Philly, and to try to use superdelegates to overturn these results, increasingly risks looking like sour grapes.
And yet Mrs. Clinton is still the loser. This has been, from the start, the Bernie Sanders show. Hillary came into the race determined to rev up the old Clinton machine, to revive the Clinton era, to burnish the long Clinton legacy. Instead, Mr. Sanders has forced her to betray it. He provided the sword, and she has slain the Clinton Democrats.
A few months in politics feels like ages, but it wasn't so long ago that the knock on Hillary Clinton's campaign was that it was content free. She spent months on the road, "listening," refusing to state her views. The cipher expected coronation, and was intent on preserving maximum flexibility for the general election. Mr. Sanders blew up that strategy.
As he surged, Hillary had to do far more than come clean. She had to abandon every winning, centrist, New Democrat position that had defined the Clinton years. Bill Clinton left office with the highest approval rating of any president since World War II. Mrs. Clinton has spent the past six months in essence saying that everything he did was weak, phony or wrong.
Bill's was the party of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Hillary's is the party that opposes even a Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiated by the union-rolled Obama administration. Mrs. Clinton protests that she still supports trade but objects to the specifics of TPP. Does anyone envision a new President Clinton recrafting the deal?
Bill's was the party that increased permits for oil and gas drilling by more than 50% -- even as it hailed the Kyoto Protocol. Hillary's is the party that now opposes the Keystone XL pipeline, opposes offshore drilling, and even opposes one of the country's greatest economic engines -- fracking. "By the time we get through all of my conditions," she promised in March, "I do not think there will be many places in America where fracking will continue to take place." Climate isn't simply the left's new religion, but core unfinished business for the White House, and Mrs. Clinton would make it a hallmark of her presidency.
Hillary Clinton has no time for Bill's old plans for Social Security reform; she'd expand the program to provide bigger payouts to women and widows. She's over his $5.15 federal minimum wage and in a bidding war with Mr. Sanders that begins, but doesn't end, at $15 an hour. She's for debt-free college, mandatory family leave, and $1 trillion in new spending for infrastructure, education and solar panels. The era of big government is so back. Bill Clinton might charge political manslaughter, at the hands of his wife, at the direction of Mr. Sanders.
And Hillary's switcheroos have also come at a price to the Clinton brand. The Sanders purists see her lurches left as false, and another reason not to trust her. Especially when they are combined with Mr. Sanders's relentless criticism of her money-grubbing and Wall Street ties. He has taken heat for ignoring her FBI scandal, probably because he was worried of being accused of stoking what Mrs. Clinton claims is a right-wing plot. Instead he shrewdly went at her ethics via topics that wind up his base: cozy ties with corporations, dark money, lobbyists. Even Mrs. Clinton's new vitriol against American business (another change) hasn't helped deflect the charges.
Mrs. Clinton's disapproval ratings -- 56% of Americans hold a negative view of her in the recent WSJ poll -- can't be blamed on Republicans, who've largely been too busy beating up one another to go after her. They are a function of the Vermonter. And they translate into depressed enthusiasm. As the stats master Michael Barone wrote this week, in 16 of the 21 primaries so far, Hillary has "received fewer votes than in 2008, or fewer votes than Obama got when he beat her." That's worrisome news for a woman hoping to reassemble the Obama coalition for victory in November.
A lot of that dynamic will come down to the caliber of Mrs. Clinton's Republican opponent. The nomination is hers for the taking. But the winner -- politically -- in this season of Democratic distress is the man who Berned up the Clinton establishment.
---
Write to kim@wsj.com
License this article from Dow Jones Reprint Service
Credit: By Kimberley A. Strassel

article name: Clinton's Negative Majority
article text:
Hillary Clinton won New York's primary Tuesday, which means that barring an act of God or FBI director Jim Comey -- they aren't the same -- she will be the Democratic nominee for President. So Democrats should be alarmed by the former first lady's rising unpopularity.
The latest evidence comes in the new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll taken April 10-14. A regular feature of this survey asks voters about their "feelings toward" certain individuals or institutions -- whether they are very positive, somewhat positive, neutral, somewhat negative or very negative. In April the poll found Mrs. Clinton hitting a dubious new record of 56% who have somewhat or very negative feelings toward her. Only 32% have a positive view.
As striking is the negative trend over the last three years. In Jan. 2013, not long after she left President Obama's cabinet, her net negative was 25%. As the nearby chart shows, her unpopularity has since climbed with only occasional exceptions (See accompanying chart -- WSJ April 20, 2016). She broke through negative 40% in the middle of last year, and she hit negative 50% in February. In April a remarkable 42% had a very negative view of the woman Democrats are counting on to hold the White House.
Some of this is explainable by the pounding any candidate takes during a campaign. Bernie Sanders has been portraying Mrs. Clinton as a tool of the big banks, even if he's ducked her serious ethical problems. But what should worry Democrats is that Bill Clinton's wife has been a national political figure since 1992, and her political identity is well known and will be hard to change.
All of which means Republicans should be poised to retake the White House in November if they nominate someone remotely tolerable. Yet they may not. Donald Trump reinforced his GOP front-runner status Tuesday with a blowout victory in his home state of New York, but his negative rating in the WSJ/NBC survey is an astounding 65%. Ted Cruz is disliked by 49%, though he's less well known, with 21% having a neutral view. The Texan finished a distant third in New York to John Kasich.
Hard to believe, but Messrs. Trump and Cruz may be the only two Republicans who could lose to Hillary Clinton.

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Pivots Toward Trump
article text:
JENKINTOWN, Pa. -- Hillary Clinton has yet to secure the delegates to clinch the Democratic presidential nomination, but the front-runner is increasingly turning to the themes likely to dominate a potential general election campaign against Donald Trump.
In a campaign swing across Pennsylvaniaon Friday, Mrs. Clinton trained her fire not on her Democratic opponent, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who is trailing in the delegate count and facing an uphill battle, but on Mr. Trump, the Republican front-runner who remains her most likely opponent in November.
Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as the candidate best able to stand up to defend the groups of Americans that Mr. Trump has frequently singled out in his speeches -- previewing a line of attack that her campaign is sure to use if Mr. Trump becomes the Republican nominee.
"I'm not going to respond to what he said about me. I'm going to respond to what he has said about women in general. I'm going to respond to what he has said about immigrants. I'm going to respond to what he has said about Muslims. I'm going to respond on behalf of all the people who have been the target of his hatred and his demagoguery," said Mrs. Clinton at a restaurant here in Jenkintown.
Mrs. Clinton was referring to Mr. Trump's proposal to bar Muslims temporarily from entering the U.S., his comparison of illegal immigrants to rapists and a string of past comments about prominent women.
Meanwhile, Mr. Trump has increasingly professionalized his small campaign operation, bringing on board a veteran GOP operative and stepping up his outreach to party regulars. Despite an off-the-cuff oratory style that has propelled him to the top of the Republican primary field, he has said that he will add teleprompters and a speechwriter to his staff to give him more message discipline going forward.
Mr. Trump, speaking to Fox News in an interview scheduled to air on Saturday, appeared prepared for Mrs. Clinton's attacks -- previewing his own general-election case against her by giving her the moniker "Crooked Hillary."
"The only thing she's got going is the women card," he said. "Without the women card, she's got nothing going, and she's gonna play it to the hilt, and I'm gonna be talking about things, and one of the things I talk about is, we call her Crooked Hillary because she's a crooked person -- she's always been a crooked person," he said in the interview.
Mrs. Clinton has been dogged by the revelation that she exclusively used a personal email server while serving as secretary of state, which wasn't illegal, but was discouraged by the government. She has also been attacked by Mr. Sanders for taking large speaking fees from major banks and corporations, and her family foundation's ties to business and foreign governments have drawn Republican criticism.
Female voters were paramount during Mrs. Clinton's stop in Jenkins, where she convened a roundtable discussion with more than two dozen women to discuss everything from equal pay to gun control. The stop included an appearance with Lilly Ledbetter, the plaintiff in a landmark pay-discrimination case who later became an activist for equal pay between men and women. Mrs. Clinton called Ms. Ledbetter a "heroine of the equal pay movement" and invited her to address the crowd.
That Mrs. Clinton has chosen Pennsylvania to make an aggressive case against Mr. Trump comes as the state has emerged as a potential general-election battleground.
Mr. Trump's best path to the presidency might run through states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Wisconsin -- Rust Belt states that have trended Democratic in recent years, but where Mr. Trump's advantages with blue-collar white voters might offset his high negatives among female and nonwhite voters. Mr. Trump and his supporters believe white, working-class voters can be mobilized to turn out in higher levels than they have in previous cycles.
Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Gets A New Keystone
article text:
Hillary Clinton won the Pennsylvania primary eight years ago in part by appealing to white, working-class voters with stories of her family roots in blue-collar Scranton and her childhood experience with guns.
Polls suggest she will win the Keystone State again on Tuesday, this time with a far different coalition -- a shift that could have big implications for the general election, should she win her party's nomination.
Mrs. Clinton now enjoys far less support from rural and working-class white Democrats, a Wall Street Journal analysis of this year's primary results shows. Instead, she is dominant among minority voters and upscale, urban and suburban professionals -- voters who eight years ago largely rejected her for then-Sen. Barack Obama.
In essence, Mrs. Clinton has adopted Mr. Obama's political coalition. Her rival this year, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, has taken over her leading position among rural, white voters and has claimed only one part of Mr. Obama's political base: young adults.
"There's been a kind of role-reversal, with Sanders winning the white, blue-collar workers -- people who earn under $50,000," said Terry Madonna, a professor of public affairs at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa.
That role reversal points to the strengths and weaknesses Mrs. Clinton would carry as her party's nominee.
With her new coalition of minority voters and generally upscale whites who live in metropolitan areas, Mrs. Clinton has a strong hand in cities and their diverse inner suburbs. Those are the battlegrounds in many key states.
Moreover, the groups now backing Mrs. Clinton are growing as a share of the population, whereas the share of working-class whites is shrinking. Nearly half of Mitt Romney's votes in 2012 came from working-class whites, but there weren't enough of them to push the GOP nominee to victory.
At the same time, Mrs. Clinton's standing among white voters, especially rural and working-class whites, has declined substantially. In November, that could pose a risk in states that are diversifying slowly.
In a Journal/NBC News survey this month, some 72% of white men said they had a negative image of Mrs. Clinton rather than a positive one. Some 64% of whites of both genders had a negative view of her, compared with 47% in 2008. Her image among rural voters has also declined.
Republican pollster Bill McInturff, who helps direct the Journal/NBC News poll, said he could imagine Mrs. Clinton losing white voters by margins big enough to "put this race into play," if her unpopularity among whites was accompanied by a drop in voter turnout among the young and minority voters who boosted Mr. Obama.
Aides to GOP front-runner Donald Trump have played up his own appeal among working-class, white voters to argue that he could beat Mrs. Clinton in Rust Belt states such as Pennsylvania and Michigan, although a recent Journal/NBC News/Marist poll undercuts that argument. In a survey of registered voters in Pennsylvania, Mrs. Clinton beats Mr. Trump by 15 percentage points in a hypothetical general-election matchup.
A look at which counties Mrs. Clinton won in her 2008 primary campaign, and which she has retained in this year's primary race, shows the magnitude of the change in her coalition.
Mrs. Clinton has won 349 rural, overwhelmingly white counties in states that have voted so far and for which data are available, a Journal analysis shows. In 2008, she had won 511 of those largely white counties in the same states -- some 162 more victories than this year.
While losing largely white counties, Mrs. Clinton has made big gains in cities and their adjacent suburbs. She has won 76 of these counties, a gain of 39 from 2008. Mrs. Clinton has also won more counties on the outer rim of metro areas than in 2008.
Credit: By Aaron Zitner and Dante Chinni

article name: Election 2016: Poll Finds Front-Runners Have Big Leads --- Trump, Clinton could boost their delegate counts Tuesday in Pennsylvania primary
article text:
Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton looked poised to build on their momentum-shifting wins in New York with victories in the Pennsylvania primaries Tuesday, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll shows.
Mr. Trump leads the Republican field in Pennsylvania as the top choice of 45% of likely GOP primary voters, the poll shows, outpacing Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, with 27%, and Ohio Gov. John Kasich at 24%.
In the Democratic race, Mrs. Clinton leads Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, 55%- 40%, among likely primary voters.
For Republicans, the statewide results in Pennsylvania -- one of five states voting Tuesday in New England and the Mid-Atlantic region -- could turn out to be more symbolic than binding.
